description:
My new favorite Taiwanese breakfast and lunch spot. The owners/workers here so nice it feels homey.

They have the fried donut and soy milk which gives me nostalgia when I was in Taiwan and I had those for breakfast. 

We also got the hot and sour soup -- good for when you're sick, and the usual General Tso's chicken. The chicken is good when you're hungry because they give you a lot for cheap.
author: Natascha E.

description:
Small Taiwanese restaurant on Clement with some pretty decent options. 
The day we went they were short staffed and service was pretty slow but the owner did apologize. 

We ordered the beef noodle soup which was pretty bland, but a little salt and chili sauce helped. 

Pros: Huge portions for reasonable price. 

Cons: Slow service. Food was mediocre
author: Milton F.

description:
I came here with my family and grandpa on a Sunday around 11am and the place was not packed, so we were seated immediately. We were immediately handed menus and tea was given to us. The service was alright, the man was more accommodating and attentive compared to the woman, but it wasn't that huge of a concern for us, considering that more customers came and the restaurant was filling up. 

Food:

- Potstickers: These are one of the biggest potstickers I've ever seen, and they were packed with meat. The potstickers were freshly made to order and overall, super good.

- Green beans: I love green beans (the dish comes with pork) and this dish had good flavor, though the beans were not as crunchy as I would've liked. You could definitely taste the char from their frying.

- Xiao long bao: Again, similar to the potstickers, these are one of the biggest xiao long baos I've ever seen. They were also packed with meat and just oh so delicious.

- Shanghai Noodles: The noodles were thick and starchy and I would definitely recommend this dish since its got noodles, meat, and veggies. This dish is one of our go-to dishes.

- Fried Doughnut: This is usually ordered with some sweet soy milk since it is a savory doughnut, but we decided not to get the soy milk and just the doughnut. It was freshly made and crunchy, but maybe just a little too oily for me. This satisfies any of those savory doughnut cravings. 

- Rice cakes: The rice cakes were very chewy and the dish didn't have much flavor, but it was a nice reprieve from other saltier dishes so it was a good balance. 

Overall, the dishes were good for the price you pay, and I would definitely come back if I'm in the area!
author: Lisa C.

description: Unfortunately the food here is not so authentic Taiwanese.  They do have a wide variety of food choices.  We had minced pork rice, three cup chicken and intestine pork blood tofu pot.  Everything was just not quite there.  With all that said, their customer service was awesome.  Everyone was kind and attentive.  Overall, I am giving a 3-star.
author: Andy C.

description:
Came to this place on a Monday during dinner time.
It was empty so very fast service.

Lots of seating!

Food: I was reccomended some dishes by someone so we ordered Spare Rib Pork, Potstickers, Spinach & Garlic, Mongolian Beef, and Steamed Rice.

Decently sized portion. Average/cheap pricing.

They have specials as well if you're on a budget.

Thoughts: Spinach & Garlic was cooked well. Good flavor.
Pork was sweet/tangy and lighty crispy. Mongolian Beef waa delicious, spicy! Potstickers are a must try!! So much flavorful and full of meat! Rice was good.

Overall good food with very fast service.
author: Michele G.

description: The beef stew noodle here saddens me. The broth was fairly watered down and the noodles were soggy. There was rare sighting of bok choy in the bowl. The chunks of tendon were decent, the beef chucks less exciting.
author: Cici T.

description: We've eaten here for years and enjoy the food and the staff. Recommend the potstickers, Dandan noodles and beef noodle soup. The green onion pancakes are nice and crispy.  Large portions and the staff are always nice and attentive.
author: Nancy P.

description:
Oversized , not juicy, XLB: Strike one.
Niu Ruo Xian Bing are using Mexican Tortilla wrap: Strike 2-3 (This is the greatest sin of them all).
Oversized, overly thick skin pot sticker: Strike 4
Host pushing to order more than I can eat, even though I asked how big each item, ( he mentioned pretty small portion), turns out I can eat for 3 full meal out of it! Strike 5.

How many strike to do out ? 3 yet we have 5.
The only good thing here is turnip cake! (Lo bak Go)
author: Dan A.

description: Ate lunch here. Street meter parking 2.25/hour if you can get space. Environment relatively clean for Chinese. Sugar, soy sauce, vinegar containers can use a good wipe down each night and hot wash weekly, greasy to the touch. Food was rather bland compared to Thai food.
author: Clifford W.

description: Family enjoy this place. We like to taste various dishes. Needless to say we over ordered. Everything tasty and plentiful for anoth
author: Deanna L.

description:
The Chinese donuts and hot soy milk (Northern Taiwanese breakfast staples) were excellent, though for the sweet version of the milk you'll have to add the sugar yourself. Definitely not a deal-breaker for me!

What I wouldn't order again:
- The scallion pancakes. Greasy and heavy.
- The xlb. Just don't, unless you enjoy thick and gummy dumpling skin. I only finished one!

The restaurant is family-run, totally unassuming, simple and straightforward - nothing special. But you come for the Chinese donuts and soy milk, obviously!
author: Jelena Z.

description: Tasted Sizzling rice soup, Dry Green Beans, and Happy Family Seafood. Pretty good Taiwanese style food and Northern Dishes. Delicious mid-PM Break.
author: Yee Ping C.

description:
The food is pretty good and satisfy our craving for Taiwanese food. Prices are good and service is prompt.
It's a small family business and I like supporting small local business. 
Most of the dishes are very home-style, not particularly unique but very tasty nonetheless.
author: Rosyan C.

description: Got 13 dishes for 7. All that was left was rice. The food was ok - not great not. As but cheap as hell. 13 dishes and rice for $125 not including tip. Atmosphere no frills. Service friendly and efficient. Men's restroom disgusting.
author: Marco M.

description:
I've eaten at this place for over 20 years, it's been one of my family's favorite restaurants to go to on the weekend together. The workers are always super friendly, nice, and attentive. I feel welcomed and appreciated here. 

We always HAVE to get the steamed dumplings (xiao long bao/小籠包), potstickers (鍋貼), Shanghai noodles, and a soup noodle. The soy milk and donuts are so good too. What I love about the food is you can watch them hand make their dumplings and donuts in the front, always tasting fresh and delicious! They also are very generous with the portions and with a very reasonable price too so I am always leaving stuffed and happy. 

It can get pretty busy on the weekends but it's worth the wait. The food also comes out pretty quick. All the other Taiwanese / Shanghainese places we try are no competition.

FYI: They've recently changed to CASH ONLY!
author: Allison S.

description:
I've been coming here for years with my family, and the food is always good.

I came in Sunday to eat lunch with my Dad shortly after 11am, and there was no wait. On the way in, you can observe the chefs make all the potstickers and donuts fresh from the fryer. What's great about this place is that my family is one of their usual customers, so my parents have become friends with the waitress so the atmosphere is always inviting. Although this place isn't the best looking restaurant, the food makes up for it.

I got my personal favorite the Mustard Green with Shredded Pork Noodle Soup, and my Dad got the Braised Beef Ligament Noodle Soup. 

Let me just say that the noodle soup portions are huge. If you're not a big eater and you order one of their noodle soups, I would suggest you split the bowl with someone. The mustard greens and pork are cooked in a sauce that adds a lot of flavor to the soup. Both bowls really hit the spot, but this time around the proportion of noodles to everything else was slightly higher than normal. Other tasty options are their potstickers, fried doughuts and unsweetened soymilk. The potstickers are so crisp and juicy, and the fried doughnuts go well while drinking the soymilk (there's sugar at the table for you to add yourself). The rice plates also come in huge portions as well incase you're not a noodle person.

Prices are decent, cleanliness is alright, and decor is bare minimum, BUT the food is what makes this place amazing.
author: Kevin S.

description: Went here for a Taiwanese breakfast because I was craving it after not having been to Taiwan for a while and it was really good. We got the salty soy milk, sweet soy milk, a krueller, and the deep fried turnip cakes and everything was tasty. The staff was also very nice and everything was decently priced.
author: Carolyn E.

description: This is a regular dining spot for my family and me. We love the potstickers and the pork chop noodle soup. The wait staff knows us and is super friendly and accommodating.
author: Descartes L.

description:
Overall, not satisfied and would not return. Below are dish I ordered.

- HOT & SOUR SOUP: this tasted as expected it should.
- 8 PIECE DEEP FRIED PRAWNS: tasty and would order again.
- DRY BRAISED GREEN BEANS: this was listed under their vegetarian options, it was not!! There was ground beef in the dish.
- BLACK BEAN SAUCE SQUIDS: could not taste the black bean sauce. dish was tasteless. would not order again.
- CURRY TOFU: was very bland and tasteless. would not order again.
author: Hello E.

description:
I do love this place. I've been coming here for 20 year with my family.

We always come here for the potstickers, the dumplings, and noodle soups. I love that they make all the potstickers and dumplings fresh. I also love that everything is really affordable.

Came in with my sister for dinner, we ordered potstickers, dumplings, two noodles dishes and it came out to be around $25. Apparently they are cash only now.
author: Jessica S.

description: Reasonable price and huge portion! The food is delicious too-- we got Mandarin beef, fish egg plant, and squid soup. Would definitely come back.
author: Tinaa T.

description: Great food, better service and amazing customer service by the owner. My original plan of having Chinese food delivered to the Financial District on Chinese New Year fell through. I found myself looking for other places that were open and I stumbled upon Taiwan Restaurant. The owner George was super kind and helpful, he was busy because I called the night prior Chinese New Year on my attempt to place an order for 30 people. He had to call me back like three times because he really wanted to ensure I was ordering enough food for my event. He was thoughtful, reasonable and made me feel he wasn't just thinking about him as a business owner but also on me as a customer. Excellent follow through and I can't be more grateful. The food was plenty, excellent and he gained a loyal customer for life, not to mention 30 other customers because the food was truly delish!
author: Pilar H.

description: Whole in the wall, but delicious. Potstickers are bomb. I do like the pickled vegetables shredded pork soup and the deep fried pork chops.
author: Bryan C.

description:
Taiwan Restaurant is alright. I would recommend if you were looking for a decently priced meal, but I wouldn't go in with a high expectation on quality of food -- at least not across all plates. 

I came to Taiwan Restaurant for lunch and ordered 5 dishes. After tax and tip, it came out to $26. For San Francisco that's definitely impressive! Service was also great. 

The Chinese donuts were good and the pot stickers were decent. They definitely don't skimp on portion size. However, as others have noted, stay away from the soup dumplings (XLBs). They were double the size they should be (probably not a good thing), the wrapping was extremely thick and there was no soup in the dumpling. 

All in all a good restaurant to go to every once in a while.
author: Bernard H.

description:
My friends and I were in search of good Chinese food when we to visit the Bay Area. Instead of going to the over-crowded tourist China Town, my Bay area friends took me to New China Town instead. This place is definitely a hole in the wall, so it wasn't busy. It's decently sized but the food was generous portions. I have to say this was one of the best Taiwanese food I had up in the Bay Area. Great for family style eating!

If you're looking for good, under the radar Chinese food: Try this!
author: Michelle M.

description: Went for dinner the other night. Was disappointed in the steamed dumplings. The meat filling was solid meat and no juice coming out as you bite into it. We think it's a new owner, pot stickers we big but meat wasn't as solid as the steamed dumplings. Just not the place it use to be. Maybe if we had no other place to go to but SF has so many Other restaurants to try. Sad it's not as good as before...
author: Kim F.

description:
It's been years, maybe even a decade.  
The original in Berkeley was the standard, though didn't dine there often while living on campus.
Then, their Chinatown/North Beach location was in my regular lunch rotation for takeout food since it was close to work.
This Inner Richmond staple is a change from the primarily Cantonese restaurants in the neighborhood.  My friend chose it for her birthday lunch on a recent Saturday.  While ordering post meal takeout, I recognized a waiter from that Chinatown location, leading me to believe ownership is likely the same.  Here's what we shared, all family style:

Appetizers
1.  Kuo Teh (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=GERaTy5i44rasD7Ug_8WTA) - Also known as pot stickers, these were nicely browned though skins are on the doughy side.

2.  Green onion pancake (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=oJk7G8GtWxavVDwXRmJTXA) - Crisp and served hot, these disappeared from the plate quickly.

3.  Steamed dumplings (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=bVTHJlHoJ4YQiirRjgLw9w) - Better known as Xiao Lung Baos, they are larger than most and like 1., skin on thick side.

4.  Taiwan special deep fried tofu (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=X-L5Bh-SdVNUHMCt3j3tcA) - Seeing a neighboring table's order, we added this.  Fried well but no distinct flavor.

5.  Fried squid (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=2KeA1m_3rWgKrf9FNTJKdA) - Probably my least favorite as they could pass for pork rinds.

6.  Wok-fried Shanghai thick noodles (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=h9FnAuBagMh80C4CBXQsGw) - The noodles were extraordinarily thick almost udon like.  Flavors were very distinct as chef had a light hand on the soy sauce while stir frying.

7.  Bean and meat sauce noodles (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=agbAC1NtfEOYP3SPCl4Izw) - Probably my favorite as seasonings were spot in.  A little more veggies might make this a must-order.

8.  Dry braised green beans (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Hard to do this wrong, they did a decent job in savoriness and not overcooking them.

9.  Smoked tofu, celery, and pork stir fry (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=s2EjsJtnF1mlqI2lsvCMCQ) - My second favorite of the meal, all ingredients shined.  Tofu size made smaller would make this perfect.

As many comment especially Ken K. (http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=DS0Idr2XDhz5e7ZfSy0dYA), this is a pretty far cry from authentic Taiwan food as far as flavors go.  The bar is set high in Southern California with the predominance of locals there.  Here, Cantonese palates reign and welcome any variation of Chinese cuisine available.  Portions are generous and prices are certainly reasonable here.  
Just don't expect to enjoy the true flavors that you'd enjoy in or around Taipei's night market.
author: Mike C.

description:
Delicious! We split the white turnip cakes, mandarin tofu, and fresh vegetable chow fun for lunch. Enormous portions. All for twenty bucks! 

*edit: it was our first visit and we found the restaurant from Yelp. Didn't disappoint!
author: Tyjen C.

description: The food here is always good. I particularly like the red wine, served by the carafe or if you're by yourself, and I am too often, by the 1/2 carafe. For the quality, quantity, and service I would like to to give this place 5 stars, however it is cold. I mentioned this to the server, who didn't seem to understand or care. I pointed out that everyone in the restaurant was still wearing their coats. I came to the conclusion that she understood, but was not able to do anything about the apparent lack of heat. The door is held open, I assume to provide make-up air to the kitchen hoods.
author: Iain A.

description: Tasty fresh made dumplings. Shrimp and leek and fatter/larger pork steamed are delicious. Scallion pancakes are also good. We added steamed spinach with garlic and it was enough for 3 adults and a 11 year old who doesn't always eat that much. Went down the street to get custard buns at Good Luck Dim Sum for dessert.
author: Jon R.

description:
While service may not be the friendliest or the fastest, this small restaurant delivers on taste.

Try their beef noodle soup (4/5) soup tastes homemade and the noodles are plenty and chewy. Their green onion pancake and turnip cake (3/5) are deep fried instead of pan fried, delicious but probably a little overwhelming if you eat more than one piece. I also recommend the basil chicken (4/5) which has many levels of flavor and a great dish to share.

Other items we've tried are dumplings (boiled and pan fried) (3/5) which were standard and rice cakes and Shang hai thick noodles (4/5).
author: Tiffany L.

description:
I only order 2 things here: the beef noodle soup and an order of pot stickers. Perfect comfort food and still good even when you order it to go for pickup. 
They speak Chinese to me but I do not understand what they are saying. Try the potstickers with red vinegar and hot sauce. Yumm.
author: Mari A.

description: Family owned for 30 + years! They can serve to vegans & the decor is in pink shades. The prices are reasonable & the portions are huge.
author: R C.

description:
I gave Taiwan another try at the urging of the owner and it's clear the previous visit was an off day. Everything was fresh, well prepared and piping hot. 

I did some examination of my favorite Spicy Prawns, however, and realized the problem is that the batter is simply water and cornstarch which makes for bland flavor. I'm sure they used to put something else in there (when I make this dish at home I add sesame oil and soy sauce). 

But that gives me justification to explore the menu on my next visit, so I'm good.
author: Otis M.

description:
Probably the best pot stickers and xiao long bao on Clement St.  Amazingly my kids love this place despite its crowded and old decor.  Forget that they have a piece of rope tying the door to a pole so the door doesnt fly open

Nicknamed the Chinese Pink Palace this has been around since at least the 80s. They have a wok in the window where they make their pot stickers fresh!!

We ended up here on Christmas Eve.  As my mom says,  the only things you'll find open on Christmas eve are self serve gas stations and Chinese restaurants. As a matter of fact, many Chinese restaurants on Clement St. Were closed.

Nobody wanted to cook after Christmas Eve services so we drove along Clement St. Until we found some lights on.  We sat down overdressed and flagged down are waiter for some menus.

When they are busy here, you have to flag them down for everything from menus, to more hot tea, to your bill.  It is not rude.  They just staff very thinly.  In fact I think it is a family run business.

We ordered the Jia Jia Mien ( noodles with meat sauce, beef chow fun, 2 orders of pot stickers (6 to an order) and an order of xiao long bao (6 to an order).  We ate it all up

I give the food a 4 but the ambiance and service a 3. Parking can normally be a pain on Clement St., but not on Christmas Eve.
author: Erik H.

description: Very consistent... great pot stickers, chow leen go, dry fried string beans, green onion pancakes, and steam shrimp dumplings.
author: Jennifer T.

description: The fried tofu was okay and the turnip cake was normal. The Taiwanese noodles were undercooked with two pieces of shrimp and half an egg. Definitely much better places in the area.
author: Sean H.

description: I like this place. Variety food choices and the Chinese fried dough is really good. I definitely recommend this place to people who interesting to try new things.
author: Unyo N.

description:
When my friends say that Costco has the best potstickers I laugh and think to myself, "You're all morons."

Now this place has the best potstickers, fried bread, and Taiwanese noodles.

I'm not a betting man, well maybe I am, but if I were to bet on one of the best homemade potstickers in the Bay Area, it would be this place.

Their portions for their noodles are enough for two people, and it's one of my favorite Asian comfort foods. 

They also have the traditional soy bean milk (hot) and fried bread, which reminds me of my trips to both Taiwan and Hong Kong.

So if anyone tells you that Costco potstickers are the best, do what I do and laugh in their face, then send them here!
author: Jack R.

description:
I've been coming here for over 25+ years. Still original family owners. George was taken over now. Excellent Taiwan style Chinese food. Large portions of Beef Stew noodles. All of the bowl of noodles are large portion. 牛肉面, 炸酱面, 担担面。

They also make Northern style dough pastries. Their Chinese donut 油条 is the best in San Francisco Bay Area. 烧饼油条 豆浆。手工猪肉水饺，独一无二。
author: Will L.

description:
The dumplings are disappointing.
The noodles are ok. The fried onion pancake is awful.
I feel sorry for the mom and pop so I will come back for just the few items.
Not authentic!!!
author: Alison W.

description:
A great neighborhood "stick to the basics" Chinese restaurant. Taiwan restaurant has very tasty pot stickers, chow fun, and string beans. Friendly servers, and slightly tight fit to walk to the restroom. Location provides a lot of post dinner shopping and exploring; from a nearby aquarium pet store to green apple books, you'll be able to work off those pot stickers. Just note, lately Taiwan hasn't been very busy, but don't let that discourage you from stopping in. 

Bottom line: Solid Chinese food. Order pot stickers.
author: Jaime W.

description:
2 Words- Amazing food!!!
 I Recommend  the Dim Sum!!
Taiwan country favorite spareribs, salt and pepper pork chops, Szechuan hot sauce noodles, dry braised green beans, and onion pan cakes are my top 5 dishes. 

Fresh Chinese donuts daily, and they are delicious with their fresh sweet soy milk! 

Whenever I'm in the area I have to come here because the servers are the best. Especially George, he always makes me laugh. The things we talk about together is just Hilarious.  

Sometimes when Im not feeling well won ton soup is the way to go. I honestly recommend this place because service is amazing, food is amazing, perfect atmosphere, and great prices.
author: Mr. D.

description:
It was a quiet weekend since my girlfriend was out of town so my buddy and I met up for dinner in the Richmond.  I chose Taiwan Restaurant since it had been some 10 years since I last visited with my dad.  I was looking forward to some authentic and nostalgic stuff.

While not necessarily a dish from my past, I went with their salt and pepper pork chops.  My buddy and I also shared some of their boiled dumplings and won ton soup.  The food quality was good especially for the price, and the portion sizes were huge.  I really wanted to get some of my old favorites as well, but my buddy can be a bit pick at times.  I would definitely get the pork and the dumplings again, but I thought the wonton soup was a little bland.

Service was friendly but the food was brought out at different times when we really wanted it all at once.  The restaurant goers have changed over the years and this place has joined the ranks of the hipster favorites.  However, prices have stayed the same so that's always a good sign.  I would come back for their dim sum and small plates for brunch.

Food: 7/10

Service: 7/10

Price: $

Atmosphere: 7/10
author: Joe M.

description: Taiwan has been my go-to Chinese restaurant for over 10 years. Service is quick and the food is fresh and tasty. Favorites include the Shanghai noodles, the pork and leek buns, twice cooked pork and any of the dumplings. Great place. Reasonable too!
author: Pierre K.

description:
Been coming here for 30 years!
Still authentic and has great Taiwanese dishes, though I do wish they would expand and add more dishes.
Taiwanese country favorite sparerib and chicken... yummy.
Potstickers the BEST in SF.  Nice and juicy inside, flavorful, and most importantly NOT deep fried, must be tender on top and golden brown crispy on the bottom (yin and yang).
author: David H.

description:
I haven't tried anything else on their menu except for their pork chops so this is based only on that one item.

Really tasty pieces w/ a slightly crunchy crust. It comes w/ pickled veggies. Order extra cuz it really complements the meat.
author: Julie L.

description: From my first experience in this modest looking spot I was hooked! A buddy took me here and insisted on what he calls "pork candy" which was the pork spare ribs (dry salty rub, delicious!) They are f#$king amazing. I could have just these over steamed rice every day for the rest of my life and be happy. Then came the sizzling rice soup. so many amazing flavors! The pot stickers are also fantastic. My go to spot for any special day, friendly staff that always makes us feel welcome
author: Jack B.

description: Food five stars, deco one star, service one stars. We ordered bow and it was homemade and you can tell it's quite different from made by machines. Rice cake was home made too and delicious. Soy milk was home made so you can taste the slight burn smell. The tofu noodle soup was ok - was hoping the noodle has a bit more texture. Not enough servers. Deco was very dated and menu was dirty. We ordered three dishes and was only $16
author: Anya C.

description:
This place is like a landmark for one of the pioneering Taiwanese Restaurant in the city.  It has been here since I was a kid.  LOL :p  I have always enjoyed Taiwanese breakfast.  It is so different from Chinese.  The Taiwanese pays close  attention to sauces and they like to eat "Tapas style."  It's just a whole different culture put together.  With that said, I'll keep this review short and "sassy!" I only come here for their Taiwanese breakfast, and I usually order their hot soy sweet milk, and their super fresh sweet deep fried Taiwanese donut.  They go hand in hand and a must while you are here.  You can even watch the chefs at front kneading the dough from start to finish.  It's an amazing feat! 

Cheers! ~ :p
author: Edwin R.

description:
One of my favorite Taiwanese restaurants! I love their potstickers, perfection! Their beef stir fried rice noodle is right amount of flavor. The fried rice is perfect! I love most dishes from this place. I totally recommend.

But one plate I DO NOT recommend is the yam stuffed with mushroom and beef. It looked like you made your own glue paste. The taste wasn't fantastic either because the bamboo totally empowers it.
author: Annie H.

description:
Very so-so. Why is it so hard to find good Taiwanese breakfast in the city??

Our party of 4 was seated without a wait around noon on a Saturday. We ordered tonssss of carbs (beauty of tw breakfast!) -- Chinese donut, salty soy milk, turnip cake, red oil wontons, salt and pepper squid, oyster pancake, and minced pork rice. Everything was just meh and lacking in a little flavor. I enjoyed the rice the most, but that's preeetttyyy hard to do wrong. My least favorite was the squid - it had too much batter and no flavor. Oh well, the search continues.
author: Kathy L.

description:
My dad use to go here in his USF days. As a Hong Kong transplant, he searched high and low for semi authentic places. This was one of them. 

Mostly Chinese people were at the restaurant, which usually points to some authenticity. Ambiance isn't the best, but we didn't expect much. Old restaurant, but everything seemed decently clean. 

We ordered WAY too much food, as usual. Xiao Long Bao, potstickers, sesame noodles, and Sichuan beef. 

Xiao Long Bao were big, hand made, and hot. I really enjoyed them. The potstickers were crispy and juicy. They were also pretty big. 

I was so focused on the dumplings, I didn't even bother to try the beef. It seemed overloaded with bell peppers though. When ¾ is bell peppers and the rest is meat, I feel a little cheated. 

The sesame noodles were great! Very rich and filling, but the sauce was killer. We got meat on the noodles which really helped cut through the think sesame sauce. 

The service was really good. Everyone seemed kind. Dumplings took longer than usual since they were super fresh. Our waitress was nice, and she even talked to me in Chinese. I kept up... Sort of. She was, however, a little shocked at how much we ordered. 

Defiantly a place to try and I will try and head back before my San Francisco summer is over. I really just want more potstickers!
author: Chandler H.

description:
Came across this place for the first time and man, I wish it was closer to my regular haunts!  The Sizzling Beef hot plate was served with crisp bell peppers and onions, and was pure perfection in a kind gravy for $10 and a lot of it.  The dumplings are very much Taiwanese style and both huge and packed.  Plenty of vegetarian and seafood options.  I would gladly come here again.

The final touch of authenticity:  The bathrooms that are simultaneously filthy and antiseptic... dirty looking with a mop pail and a drain on the floor, but smelling completely of disinfectant.  That's how you know you're at the real thing.
author: G M.

description:
Honestly, its probably one of the worst restaurants I have been to in the Bay Area.  I ordered 銀絲卷and排骨pork rice, the deep fried roll was mediocre, but the pork rice was simply disgusting.  I don't understand all these 4 star reviews or even 5 stars.  In any review I give, I always try to be as subjective as possible, but the food here is really sub-par.  Taste of Formosa is a better choice in the area, however, it can be a bit salty in their dishes.  

I am just puzzled at all these 4 and 5 stars given by the yelp users.  Questions for these people.

1. Have you tasted authentic Taiwanese cuisine in California?
2. Have you been back to Taiwan in the last 20 years?

If the answer is no, then I urge you to either take a drive to Cupertino or try Taste of Formosa nearby.
author: Cheng L.

description:
Owners or chef has changed. Their Chinese donuts which used to be worth a trip over from mission is thick and too doughy now. Hot and sour soup was salty and not sour or spicy. The vegetarian dumplings had very thick floury skin and we ended up having to scrap the veggies out. The soy milk was sandy and not hot. 

I've been to Taiwan and this restaurant before and it's very disappointing. Never again...
author: Jannies L.

description:
This is a great friendly restuarant. Been coming here for over 20 years. Is alway a positive here. Foods are good, better than any other Taiwanese restaurant in the bay. Very good price
too. Friendly services.
author: Judy T.

description: Don't order dumplings.  Not fresh.  Green onions pancake was deep fried, not traditional.  The fried rice had no wok fired flavor.  The soup was good and sweet and sour shrimp was really good,  not too tangy like other restaurants.  I was disappointed with service, very slow and up attentive.
author: casey j.

description:
it finally happened.  took my Taiwan wife in.  this isnt our first time, and we dont remember our last visit. 

what finally happened?  we walked out.  yup..took one bite of each dish, got the check and left.  food was brutally salty.  and we got this dish we have eaten often.  it is a dish that is seasoned beef wrapped with a roti like onion pancake-ish thing.  (that is how i actually describe the dish to my wife so she can order it)..what we got was comical.  i kid you not, it was wrapped with a tortilla.  not a Chinese wrapper..a Mexican tortilla.  and the thing was a salt-lick.    food was cheap..we spent $20 and still left a tip..but we just got up and left.  no sense wasting a togo container..  one dish had that salted pickled veggies.  they didnt rinse the veggie before cooking with it.  wow..it left your mouth tingly it was so salty.

and that place has gotten filthy.  no thanks.
author: Cliff L.

description:
We stopped in for some Taiwanese food because we saw the layout of the Chinese doughnuts (crullers) displayed in the window along with other fried bready things. Once we sat down and perused the menu, we were really disappointed because there really wasn't anything Taiwanese on the menu. There were a lot of regular dishes and a handful of Taiwanese street food like fried oysters with egg, but that's it.

We settled on some salty soy and salty tofu, but was told they didn't have the latter. So salty soy milk it was plus some Chinese doughnuts.

The doughnuts were terrible! They weren't crispy on the outside and airy on the inside. The texture was like bread, dense and chewy. The soy milk had no flavor whatsoever. They didn't season it nor did they put much condiments in there except for some dried shrimp, scallions and preserved vegetables. Where was the pork sung? How about soy sauce, vinegar and other things to flavor it?

We didn't order anything after that. We moved somewhere else for food. I don't recommend it for Taiwanese breakfast!!!
author: Anita L.

description:
I gotta say, you have to know what's good here in order to like this restaurant. 
The noodle soups are pretty much terrible and not worth it. Same for their dumplings.
I went here today with my mother and uncle. The restaurant feels like a hole in the wall, this place hasn't been updated in decades. flies were everywhere. it is a bit dumpy and dirty. That would be fine, as long as the food is good, that's the most important thing. We ordered 3 dishes, the fried pork rice plate, japanese seafood noodle and this beef noodle soup dish. Of the three, the rice plate was the best. it had a sweet and spicy sauce with a real kick to it, and a very large portion. I think the rice plates are the better items to get here. Those are the safe bet, and u'll get a very large portion. they didn't skimp.

What was terrible were the noodle soups. Japanese seafood noodle was just flavorless, bland and average. For a pricey dish at $9, it should've been better. it was a risky choice picking this.  I thought it was a stir fry dish by the title, like a stir fried udon dish with seafood. so i was surprised it was noodle soup in a big bowl. it was a clear broth with udon noodles, shrimp, shellfish, green beans and carrots. it had absolutely no flavor to it. My uncle's beef noodle soup was just ok too. The noodles were oddly gummy textured.  Portion wise, both are good on that front. 

Overall, there are many other better choices on Clement and nearby here. If you do come here, order the safe items.
author: Jim D.

description: Avoid this place if you have a food allergy or restricted diet. Have celiac, have to eat gluten free, ordered an egg flower soup, confirmed with the waiter that it didn't have flour or soy sauce, etc. Ate it, was a bland rendition of the dish, ended up sick all night because it had something in it I couldn't eat. Will not ever eat here again.
author: Erik H.

description:
If there is one thing that this cat loves, its restaurants that I can always count on to bring great food at a great price when I need something quick and easy. and for me, Taiwan restaurant is exactly that!

I have been dining at Taiwan restaurant frequently for years, and I always bring friends and family here as well. Why you ask? Simply put, I can always leave this restaurant feeling very full, satisfied, and not broke. 

here at Taiwan, they definitely have your standard sort of Chinese restaurant menu items, but a look further Into their menu shows many things that are not so common and unique. The menu is HUGE so take your time looking through. if you find yourself wondering about a dish, asking the server always brings a very detailed description on what the dish is and how it is prepared. very informative. 

I will say, Taiwan restaurant isn't the cleanest and nicest looking place in the world, but don't let that be a turn off as I can honestly say that the food served here is honestly wonderful, and doesn't feel greasy and salty like many other Chinese places. 

been coming here for a long time, and will definitely continue  to do so! 

*chirp!*
author: Jei C.

description:
This place seems hit or miss, as our friend has been going here for years, yet when my family went, it was definitely more of a miss (though they did say their main chef was actually in Taiwan, so some of the dishes we couldn't even order with him being gone)

We got several staple Taiwanese dishes, beef noodle soup, stir fry rice cake, fried tofu, xiao long bao, salt and pepper pork chop, stomach, eggplant, and sweet and sour fish. Sadly, my family was not pleased with majority of the dishes, the beef was tough, the rice cakes were not cooked well, the stomach was way too tough, etc.

The upside is the staff were relatively attentive, there was plenty of seating on a weekend, and the prices were reasonable.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
This place was just okay for me? I went with another Chinese-American friend, and admittedly, neither of us can really articulate the difference between (various) Chinese and Taiwanese food. What we got (vegetarian mu shi; eggplant; and green onion pancakes) didn't help.

I will say, though, that the service was generally great! Sure, we didn't get any menus handed to us when we sat down, but the woman taking our order was super attentive and clarified any questions we had about whether or not there was hidden meat in the food (note: this was all in mandarin). Gotta love that!

So, overall, no complaints, but also nothing to write home about. :T
author: Shendi X.

description: My mom was on the hunt for Chinese doughnuts (油條) this morning. She knew that Taiwan Restaurant was likely still closed since it was so early in the morning, but decided to walk by anyway. One of the workers, an older man (perhaps the owner...?), was at the window making and frying the doughnuts. Although Taiwan Restaurant was indeed closed, my mom waved to him and asked if she could buy two, and he agreed! So nice and great customer service even though they weren't open yet! Only 三塊 or 2 for $1.50.My mom left a happy customer. It's quite satisfying getting something fresh off the presses, or in this case, fresh off the oil. :)
author: Emily L.

description:
Hot fresh soy milk - a giant bowl of the stuff sweetened with a little sugar - is this not the most perfect breakfast? It's filling and nutritious and I guess if you were being sensible you'd stop there... but of course I didn't and ordered dry fried beans and XLB dumplings too.

The filling in the dumplings had excellent flavour, but the skin was a little thick and stogy. The beans were amazing...I love that it's listed as "vegetarian" on the menu but is really just a guise for eating sweet and salty mounds of ground up fried pork.  YUM!

Over order because you can take home everything you don't get through (such a novelty for this Australian).
author: Tresna L.

description:
Taiwan Restaurant is a valiant effort but ultimately suffers from the problem I have found in most of SF's other non-Cantonese Chinese restaurants: Ambitious attempts at replicating the classic dishes of the region are compromised by staff who don't actually understand how to make these dishes and who are catering to Western palates. The result is a confusing hodgepodge of offerings that don't really bear resemblance to one region or another.

Beef noodle soup: Nice noodles but bland broth. Slightly overcooked beef

Shredded pork and mustard greens noodle soup: Very good. The mustard greens were fresh and abundant, cooked to crunchy perfection. However, the broth was lacking in pork flavor

Xiao long baos: A little too watery, though the skins were pretty good

Vegetarian dumplings: Adequate, but not really like the Taiwanese vegetarian dumplings I'm used to

Sticky rice: Very good. Perfect combination of soy flavors + soft, sticky rice + flavorful meat

Oyster pancake: This would never pass muster at a Taiwanese night market. Too much egg, not enough oysters. Also, overcooked

The people are really nice and the area is quite spacious (good for large parties). However, I wouldn't go out of my way to come here if you're craving Taiwanese comfort food. Unfortunately, I haven't really come across a decent alternative in SF.
author: Josephine L.

description:
BEST CHINESE FOOD IN San Francisco!

Here is why: I have been coming here since I was 5 years old and that was a long time ago! The flavors are consistent as to when I first remember which is a rarity, trust me.

Pot Stickers - Order these and you will thank me. I have had these dumplings from every restaurant in SF and these BY FAR are the best. (Just make sure you make a nice Soy Sauce, White Vinegar, Hot Sauce) to accompany these. 

War Won Ton Soup....One word, Amazing. (I get it with noodles, makes a fine meal)

Chinese Spaghetti with meat sauce. Simple and Delicious.

General Tsao's Chicken: Order it old school way, not friend but saute'd - another favorite. Get an extra order and next day, make a 3 egg omelet with milk and add this dish to it. Again, trust me on this one, delicious!

Spicy String Beans - 5 Stars
Spicy Chicken Wings - 5 Stars

Can't say enough good things....just go here and enjoy!
author: Robert N.

description:
The food was fair.
I've ordered a Chinese sweet donut, but it was undercooked.
The environment was not okay. Water was dripping through the ceiling (second table near the entrance)
I don't think I will come again.
author: Vickie Y.

description:
I've gone to this restaurant over the past couple decades whenever I'm in the neighborhood. My father likes this place because the food isn't greasy or overly salty. I've always had polite service here but then I've been told I'm not very demanding. Still, I can discern the difference between being neglected and treated rudely from decent service provided by a family-run business (not polished but still taken care of well).

As with most restaurants, there are a few reliable dishes on the menu and I stick with those when I want a guaranteed good meal. My favorites here are the dry braised green beans with meat, mustard greens shredded pork noodle soup (omg! such comfort food), Taiwan country favorite spareribs, red snapper filet and the very simple/plain chicken chow mein (they use the thick Shanghai style noodles for this dish).

I love the down-homeness of this place. Not fancy or new, but still comfy seating with my one of my favorite soup noodle dishes in town.
author: Everso T.

description:
I was born and grew in Taiwan for 30 years before moved to the States, so I can tell if it is authentic Taiwanese foods. We went to this restaurant while we were in SFO, and wanted to tried it out. The menu looks very Taiwanese, with some unique Taiwanese items. We ordered some and found out that the tastes were more like Chinese, nit Taiwanese.

However, the tastes were still quite good, if you were not looking for true Taiwanese foods. The interior was not great, but clean enough to dine in. The service were OK too, not too quick but friendly. Best of all, its price was very affordable comparing its big portion. Will come again next time when we visit again.
author: Eric H.

description: They are well-known for their Chinese donuts here, which are made fresh daily - goes perfectly with porridge! Came here with my mom and sister and had their soymilk, which was good - not to sweet or bland. We had their flat rice cake noodles which lacked flavor and their dumplings were not tasty. Their dumpling skins were too thick and hard, and lacked soup inside the dumplings. Probably won't plan to come eat here unless I want the donuts or soymilk to go.
author: Amanda C.

description:
We never deviate when we eat here.  

Pork chop with soup noodles. 
Braised beef ligaments in soup noodles.
Pan fried potstickers.

If we do family style we always order the dry fried green beans and the eggplant in garlic sauce.
author: Shirley N.

description: Authentic Chinese restaurant. Really like this place. Food is always good. Never had a problem. The owners are very friendly; their English might not be very good but they manage. Highly recommend the fried pork chops and the onion pancakes.
author: Celia Y.

description:
This place is NOT anywhere close to an authentic Taiwanese restaurant so if you are looking for decent taiwanese food, please do not come here because you will be very disappointed. This is the worse Taiwanese food I have ever eaten in the bay area!

Oyster Vermicelli - The noodles were too thick, the sauce was off, the flavoring was wrong and everything about the dish was nowhere close to what it should be except that there was oysters and noodles in the dish.

White Turnip Cake - the only decent dish we ordered although you can make better turnip cake buying it frozen at an asian supermarket and cooking it yourself.

Soy Milk - very bland, did not taste good.

Oyster Pancake - the worst mix of batter, eggs, spinach and oysters. It tasted more like a thin layer of egg and spinach with a few small oysters thrown in there and batter mix. They didn't even use the right sauce on top.

Changhua Meatball - too much shell, not enough ingredients - it did not taste right.

Sticky Rice Lotus Leaf Wrap - worse than any dim sum place I have been to, the rice was too hard and there were few ingredients inside. 

NONE of the items we ordered tasted good and they put oyster sauce on top of everything which isn't even the right sauce that goes with any of these food items. It was a poor attempt cooked by someone who clearly does not know what Taiwanese food even taste like. I was quite disappointed. This restaurant should not be called Taiwan Restaurant because it is nowhere close to it.
author: Peggy H.

description: I've been going here for more than 20 years.  The Spicy Shrimp is very good.  The owners work here and the food is very good and the prices are reasonable.  Their lunch special is a very good deal and whenever I'm in the area I try and go followed by some beers next door at the Bitter End.
author: Harrison P.

description:
It's really 3.5 stars. Xiao long bao was okay, but their you tiao was delicious and fluffy. The service wasn't the best because they're understaffed, but the people there are really nice. 

Really liked their stirfried rice cake and their Tainan noodles. :) I would come here again for some you tiao again!
author: Belyn L.

description:
Please read before coming here!!!
Wanting to bring my Taiwanese grandparents here for a final lunch before they were off to the airport I though Taiwanese would be appropriate. 

How greatly disappointed I was, if 0 stars was possible I would give it. My problem with this restaurant is the fact that they sell themselves as a Taiwanese restaurant but it's about 0% authentic in the food.

First of all you know you were in trouble when there wasn't a single Taiwanese staff. I would have left if it wasn't for the did fully of my grandpas wheelchair. 

Now about the food: 
the minced pork rice: terrible, the rice had clumps and tinge meat was literally just ground beef. Authentic minced pork has fat to make the dish more flavor for and rice shouldn't have inconsistent lumps in them. (I think the rice was frozen)

The dandan mian: the meat looked raw (pink) and it was drenched in peanut butter sauce. Sorry I didn't order peanut butter noodles! 

The 彰化肉丸 was most likely frozen and just heated up. The skin didn't have any of the chewy texture that makes this item delicious.

The oyster pancake: first off the sauce was all wrong, oyster pancake doesn't mean oyster sauce on top..... 

The sticky rice, the rice wasn't sticky and the pork on top seemed old it has the frozen meat taste. 

牛肉大餅 sorry but I didn't ask for a flour tortilla with red looking beef and drenched in sauce. Nough said. 

Please save yourself money and don't come here and make the whole family sad! 

Positive: it's cheap
author: Catherina W.

description:
Taiwan restaurant has been around for decades. decor is beige walls. minature red lanterns and like facsimiles hang from the ceiling.

eats:
-xiao loong bao: 6/3.95
golf ball like with lots of meat inside but no juice. no red vinegar provided,  just ginger
-lamb noode soup(6.95)
broth had lamb, green onion, and msg flavorings
tender lamb meat on bones
noodles commerical type, tab mushy
a few pieces of spinach also present

leftovers:
-cheap eats, dumplings @4.95,  potstickers @3.95
-quality of food just so so, portions above average.
-english spoken here as well as mandarin.
-service adequate.
author: Victor G.

description:
Taiwan Restaurant may not look like much, but this place has THE BEST dan dan mien, fit to appease the gastronomy gods.

What is are these foreign sounding items of deliciousness, you inquire?

Dan Dan Mien are noodles topped with a generous heaping of spicy or peanut sauce. The noodles are traditionally freshly pulled thick noodles made in house. The name of the noodles come from the "dan" merchants use to peddle the noodles in China. Also, "dan" means "bouncy" or "springy" in Chinese, which perfectly describes the process of how the dan dan mien is made, as well as the texture of the noodles when eaten. But, enough about the history of dan dan mien.

On my most recent visit, we ordered the Xiao Lin Dumplings and Hot and Sour Soup to start off. Xiao Lin Dumplings are fickle creatures. The chef made them amazingly juicy and tender with the right amount of broth in each morsel. Dipped in red vinegar, it makes you crave for another. The hot and sour soup was standard, nothing special about it. I will give credit because it's not overly sour, which is always a good thing.

Our main course is the dan dan mien. I ordered a garlic peanut sauce one because the classic has always been my favorite since I was a child. My friends ordered the spicy flavored one. We ended up eating the noodles family style, split into smaller bowls. Why? Because the portions of these dan dan mien are HUGE. One bowl can serve 2-3 people. But it's not just quantity, it's also quality also.

The garlic peanut version had a milder taste, the tones of peanut and garlic meld together with the creamy noodles, it's very rich and filling. The spicy variety is also very buttery, but has a spicy kick to it. It's not Sirarcha-worshiper spicy, just enough to go with the rich creamy texture of dan dan mien.

Service here is slow because there's only two waiters, the owner and a hired employee. Atmosphere is very casual and the decor is drab, but that's because they spend their resources on making good food. They tend to the taste buds, not the eyes.

Bottom line: Delicious dan dan mien. Try it~
author: Anna F.

description:
I use to come here as a kid and I decided I would revisit this place because we were hungry and did not want to wait in a line. This place has the usual food that you can expect from dumpling kitchens everywhere but they have very cheap prices. 

I ended up getting a shanghai rice cake, soy milk and xiao long bao and it was all for under $20! The rice cakes were okay I wish it had a little bit more flavor but it was a big plate. Can't go wrong with the soy milk and it was a big bowl of it for about $3. The xiao long bao was not all that great and had no soup in it but I can't complain cause the price was so cheap. 

I did see another table eating different types of dumplings and pot stickers that looked quite appealing and delicious so I think go for that over the xiao long baos. Overall the service was friendly and the food was cheap.
author: Angela S.

description:
Coming from an American and Taiwanese perspective, 
This is literally terrible. 

At one point a tortilla was served to us. A Mexican tortilla.

The service was also very bad. When we questioned the color of the meat on whether or not it was cooked, the waiter became very gruff and rude. He insisted that it was cooked without even a glance at the meat in question and walked off.

Every item that was carbohydrate based was extremely doughy and hard to swallow.
 
I applaud their efforts at an eclectic assortment of food but they really couldn't live up to any of the dishes. What good does making hundreds of half assed food come to? Sad stomachs, broken hearts and an honest yelp review.
 
Don't come here. The highlight was the tea.
author: Isabella W.

description: Order the Fried Chicken, it was very dry, not fresh re heated old fried chicken. I hope it was not chicken from others left over plates that they served me. Sorry it was gross. KFC is even better. Won't be coming back.
author: Unus U.

description:
Wuh? So I've been living in the Inner Richmond for over 10 years now and yesterday was my first time in here!

Goddamn, their food is cheap. Why have I not stepped in here earlier.......
-FREAKIN CHEAP!
-Good portions for the price!
-Decent food!
-Pretty clean!

I will def come here again since I only had the potstickers, dumpings, a noodle, and an eggplant dish.
author: Emily C.

description:
Me and my family visited this location earlier today. We ordered Hot & Sour soup, 2 orders of potstickers, general chicken, and spring rolls.

The Hot & Sour soup was excellent! It came out fast and was delicious.

The potstickers are outstanding. Every single time we visit SF we get these potstickers. They're so good! It came out last though.

The general chicken was the best I've ever had. Perfect amount of flavor.

And last but not least, the spring rolls were out of this world! The best we've ever had! 

Service is amazing!
author: Isabella K.

description:
I think we have finally found our go to Chinese restaurant too bad it's clear across the city, but so totally worth it. we've been going so frequently that the owner (the older Chinese man) and a good deal of the waitresses know my brother my face.

Their rice plates are such a great value for under $6 and include soup and fruit at the end. My brother likes to order the general tso's rice plate. And my favorite would be the dry fried green beans with your choice of meat (beef, chicken, or shrimp) I normally get the shrimp. The general tso's has a bit of a vinegar like tang to it.

Our other family favorites are the potstickers, the taiwan special spareribs, the green beans, the braised flounder, and the braised fish filets.

We've been adventurous lately and have been trying some other items in the hopes that we could include them in our repertoire. Do NOT order the taiwan special chicken. We thought they would be like the spareribs... soooo NOT the same. Totally different preparation. The spareribs are prepared like the San Tung Chicken wings with basil a top. The chicken was prepared in a clay pot and resembled and tasted more like chicken adobo. The hot garlic chicken was another fail, thinking those would be good. They were chicken wings prepared much like the General Tso's chicken, but less saucy and not even the slightest bit hot or even garlicky. Both big disappointments.
author: Dina V.

description: Good food at a good price!  Fast service !  Simple and enjoyable!
author: Thomas G.

description:
Their lunch specials are really good and the service is decent and the food is great and the bathroom is clean! What more can you ask for?

I like the rice plates and lunch specials and the dumplings are good too. It's not too crowded during lunch hours but I always stop by after 3pm and it's quiet and peaceful. 

Great place to eat alone too.
author: Gangsta G.

description: Their beef noodle soup was very good. I got the half-and-half (beef/tendon) - but the tendon was so tender I'm going 100% tendon next time.
author: Lulu B.

description:
Their Wonton Soup is a magical remedy worth driving across town from The Mission (or a short hop from Kaiser). Cures all ills, banishes evil, add a hot sake and there's nothing better when you're feeling sick.

Prawn w/ green beans, Shanghai dumplings, & thick noodles are great too.
author: Steven B.

description: Haven't been back in years and some plates remain the same while others completely lost their flavor. The tofu plate should had been spicy but the only heat was the kind that burns the hand. The noodles plate was dependent on the sauce for flavor. The intestine plate was the best, but not made the way listed.
author: M C.

description:
Quick, inexpensive and ample lunch.  Lunch specials come with soup and  white or brown rice.  The brown rice costs a bit extra. 

I got the asparagus prawns which had at least an entire bunch of asparagus and lots of shrimp in a tasty black bean sauce.

The lunch special servings are at least two - three meals worth.  No one offered to wrap up the leftovers but since I had another half day of training and a long commute home, I probably wouldn't have taken them up on the offer anyway.
author: Emily J.

description:
The food is okay. 

I got the beef soup noodles and the bf got the asparagus prawns + rice. Meh. Edible, but not great. 

The portions are HUGE! I think I ate about 1/8 of my noodles and became full. This is the place if you want the bang for your buck. 

I'm hoping there's better Chinese food in the area. I wonder the location in SF also owns the one in Berkeley. The Taiwan Restaurant in Berkeley is significantly better.
author: Debbie T.

description:
Wonderful for breakfasts especially the freshly fried you tiao 油條, pot stickers, and warm soy milk. For those who haven't had fresh soy milk, I do recommend savory if you are more adventurous. 

They also have really nice rice cakes/noodles 年糕  in both soup and stir fried form which are not so common to find. The service is prompt and friendly. I will definitely go again.
author: Jimi G.

description:
This place was 'meh'. We had red beef noodles and fried pork chop. It didn't come with an egg.  Bleh. 

The interior needs updating.  

The search for good Taiwanese food in SF area begins again...
author: Jboogie L.

description:
I was craving taiwanese beef noodle soup so thought I try this place. 

I ordered:
"original" beef noodle soup - it was decent.   Broth was pretty good, fair amount of beef chunks tho somewhat bland. I have had better back east (nj).
Beef crepe - tender, tasty. Would be better  if they use softer doughier pancake, added scrambled eggs and topped with some oyster sauce.

I would come back to try their Taiwanese breakfast menu.
author: Cheung L.

description: My fave soul food comfort food place. Almost homey cooking but with enough polish to justify eating out. A neighborhood stalwart. The noodle soups are good go tos, with thick noodles and tasty meats, as is the fried string beans. Parking is hairy.
author: E. W.

description:
In my constant quest for great Chinese food in the bay area, my friend and I visited Taiwan restaurant for their Chinese breakfast and it was heartily disappointing.

The bad: The chinese donut tasted oddly savory, their fried daikon cake was just deep fried and greasy, the oyster pancake was sludgey and I think the worst part was the pork buns. The meat was overly spiced and weirdly grey, and after a couple of bites we stopped eating them.

The good: There were several Asian families here (always a good sign) and most of them ordered entrees like stir fried noodles or rice, which I'm guessing are the strengths here.

Ambiance: Chinese family style restaurant.

Overall: Not somewhere I would return. A poor effort at re-creating good Chinese/Taiwanese food, but maybe we just didn't order the right thing.
author: Jackie T.

description:
Sure, they do have real Taiwanese dishes like three cup chicken (they called it Taiwan country famous chicken), street food, and freshly made northern breakfast items like soy milk, baked cake, twisted dough, etc. However --- all of them were bland and like the worst versions one can make that is still edible and resembles the dish it's supposed to be. 

The twisted dough and fresh soy milk were the only two items I thought was ok. The red bean bun had a very doughy texture. The spicy wontons had very thick skin (not desired) and the sauce wasn't flavorful enough. The sticky rice cake contained only two things: sticky rice and bits of meat and it was close to falling apart -- a good version of it would have the sticky rice very sticky forming a pretty pudding shape, filled with sumptuous meat, mushrooms, dried shrimp, topped with a hearty sauce.

In other words, going to this place when you crave Taiwanese food is like, going to Pizza Hut when you crave pizza and going to McDonalds when you crave burgers.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: Food here is totally not authentic Taiwanese food.  I can only say the food is trying to mimic Taiwanese, but the taste is far from the authentic, delicious Taiwanese food.  There are many other Taiwanese restaurant way better than this.  Not recommend.
author: Kyle C.

description: It's a Neighborhood gem.  I've been coming here for more than 15 years.  Good things to get is  Taiwan country spareribs, pickled cabbage and pork noodle soup, pot stickers, all their dumplings are also good.  Everything's at a reasonable price.  Come and try it out.
author: hannah t.

description:
Food: 
- Vegetable and pork dumplings are very, very good. Generous portions. 
- Pork buns were huge and extremely tasty!
- Schezuan noodles were very tasty, but a bit heavy on peanuts and not as spicy as I'd though they would be. Would still order again.
- Wine for $2.25 a glass! 

Ambiance was fairly plain. Walls are an odd pink/peach combo. Not a fine-end decor. 

Service was a bit slow, and they didn't check back after dropping off the food. Took a while to get a bill, so don't come here for service, come here for the food.
author: Matt S.

description: I've eaten here a few times for lunch. Standard Taiwanese cuisine. It's good for what it is. I would be giving 3 stars but my last visit ruined it for me. I was eating my shanghai noodles when I discovered a fortune cookie wrapper embedded in the noodles. I don't even want to know how that got in there. Informed the waitress and they made a new order. I like my fortune cookies after my meal, not in it. Definitely not kosher.
author: Liv A.

description:
Review is for pork chop rice only. It might be harsh to judge a restaurant solely based on its pork chop rice, but two dishes are Taiwanese staples: 1) pork chop rice and 2) beef noodle soup. Reasonable to expect that a restaurant named "Taiwan Restaurant" would at least have decent versions of these dishes. I should have been wary and walked out when the servers started using Cantonese.

The pork chop rice here at Taiwan Restaurant falls flat. The pork is overly seasoned and too sugary. In addition, a proper pork chop rice needs its small accoutrements (shredded sour vegetable, ground pork sauce, roasted egg, garlic-steamed bok choy or cabbage), the only one present here was the sour vegetable. Say nothing of the poor decor, grungy dark restaurant, Taiwan Restaurant is not worth coming to if you're looking for authentic Taiwanese cuisine.
author: Michael C.

description:
Skinny:

Great food
Good prices

we sat at a table with a couple and their son and we had a blast - great conversation and good service - or should i say typical of restaurants like this - people are nice but you have to speak up.
author: Chris G.

description: Don't sleep on this spot if you're looking for consistently great Taiwanese style fair. Best Hot & Sour soup I've had in SF and the General Tso's Chicken is legit...
author: Jack F.

description: Came with a foreigner (!) and introduced him to some classic dishes.. the "fish flavor" eggplant, mapo tofu, and turnip cake. Everything was pretty good, though not at all spicy. They must have assumed my friend didn't eat spicy.. BUT I LOVE SPICY GIVE IT TO ME YOU JERKS. You know what happens when you assume? Not only do you make an ass out of u and me but I get really sad. The dishes were huge but we actually finished everything.. that's how good it was. The server was super sweet. Also they have brown rice, bonus! AND they take credit. OK fine you get 4 stars (on chinese resto standards).
author: Vivian H.

description:
FINALLY! A good Taiwanese restaurant to get some good ol' Taiwanese breakfast! I can't believe it took me to long to finally come here and get my fix.

Order:
1. Chinese donut made fresh and crispy
2. Sweetened soy milk --it's not actually sweet because you have to put sugar in it. THEN you dip your chinese donut in there! TOTAL WIN
3. Sizzling rice soup - SO good and totally hits the spot
4. San Ba Ji (3-piece chicken) --a Taiwanese staple. Takes 20 minutes to cook though so be patient

There was so much more on the menu I didn't get to but if you are looking for a Taiwanese breakfast fix, this place totally does the trick. Ever since I moved up here, I've been craving a spot like this so this just made my entire weekend.

Don't come here expecting some fancy nice decor. The questionable cleanliness of the whole place is what makes it so authentic and endearing.
author: Diana Y.

description: san francisco taiwanese breakfast search...outer richmond location...small and unassuming...find by address number...leaving it up to the taiwanese sister to order...but, requesting fresh donut sticks and sweetened warm soy milk....a bowl to of soy milk to share...perfectly lightly sweetened...jar of sugar to sweeten more, but not needed...hot crispy outer and fluffy inner donut sticks...deep fried goodness...a dip in the sweet soy and tasty....crispy fried onion pancakes good...double stack portion and filling...thick and fried bubbling crisp...platter of dumplings decent...little hot oil and soysauce self-made to dip...quite the large servings...an order of the oyster noodles finding hefty, thick saucing and oysters loaded....tasting not fresh and the least favorite and biggest entree....about $sixteen total breakfast for two with plenty of leftovers boxed...
author: Hen A.

description: One of my favorite Taiwanese restaurant since I was a kid. Ordered their sweet and sour soup, potstickers, Mandarin beef and their meat sauce noodles. The food here always tastes so good and you get a lot for the price. The service here is very fast and your orders come fast. I would also recommend their Shanghai dumplings and their Chinese doughnuts where in San Francisco is very rare these days.
author: Peter C.

description: I've been craving chinese breakfast for a while.  I came here on saturday, hoping they would satisfy my craving.  Sadly, I don't even remember what I ordered.  I remember the serving being on the larger side and liking the green onion pancake.  Cool to see the guy making chinese donuts in the window.  Anything memorable...probably not...
author: Tiffany C.

description:
I'm going to be completely honest here. Nothing about the dumplings or the niou ro mien (beef noodle soup) is authentic. The dumplings are just steamed or boiled pot stickers. And the beef noodle soup is simply what the description is; a soup with noodles with beef in it. Although they were tasty, neither dish(es) are authentically Taiwanese, as the restaurant suggests it is. 

They used lo-mein noodles for the soup, which are not as bouncy and get soggy too fast, and they do not include the pickled mustard greens and use spinach instead. I also sensed there are some spices missing, such as star anise. And the dumplings' filling seemed wrong, as if it was just the same salty pot sticker filling. It should have been made with a consomme that liquifies during cooking which makes them juicier.

So, basically, if you were to go to Taiwan, you would never, ever, in a million years, find these dishes served this way, period. These are pretty much Americanized versions which had to be adjusted due to inexperienced American palates. And unfortunately, if you do not have the opportunity to travel to the real Taiwan, then the only authentic way to get the real deal (in San Francisco) is to find a Taiwanese person to make a home cooked meal for you.

I believe the owner of the restaurant is truly Taiwanese, so I hope one day the public will be ready for the real deal. When and if this ever happens, I will be there every single day at least for breakfast!

Anyway, I will say that the service is very good here. They speak English, Mandarin, and Cantonese. I have yet to hear Taiwanese, but I would not doubt that they probably speak it too. The menu is also quite extensive, and there is a good variety of Americanized "Chinese" food, mixed in with some "authentic" favorites. It is a rarity to find Taiwanese food in San Francisco, so I will give them a lot of credit for even having the option. Also, the dining area, china and flatware are clean. So, I will be going back, and I will recommend coming here, mainly due to the lack of alternatives for Taiwanese food.

Oh, and one thing I found authentic about this establishment was the restroom, which was authentically dirty, just like in Taiwan!
author: Lizzie L.

description:
I've been here on and off with my family for years.  Its good for Taiwanese food. The XiaoLong Bao and Potstickers are amazing! They really have great chef's in the front.

Down side? Service.  Its so bad that it takes away a lot of the pro's of the food.  Its filled with self-hating Asians...

A while back, I went here and there was somewhat a line.  After waiting a while, the waitress seated some non-Asian people who walked in after us.  She claimed these people came before us and just walked back.  Sure...   During the meal, the waiters were always great to serve the non-Asians, but we had to request several times for more tea, our FOOD and even the check. Serious?  You people are lagging when I want to give you MONEY?!

Another down side - its crazy crowded in there. I know you're trying to shove as many people in as possible, but GEESH.  If the guy behind me has to bump his chair into me EVERY TIME he breathes and you have to contort into a strange shape to get to my table...maybe its time to re-think the layout?? 

For the super savvy genius - Order take out. Come pick it up with non-Asians  Leave with your good food. Don't look back.
author: Lily W.

description:
I came here with pretty high expectations. My girlfriend is Taiwanese and this place is a couple minutes away from our apartment, so it felt like a good match.

After reading reviews, we figured we'd go with the dan dan mien, xiao long bao and green beans since everyone else seemed to praise these dishes. In the end, however, I was a little disappointed. Maybe I hyped it up too much heading into it, but it wasn't as good as I thought it'd be. The mien was a little bland, the xiao long bao were not xiao (small) at all and were just OK. The green beans were all right though.

I read someone else say that the taste fluctuates from bad to good, depending on the day so hopefully it was just the day we came by. The place was clean and the service was real nice. I have no complaints. I just wish the food was a little bit better.
author: Alex T.

description: Sizzling rice soup is yummy. I also like the pickled greens with squid. The dumplings are also yummy. My favorite Taiwanese restaurant in SF so far.
author: Kim L.

description:
This used to be one  of my boyfriend's favorite restaurants,  He still comes here quite regularly on Sundays, and he's taking me 2 or 3 times now.  Every time we come here, he gets a little nervous and says, "I hope it's good today..."  Apparently, the flavor fluctuates...a lot.  

He keeps taking me here because he claims this is the beef noodle soup I am looking for--good brown broth, chunks of beef, fat noodles, a little spicy.  Every time I go, it's pretty good, but not great,. The broth is a bit watered down.  

Their pan-friend dumplings are always pretty good--though last time they were a little watery? which was weird.  

The kicker was when we ordered the sweet Chinese donut.  I did not enjoy this at all.  It needed to be warm or soft or warm and soft.  

Thus said, it's cheap, and still pretty good.  I'm looking at another review of this place, and it says to try the dan dan mein.  I LOVE dandan mein...maybe I would go back just to try that ...
author: Aly A.

description:
This restaurant is a small, quaint building located in the Richmond District.  The food is tasty, but is high in salt, so if you have health challenges it may not be for you.  They also use soybean oil- not healthy.  The service is adequate, but not as attentive as I prefer for my dining experience.

Part of the reason it receives 3 stars as opposed to 2 stars is because of it's super cheap prices.  3 of us ate for about $25.  We ate family style and ordered 3 pork buns, prawns and asparagus, steamed rice, and beef chow fun.  I also ordered a glass of plum wine which was only $2.50.
author: Mieke B.

description: Great place ! I ordered the clay chicken, it was a HUGE portion, tasted great, had good amounts of sliced ginger and basil in it. we could barely finish it. Definitely one of the best values in town
author: Jonathan F.

description:
This place is great! Had no issues ordering vegetarian plates. The woman was very helpful and understanding that we didn't want any meat in our dishes.

The soy milk is quite good, like many have said. I didn't personally want to sweeten the soy milk, but I could see why people like it as a dessert with the donuts.

I'd go back again for another giant yummy meal. As others have said, the portions are huge, cheap and good.
author: Ninja R.

description:
I really like this spot!

The service here is good and food is good, too! (except for the oyster noodle dish, which was prepared incorrectly).

The Taiwanese country chicken (I think that was the name) - DELICIOUS!
The spicy oil dumplings are good, and the green onion pancakes, too!
Oh yeah, the soy milk is good as well, so is the Chinese fried dough thing (not sure what it is called in English lol). I like to eat them together (dipping the fried dough in the soy milk).

They serve dim sum all day (small selection), which I love.

We've eaten there about 3 times between December and January, so that says a lot.
author: Sway M.

description:
My first time having taiwanese food and I was a happy fat child when I was done with dinner. The waiter/owner was really nice and sweet. Decor could use some sprucing up, but I came for the food, not the ambiance. There were 3 of us, we ordered 4 dishes and I have enough food for two days of leftovers. 

Here's what we ordered:

Sizzling rice soup - yes! thanks to the yelpers that raved about this, or else I would've missed out. Pretty cool hearing that rice sizzle as it gets dropped into the soup. Veggies were fresh and crisp, shrimp was plump and fresh as well.

Green Onion Pancake - our waiter recommended it since they were out of chinese donuts. I loved this, so simple and tasty, you can't really go wrong with fried dough. Dunked it in the soup for that perfect combo of soft and crispy. 

Spare Ribs (I forget which kind since my friend ordered these) - battered deep fried and tossed in a sweet and savory glaze. Reminded me of the chicken wings from San Tung. Huge portion so I have tons of leftovers, yes!

Crispy Chicken - the only sad dish of the night. There was crispy skin on some of the chicken pieces, but for the most part it was just dry chicken in a sauce similar to the spare ribs we had. I'll still eat it, but could've done without this.

I don't know how authentic this place is as far as Taiwanese food goes, but it's damn good. That's all the matters in my book.
author: Sophie P.

description:
I usually come here with my family and order a bunch of stuff. The chinese doughnuts are soft and go well with the sweet soy milk. The deep friend onion pancakes are really good too. The dan dan mein is really good here. The spicy sauce is really good with the thick noodles. The pot stickers are really fresh. You can usually watch them make the pot stickers in the front while waiting for tables. The xiao long bao and the shrimp and chive dumplings are also good to order. The portion size for the chicken and broccoli over rice is big.   

The inside of the restaurant looks old. There is only street parking.
author: Alexander L.

description:
The only things true to Taiwan is the name. If you're looking for true Taiwanese flavor, no need to waste money here. 

We came here for breakfast and dinner once each. Nothing special worth mentioning in the dinner. As for breakfast,  I was happy when I saw the breakfast menu. But when the Chinese donuts came, I was so disappointed. They didn't either look like nor taste like the Taiwanese Chinese donuts. This disappointment made me ate Chinese donuts every morning for breakfast when I went to Taiwan a few months later. 

If they don't have the name Taiwan, I would give 3 stars for the food.
author: V L.

description:
(See pics)

I love this place. I ate here when I first moved here a few years ago with my best friend. A few years later as we talked about the place, we walked right by it and decided to eat here again.

As soon as you walk in you can smell the great cooking aroma. We sat down and immediately knew what we wanted first, the deep fried silver rolled dough. The dough is always my favourite since I was a kid. And the deep fried ones are special.

We also had the hot soy drink, so very good. For the main dishes we had the Fu Pei with preserved veggies (shin chai), 3 cups chicken (just learned the name is to do with 1 cup of sugar, 1 cup of wine and 1 cup of soy sauce), Wu Gan Chung Wan (tofu with lots of green onions, preserved vegetables and pork red (blood formed cubes that actually is not as what it sounds but very delicious) in a hot pot that has a burning flame to keep it warm while you eat.

In addition to all these, we had a side of rice.

It's all for 40 dollars and we took some food home!

My limited Taiwanese (language) came embarassingly handy as we communicated and the family owners were so very nice to help us on the ordering and recommending!

And the most amazing thing is that I bumped into my another best friend at the restaurant that I have not seen in ages!! Such an intersection of great food and fantastic friends!

This is almost a full circle of what I have experienced in the last few years with great reunions at a warm, welcoming family style restaurant that serves some of the best food I have experienced!
author: T L.

description:
It's decent Chinese breakfast food.
