Had the usual sweet soybean soup (Dao Jeung) with Chinese doughnuts (Yao Tiu), Red Bean bun, some other type of plain bread/pastry, and minced meat noodles (Jia Jeung Meen). 

The noodles were the best. Everything else was good but nothing spectacular.
author: Melissa T.

description:
I was craving Taiwanese food and decided to check this place out for lunch. To be completely honest, I was a little underwhelmed. 

I was hoping they would have lu rou fan on the menu. No dice. :( So I ordered the beef noodle soup and xiaolongbao. I will say that the portion size was very generous -- the dishes I ordered would definitely have been enough for at least two people. The xiaolongbao was a little dry and the beef noodle soup was also disappointing. Not terrible, but nothing that will make me a regular here either. 

As a warning, I guess readers should know that the last time I ate Taiwanese food, it was in Taipei, so maybe I'm just being picky.
author: Jenny B.

description:
This place was so bad that I didn't even want to bother yelping it. Sigh... You would think that with the name "Taiwan", they would have good Taiwanese food. I guess not.

 We had the oyster noodles and pancakes - both of them didn't have much flavor and didn't taste anything like what it was suppose to. The texture was all wrong. Everything was really pastey. Even the rice cakes had wilted vegetables. Ick. 

Definitely won't be back here. Ever. I'd rather eat McDonald's (which I never eat).
author: Cynthia C.

description:
A restaurant named after a country and so you would think that the folks are Taiwanese but in fact I think they are from China but they serve food from Taiwan and also from China. A little confusing I know but at the end of the day, the food is delicious and cheap and so we would definitely come back.

Their regular menu does not have some of the Shanghai/Taiwanese specialties so make sure you look at the wall for the goodies:

*Green onion pancake-it's deep fried versus pan fried. It's really crunchy so it doesn't have the typical consistency of the chewiness of the pan friend one. 

*Spicy green beans-yum, I love this dish

*Genereal Tso's chicken-a little less tangy than Orange chicken, deep fried goodness

*Steamed pork dumplings-xia long baos-very fresh

*Shrimp and leek dumpling-we got this boiled but I highly recommend getting it pan fried (that's what I did with the leftovers and it was soo good)

Our total including tip came out to be less than $40 and we had enough food for dinner the next night.

I would definitely come again and next time order the pan fried dumplings!
author: Betty C.

description:
I've walked by this place a million times and never went in til today.  My friend said this place has the best onion pancake and sizzling rice soup.  Sounded yummy to me so I went in.

My Lunch:
-sweet soy milk - I added no sugar cause I like the taste bland. I loved it!  Fresh made warm soy milk  really hits the spot on a cold rainy day like today.  Must drink it when its warm.  When its cold it doesn't taste as good.

-Chinese Donut- Fresh made and simply delicious.  I ate this with my soy milk.  Just so simple and perfect!

-XLB (dumplings)- Not a fan.  The skin was too thick and there was no soup.  Probably the worst dumplings I've ever had.  

-Sizzling Rice Soup - This I loved!  Its a bit on the salty side but I like it that way. Its a clear broth with veggies and chicken and shrimp.  They top the soup with crispy fried rice.  It gave the soup more texture.  Really enjoyed the part crunchy and part soggy texture of the rice.

-Onion Pancake - You can't go wrong with this pancake.  I think it was ok.  I prefer the pancake to be flat and not too many air bubbles in the dough.  But still the taste was very close to the real deal. Right amount of dough and green onion :)


Definitely will have to come back here again to try out more items on the menu.
author: Ying F.

description: I'm Taiwanese and I can tell you most of the food here isn't great. If you are a true food lover, go elsewhere. The Chinese fried doughnut (yo tiao) is not crispy, the Taiwanese special rice noodles are too "wet", the Taiwanese country spare ribs ...eh. The owner seems to be too preoccupied to really pay attention to his customers. Also, he would drop all the dishes into the bucket to wash very loudly - we sat by the kitchen so it was really annoying and loud, and every 10 minutes. Really unnecessary. I took my dad and aunt here and they were very underwhelmed. We love food made with thought, and it doesn't seem like this is a place that thinks about the quality of their food.
author: yvonne c.

description: Omg, those are typical Chinese food, especially south of China, such as Shanghai, Suzhou and Hangzhou.. NOTHNG TO DO WITH Taiwan....! Those who lived in the 3 main cities, after the Chinese civil war escaped from mainland to Taiwan, kept their own eating&food style. That's so called "Taiwan" food .....You can call it: a little mini Chinese castle TAIWAN. So basically, once you tried so called Taiwanese food, that's definitely Chinese food...
author: Sherin G.

description:
I had cravings to eat the food at Taiwan Restaurant.  Finally made it to eat there after several years.  I was soooooo disappointed with the food.  It doesn't taste the same.  I wish that it did because I had cravings for their Chinese donut (yau tiu), potstickers and soup noodles with pickled vegetables and pork.  

The yau tiu was cold and hard to chew.

The potstickers were not juicy inside and no taste.

The soup noodles didn't have much flavor and the noodles were too soggy. 

There goes my cravings.....not going back ever again.
author: J W.

description:
We came to Taiwan Restaurant for dinner and it was solid. The service and food were both good. We ordered the following:

1. Chinese Pancake - the best dish we ordered that night. It's an onion pancake and fried just right. Wasn't too doughy, which has been an issue with the onion pancakes I've had at other places
2. Eggplant - thought this dish was decent. Just a heads up, it comes with shredded pork
3. General's Chicken - battered well and has a small kick to it, but not overwhelming

Overall, the experience was good but nothing that blew me away. I'd come back if my friends wanted to eat here but I probably wouldn't go out of my way to do so. 

My tummy gives Taiwan Restaurant...3 Stars!
author: Allan L.

description:
A Chinese friend of mine loves this establishment, so we have frequented it a lot, but my mother, born and raised in Taipei, tells me that the cuisine here is not Taiwanese. 

What is nice is the high standard of hygiene, difficult to find on Clement Street restaurants, it seems. The flower rolls are exquisite, but taking them home should be avoided unless you have a bamboo steamer and know how to use it.
author: George T.

description: ...starving after green apple books...wandered into this place...got stuffed on very good food...good even service...great prices...ignore that it's not gary danko decor-wise...and, lol, i always love hearing madonna, even in a taiwanese restaurant...
author: Bob L.

description:
I'd been craving Asian fare all day and noticed this place while waiting for the bus. There are a number of restaurants right in the area, but a sticker in their window says, "People Love Us on Yelp!"  That's good enough for me :)

I tried the steamed vegetable dumplings, sweet bean buns, and steamed white rice. The food was AMAZING.The bean buns were to die for. The rice (always my litmus test) was cooked to perfection, and still maintained its flavor and consistency after a night in the fridge. Prices were reasonable too, and the staff was friendly. Can't wait to go back!
author: Katie W.

description: Owner son George is super friendly and the food is authentic, just love it.
author: Alen H.

description:
As a starving college student, I remember surviving on instant ramen noodles, pasta-roni, and anything that is sold in the frozen section that is microwaveable.  Like my peers of the time, I would oft look for some eateries that were a decent price and filled me up.  If I knew about this place in college, I'd probably come here a lot.  

This place is ideal for the college student or anyone eating on a budget.  The portions are huge and the menus haven't changed since I don't know when.  Recollections of this place in my memory pop up when I was small, so this place has got to be at least fifteen years old.  Not only are the menus and price the same, the recipe, and the taste is the same. 

Do not get what they have labeled "beef crepe", if you're assuming it is their beef pancake.  Apparently, what they mean by "beef crepe" is a quesadilla looking thing with beef and hoisin sauce.  Their potstickers and xiao long bao (or XBL as used in many fellow Yelpers reviews) are huge here.  They're not the highest quality, but they're great for the budget diner wherever you are.

The noodle dishes and noodle soups are one of their fortes.  Personal favorite, the dom dom mein, which has a peanut like topping in their meat sauce.  The sauce also is a little spicy that mixes into the flavor of the dish.  The best asset that Taiwan Restaurant has is its Chinese donut.  There's something about the dough they use or something.  They have some awesome Chinese donuts.

Haven't eaten in a few days?  Need to feed a hungry college student or maybe you want to be a good samaritan and feed a couple homeless folk?  Taiwan Restaurant could be an alternative.  Healthy portions at a good price are what they're about.  I'll come here for their Chinese donuts to go.  Maybe stop by if I have a few bucks in my pocket.  With an abundant of options in the area, it wouldn't be my first choice though.
author: Arnold T.

description:
Taiwan Restaurant looks like a Chinese bakery from the outside and can be easily missed if you're looking for a restaurant front. The back of the place is the restaurant while the front is actually a bakery. The restaurant is pretty big on the inside.

The Chinese pancake here is definitely a really good dish. It's quite different from other onion pancake places. It's thicker, soft, and fluffy while tasting like a great.

I got some kind of special village chicken and it was a pretty mediocre dish. There were too much ginger for my taste mixed in. Also the chicken was chopped chicken leg pieces so they still had the bone inside of the meat. Gotta be careful with this dish or you'll be biting a lot of bone pieces here and there.

The service was great and nice. They speak English pretty good here for non-Chinese speakers. The food was prepared pretty quickly even though the place had quite a lot of people inside.
author: Steven B.

description:
** PLUSI

pot stickers (average)
sweet & salted tofu desserts (below average)
Shanghai dumpling (below average)  dough to thick
hot oil dumpling (good)
soy drink (good)
author: Sinny S.

description:
I love this place. But it's not real Taiwanese. If you go in expecting it you will not like it (it will prob be a 2-3 star). For me I've been coming here for years and didn't know what "real" Taiwanese food was until a few years ago. This is not real Taiwanese so go in with a open mind of just Asian food.

The "real" shao lung baos are suppose to be soupy and thin skin. This is thick skin and not soupy. It's a dumpling that should be called something else. I love these. I wouldn't call it shao lung baos but if you go in thinking it's a dumpling other than shao lung baos then you will like it. flavor is good and not too gingery. Just the way I like it. (BTW, my fav "real" shao lung baos are at Yank Sings, best in Cali in my opinion. And Yes, I've been to Din Tai fung in Arcadia. It's not as good as the ones in Asia so it doesn't make my list).

A must for me is sizzling rice soup. It's very clean tasting and I love it when the rice sizzles, yummers. It has veggies, chicken and shrimp.

I also really like the thick noodle stir fry. No idea what it is called cause my parents always orders it in mandarin. You can get it with any type of  meat.

Fresh Chinese donuts! They are the best here. Perfectly fried with not overly crispy. The sweet rounder versions are good too.

I've been coming here for 10+ years. I still love it. I requested to go there for lunch today actually. We always order the same thing: sizzling rice soup, "non" shao lung baos, the thick noodle stir fry with choice of meat (prob pork for me), and chinese donut with soy milk. OK, hungry now.
author: Karen L.

description:
Do NOT order their dumplings...
Their food is def below average.. I've had much better Chinese food for the same price.
author: Mia S.

description:
The price was incredibly low - around $6-$7/dish and the portions are pretty large. 

If you're not used to these sort of smaller, not super clean, Asian restaurants, you might be a little put off by this place, but just know that the food is usually fried so any bacteria will be dead :) 

Service is so-so, nothing to write home about, but what I expected

The taste is like home (home, being Taiwan) and I'll definitely be back. 

Be sure to get the minced pork noodles in bean sauce - *SOOO good* - it's the Chinese version of Jia Jiang Mein (vs. the Korean/Chinese version).
author: linda t.

description:
This is another old family favorite that I've been going to for years for the Northern Chinese dim sum brunch (noodles and dumplings galore).  I don't know what their regular dishes are like.  They also have a Taiwan specialties section of the menu that looks interesting, but we always have the dim sum.  They now have pork blood casserole - yum.  

Their menu claims that they were the first restaurant in the US to serve Taiwanese food.  I don't know if that's true but they have been around for decades.  I do like walking by and watching them make fried Chinese donuts in the window.  There aren't many places where you can see that and their donuts are always fresh.  

For brunch we usually get soy milk (salted or sweet, $1.25).  It's served hot in a bowl.  Delicious.  My father says their donuts aren't as airy and light inside as they should be but I think he's comparing it to what he had in Taiwan.  

Their shredded white turnip cakes (4 per order) were huge, the size of a red bean bun and stuffed with turnip, ground pork and mushrooms.  The shell was thin and flaky on top and thicker on the bottom.  These were really good.  

The hot boiled dumplings had a tasty pork filling but there wasn't enough filling and there was too much dough.  Also the soy sauce it was tossed in made the dumplings too salty.  I noticed you can ask for low salt - we should remember to do that though I'd rather get other dumplings (these were like won tons) with less skin.  The Shanghai thick noodle was disappointing - oily and bland.  

They are trying - they will make dishes w/o msg, with less salt or hot & spicy upon request and they even have brown rice now.  The food comes out very quickly, the décor is very pink but no frills, and the prices are reasonable.
author: Lolia S.

description:
I have eaten here with my friends and family. This is restaurant is quite good. As people think that Taiwanese cuisine is just Chinese food. But the fact is that it is quite different. I enjoyed the food here.

Top on the list I enjoy the three cup chicken. I have tried three cup chicken from other restaurants. This restaurant makes the best three cup chicken. The chicken is cook and braised in a clay pot. The result, is pieces of chicken the is tender and juicy with a slight sweetness because of the rock sugar used to braised the chicken. Yet the chicken is refreshing because of the use of basil. If you are craving a chicken dish remember to order the three cup chicken.
author: Christopher W.

description:
Great no frills Chinese (more than Taiwanese) food.  Good comfort food.  Not greasy, no MSG.  Extremely clean tables, everything gets wiped clean.  I've even seen them wiping down the soy sauce and condiment bottles, and menus.  Nice family-run place (fewer of these left here in SF!).  Nice mix of customers, and family-friendly.

I come here regularly to get my fix.  I stick to the basics (e.g., beef and broccoli) and everything has been good so far.  The highlights:
- Pot stickers are a must.  As everyone has mentioned.  Every table orders it, and you'll see why.
- Green beans are cooked perfectly.  Not mushy, CRUNCHY!  I usually get green beans with tofu or chicken.
- Hot and sour soup.  One of the few places that makes it with chicken instead of pork!
- Ma Po tofu.  One of my comfort dishes, personally satisfying.
- Brown rice is an option!

That's really about it.  I haven't ventured into the fringes/exotic parts of the menu, which seems to be where other people's complaints are coming from.  That's really not what I'm looking for in this place anyways (even though I am an American-born Taiwanese).  Just go here and try it out when you're craving some old-school basic Chinese grub.  You won't be disappointed in this local's spot.
author: J C.

description:
on a cold Saturday morning, my boyfriend wanted to come here. 
We sat down and a conversation followed when we were suddenly interrupted by the waitress.

waitress: you're so lucky!
me: huh?
bf: uhhh? 
waitress: she's so pretty!!
me: huh?
bf: *blank stare*
waitress: your girlfriend! she's so pretty! you're so lucky to be with her.
me: thank you! *snicker at boyfriend*

the rest of the day: 

bf: oh you think you're so cute don't you? just because the waitress said you're pretty! you're going to do something like, run over a dog and say "it's okay, i can get away with it, the waitress said i'm pretty!"

but anyways. in all seriousness, it was okay. i liked the soup and fresh hot soybean milk, mmmmmmmm.
author: Susy C.

description: The food here is okay. Their salt and pepper shrimp was meh. The steamed pork dumplings was the only item ordered that I actually thought was good.
author: Alice D.

description:
OH WOW! A hole in the wall restaurant in the clement with amazing food. 

We ordered chicken fried rice with some noodle dish that comes with fried porkchops (don't ask me what's it called b/c I don't know). It tasted amazing. Wasn't a big fan of the soup/noodle but the fried porkchops were like da bomb! The fried rice (which is usually an easy dish to make), was packed with so much flavor. It's almost as if it's saturated with something to make the rice heavier than usual. So good. 

Place is kinda dull looking though. They really should remodel the interior but other than that, the food was fantastic.
author: Lily W.

description:
CHILDHOOD FAVORITE

mom: where do you want to eat?
me: lets go to the pink Taiwan place

Its been a while since i ate here but it used to be my family's favorite place to eat when we have time to hang out together. good memories sitting with my parents and siblings and then after lunch or dinner, we would walk around and my mom would buy groceries before heading back home. 

Prices are decent and the food is very flavorful. We ALWAYS had to the Shanghai dumplings and noodle soup. normal Taiwanese food. I'm glad the restaurant is still open after so many years.
author: Carol Y.

description:
Was putting all my bets on the yelp community because the one in Berkeley with the same name is not good (or maybe ordered the wrong items)... anyway, being taiwanese-american myself, I found this place to be the perfect place for my cravings. 

-Started off with the mustard green & pork belly soup - warmed my soul!
- Soup dumpling (shiao long bao): it was dry. no soup spilling out. but it was tasty nonetheless. Shiao long bao's are not a specialty in taiwan
-The green onion pancake seemed extra crispy and fried .... and it was so tasty! 
-The oyster pancake (a staple taiwanese street food) was lacking the "snotty" consistency, but it was still delish
- Eggplant in fish sauce... i looove eggplant 

considering i haven't tried many places in sf or east bay for taiwanese food, i give it 4 stars. great service, super casual, and cheap food.
author: Marian C.

description: It is a restaurant which will be easily ignored ,cause its normal doorway. We ordered a beef noodle soup , lamp noodle soup, and three cup chicken, and they are delicious . My friend  recommended this restaurant to me ,and I think it is worthy to try, like it !
author: Panny P.

description: Didn't realize that I had already written a review, but after last night's dinner I wanted to because again, the folks working there are SO NICE! The rest of my old review stands, but I decided an upgrade was in order.
author: Quinn S.

description:
This place is a hidden gem. It does have a fancy glowing neon sign. It does not offer the the greatest of service but the food is solid. ...and it won't burn a hole in your pocket.

The braised lamb noodles is my favorite. The noodles are fresh, not prepackage. The portion of the noodles are on the larger end of the size spectrum.

I usually get an appetizer and share the noodles with my girlfriend. 
Good food has its limitation after that it is gluttony.

I am not Taiwanese, I don't have a reference of what good Taiwanese food is but I like what I ate. So you Taiwanese food snob/purist out there can suck it.
author: Tony N.

description:
I give this place three stars for their nice service.  It's much better than when I last came here many years ago.

I ordered their shrimp and chives dumpling.  It was okay, the skin was probably thicker than it should have been, thus making it more chewy.  Along with it I tried their hot and sour soup which was tasty with a lighter color texture than most other restaurants' version.

For actual Taiwanese food fan, there is a section of the menu more dedicated to food items more associated with Taiwan.  I would love to check those out despite my limited knowledge of their cuisine since I'm not a native of Taiwan.  At least the menu looks much better than, say, Taipei Restaurant on Ocean Avenue. One disappointment is that they do not serve fried stinky tofu, one item I definitely I associate with other Taiwanese restaurants that I've visited regularly.
author: H K.

description:
I don't know what everyone is raving about. Since I adore Shanghai dumplings, friends kept mentioning this joint. So I finally went on a Sunday morning. 

The dumplings were over-sized & the wrapper was too thick instead of delicate. The filling wasn't tasty - not enough spices or broth. 

All the other items the "expert" I went with ordered for brunch were fried. I rarely do fried - especially in the morning. I tasted everything & even the fried didn't help the food taste.
author: Kim S.

description: Xiao Long Bao was okay - not enough "juice" but okay. Other than that, the veggies tasted like they were "watered down" and double-cooked pork (hui guo rou) tasted super dry. I'm guessing this restaurant is only good for those authentic snacks (e.g. you tiao), but real dishes.
author: Su L.

description:
Came here for lunch with my friend. As soon as I walked in the waitress immediately greeted me very nicely ( I am not use to Chinese restaurants with nice happy workers). The place is really small I guess you can kind of say its a hole in the wall place but its on Clement Street so not really but I looks like a place that would be. But do not let the place fool you or turn you around. The food is really good and very very very CHEAP!

We didn't order any of the food off the menu. Instead we ordered the food that was listed on the wall. We got:

Shanghai Noodles- Not the typical Shanghai noodles I'm use to but it was still very good. It also came out a lot bigger then I thought it would. I got it with pork and it had veggies in it as well stir fried in a fat egg noodle. I liked it because it was not greasy at all and not too much soy sauce tasting like other ones I've had. 

Spicy Szechuan Noodles- It is the regular egg noodles with minced pork and a bunch of stuff (sorry didnt know what it was) and thick gravy/sauce. Do not let the name fool you, it is not spicy at all but it is soooo GOOOODD! Its one of the best dried noodles I've ever had. Definitely going to back and get that.

Green Onion Pancake- I also like that this one was not greasy like most other places. It was fried very well too. 

All of that came out to only $17! And we did not finish any of our food either! We finished only about half of each dish because we did not expect it to be that big. 

I would definitely recommend this place if you are looking for some good taiwanese food for CHEAP!
author: Annie L.

description:
This used to be a great place for authentic Taiwan style Chinese food.  A few years ago I would have rated it 5 stars.  Not anymore.

In the last couple of years I've had a few mediocre meals here and then a couple of days ago we came and we left feeling "never again."  The food had no taste.  Every dish we had was just plain lousy.  The service was adequate but not friendly.  I think this place is riding on its past reputation.  

We definitely don't plan to return.
author: Bob S.

description:
I wouldn't say this is the best place for Taiwanese food, but it is cheap and worth every penny. Portions are huge; in fact, this is probably one of the few restaurants around that don't rip you off.

Their dumplings seem to be very popular here, but I really don't think they're that great. The skin is just too thick. Plus, their potsticker (kuo tieh on the menu) and Shanghai Dumplings taste exactly the same, i.e. they use the same filling. Their Shanghai dumplings just doesn't taste right, plus the skin is too thick.

Their other dishes are good though. Potstickers are a good choice, radish cakes are cheap and delicious, and their country spareribs pack a unique sweet and salty taste. Also, for you oyster pancake (o wa jian) lovers, this place makes it, though I wish they'd be a little more generous with the sauce.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
We were walking down Clement Street one sunny day and were drawn into Taiwan Restaurant by the sight of 3 cooks making the most delicious looking dumplings in the window. We weren't very hungry, but the dumplings were calling our names so we ordered 1 basket of chicken and 1 basket of pork dumplings along with 1 of those long Chinese donuts with warm soy milk.

We were so excited when the two baskets of steaming dumplings arrived at our table, but after the first bite we found out that they were lacking in flavor. The donut and soy milk were ok, but we were really disappointed by the dumplings.

I have to admit that I don't know much about Taiwanese cuisine, so I am looking forward to going back and trying more items on the menu.
author: Keau K.

description: Ate there tonight. Waitress was pretty indifferent, never asked if we needed anything and did not bring utensils we asked for. Two dishes I ordered they did not have but we still ordered other three dishes. I was very disappointed that none tasted as I expected. I grew up in Taiwan n just visited Taiwan a month ago. The name of this restaurant is misleading to me.
author: Paiyu G.

description: My brother and his gf LOVE LOVE this place. So I finally went to eat with them and they ordered their usual. I personally LOVED their green onion pancake the best!! The dumplings were good too and the noodle dish we had was good. I thought the noodle soup was a bit of an overkill though on the noodles. The Dry Fried Green Beans were DELISH too! I can see why they keep going here and the bill was pretty cheap. We also ordered extra green onion pancakes and dumplings to bring home as well.
author: Leah F.

description:
I will never be disappointed by this place! I extremely love their turnip cakes, so that dish will appear on my table every single time I am there. I also usually go for their dried noodles and soymilk. Definitely big portions. I also adore the staff because they're so nice and courteous.

And they play old Chinese music like Teresa Teng (or 96.5 KOIT), so my old soul trapped in my young body is quite content about that.
author: C. C.

description: Hands down, this is my favorite Chinese restaurant in all of San Francisco (and perhaps the U.S.).  The food is as good as it gets.  Fresh, well prepared and tasty.  And come hungry, because the portion sizes are gigantic.  The prices are insanely good too... a meal for three adults came to less than $40, including tip.
author: Mike N.

description: Yes, i'm a fan. They have lunch specials that i get all the time...cashew nut chicken ...simple and fast! Dumplings are huge - a must try!
author: Thomas C.

description:
I was visiting from Seattle and had a case of bad cravings for Taiwanese food. A quick search on Yelp and I found Taiwan Restaurant with stellar reviews. Hey at least they got the name right, right?

Well that's about the only thing they got right.  I ordered the "fried yam cake with meat and mushroom" and Taiwanese oyster pancake. Both are very traditional Taiwanese dishes that every Taiwanese restaurant should do well or go home. 

I had a bad feeling when I walked in and heard the owner speak Cantonese. Nonetheless, I sat down and gave it a try; 200+ yelp reviews can't be that off, right?

Yam cake: the dough layer was way too thick thus undercooked. The stuffing was big chunks of pork that had no flavors. I think they microwaved it because the parts of it was cold.

Oyster pancake: what oyster? I found a total of one oyster inside. The dough/pancake part of the dish was too dry, the consistency was all wrong. They did not top it with the red sweet chili sauce per tradition either.

Reading other reviews, most people compliment their dumplings, juicy pork bun (xiaolong bao), green onion pancake, etc. NONE OF THEM ARE TAIWANESE FOOD. I believe Taiwan Restaurant does these dishes well but they can't do any Taiwanese food.

So the lesson is, Taiwan Restaurant may be a decent eatery but don't come here and order Taiwanese food...hmm...how ironic.  Blech.
author: John K.

description:
Taiwan Restaurant's inconsistencies leave it mired in the land of the forgettable.  

Our usual orders include the green onion pancake, Chinese doughnut, thick noodle chow mein, beef noodle soup, and thick sliced noodles.

The green onion pancakes vary in thickness, amount of oil coating, and crisp with each order.  

The Chinese doughnut is rarely freshly deep fried, and is discernible by its level of chewiness - the more chewy the doughnut, the less fresh it is.

The chow mein noodles and thick sliced noodles range from rubbery, limp, and unable to soak up flavor to al dente, fresh, and vibrant for the taste buds.

The beef noodle soup often contains enough salt for a pot twenty times the amount.

We come back here often because it is conveniently located and substantial for the price, but are ready to jump ship should we find a better restaurant.
author: Andrew M.

description: Large portions and cheap prices still gets this place 3 stars, but it is the pot stickers that is the highlight of this restaurant.  The other dishes seems to suffer from average quality ingredients that is masked by decent sauce unfortunately.  Still for those who are not ultra-selective would likely not be bothered by this fact.
author: Laurence H.

description:
This is my go-to spot for chinese food near my hood. I've gotten take-out from here, brought family and friends for lunches and dinners and I can't stop going back even though there are tons of chinese restaurants all over this neighborhood. 

I love their portion sizes. Whenever I get take out it usually lasts me for days. One time I got the lemon chicken, fried rice noodle and steamed rice. When I scooped out a serving of fried rice noodle it didn't even seem like the portion in the togo box lessened. That is awesome!

I also love their noodle soups. So far I've only tried the pork chop noodle soup and the beef stew noodle soup, but they are both so yummy and comforting on a cold, rainy day. I think my new new year's resolution is to go through their entire menu.

The waitstaff here is also friendly enough. I once made an order 15 minutes before closing and they accommodated. Thank God! I also like the man making chinese donuts in the front. It's quite enticing.

All in all this is a great taiwanese spot in my opinion and I did go to UC Irvine so I have some clout in my review.
author: Charlene C.

description: Came here earlier this week and had lunch with my parents. I thought this place would be like the old Taiwan Restaurant in North Beach. Nope...Horribly bad. We order a few dishes but they tasted the same. Heavy handed on the soy sauce. They have this oyster dish that has egg on it and something chewy. The oysters tasted nasty and really gross. And the xiao long bao were big and the skin was thick, not small and thin and fluffy like they're supposed to be. Horrible experience and not too sure if I would ever want to come back here ever again...
author: Anthony L.

description:
I have been coming here since high school....their food are A OK since years ago, no improvement or decrease in quality.  Good for average lunch, not recommended for dinner.  

Tipical Taiwanese food....not a big fan
author: Wasabi L.

description: Good green beans, sizzling rice soup (clean tasting), and green onion pancakes. Inexpensive and a favorite neighborhood place when you don't want to cook at home.  It's been here for years and years.
author: Nan W.

description: Delicious dumplings. SOOO good.
author: Emily D.

description:
I've been to this restaurant a number of times. After having lived in Taiwan for a few years, this is the closest to authentic Taiwanese food there is in the city. The servers can make you feel like being in Taiwan and will help with the selection. Ask for the oyster pancake if you dare.

The prices are low considering the portions being served. It's one of the best restaurants serving Taiwanese food in the Bay Area.
author: Alan L.

description:
I like going here as the service is polite usually pretty quick; The boiled dumplings are phat, succulent, stuffed with pork and other tender vittels and deelishus, did I mention you get ten of these tummy stuffers.  My favorite is the flat bean curd with chinese greens; it's a large serving of wonderful flat bean curd noodles and chinese cabbage, sooooo  yummy and healthy. Update, you can ask for brown rice. Try dumplings, flat bean curds with chinese leeks and  the mongolian lamb, these will topple your Tummy Tiger. 
Tonite, 11/13/07, the dry bean curd and leeks, and steamed dumplings were good, however, the rice was dry and looked a few days old. I did complain. Taking two stars off.
author: Bert K.

description:
Taiwan food is so delicious.  Especially for brunch, make sure you order the xiao long bao and the cong yo bing (steamed 'dragon' buns and scallion pancakes)

It's also super cheap too.  You can order a meal for two for less than 20 dollars and still have leftovers.

This is definitely one of the most under-rated Chinese Dim sum places I've been to
author: Alison L.

description:
3.5
this place sells cantonese, shanghainese, and taiwanese food. The dishes I usually get are the deep fried onion pancakes, the 5 flavored tripe, the xiao long bao's, and one of their noodle bowls. The deep fried onion pancakes are quite crispy and different than the usual pan fried variety and I highly recommend trying it here if you like onion pancakes. The xiao long bao's or soup dumplings are also made daily and steamed to order. They arent the best ive ever eaten but they are pretty good and i would say above average. They have various flavors of noodle soup bowls. I havent tried all of them but they all look good at least. The one i usually get is the preserved mustard green and pork noodle soup. Other notable dishes are worth getting is their hot soy milk and chinese donuts/oil sticks as they are usually made fresh daily.

overall its a good cheap asian restaurant that I would go to more often if I lived closer. Parking on clement can be a hassle.
author: Robert Y.

description:
Ginormous food portions!  One entree, and it's usually less than $7, can easily feed two!  

Everything we ordered from the spring rolls to the curry tofu w/rice to the braised beef ligament noodles tasted great.  I really enjoyed mixing the sweet sauce with the onion pancakes, it was awesome.  And pretty impressive veggie selection, I saw plenty of things that I wanted to try.  

Great service, UBER cheap prices, lots of tasty and good and filling food.  I think Taiwan Restaurant's a bargain, definately get a bang for your buck.
author: Swetha G.

description: Best sizzling rice soup ever. Friendly staff. Great prices. What else u can ask for:)
author: Mutlu T.

description: I like there.Nice waitress and soybean & Chinese donuts.
author: H S.

description:
Came here for lunch with my family and I have got to say, pretty good. Definitely can't judge a book by it's cover. The service was great, the people were nice and attentive. The food was yummy!

We got the FRESH hot soy milk. You add sugar to it yourself so it's perfect for those who are picky. It was very good. We also got the green onion pancake which was pretty good, very oily but what do you expect? We also go shanghai dumplings which were pretty good and they were huge! There's also the I think black bean noodles. It wasn't impressive because I've had better and cause it wasn't spicy. The best thing we ordered besides the soy milk would be the Shanghai noodles. Fat noodles cooked with meat and some veggies. I've never tried such fat noodles but I'm not a fan. 

The servers were super nice as they packed our unfinished food for us. Food came fairly quickly. I will definitely come back.
author: Annie W.

description:
I was on the hunt for jook (Chinese rice porridge) in the Richmond district, but decided to try for a northern Chinese breakfast at Taiwan Restaurant instead.

The scene:

At 11:30am, we were one of the first customers of the day, and the man at the front of the restaurant was frying up some homemade Chinese donuts.

Taiwan Restaurant has a lengthy 4-page menu with items varying from "Northern Chinese Specialties" to a variety of dry and soupy noodle dishes. They even have an impressive selection of fried breads which are probably made with lard, but who's counting calories, right?

The food:

For 2 people, we ordered the sweet fresh soymilk, a Chinese doughnut for dipping, spicy wontons and Szechuan Hot Sauce Noodles. All came out to about $20.

Soymilk and Chinese doughnut- Disappointingly, the soymilk was lukewarm. One of my pet peeves at a restaurant is lukewarm dishes. However, the doughnuts were fresh. We only ate half of it since it was so big.

Spicy Wontons - The wontons themselves were really good, but it wasn't spicy at all. The skins were thicker than I'm used to, but it was al dente - the way I like it. The meat was super juicy too. The sauce was basically just soy sauce. I didn't see any chili flakes or chili oil in it.

Szechuan Hot Sauce Noodles - These were sooo good! The noodles are the kind you usually see in northern Chinese noodle dishes. I don't think they were homemade, though. I really couldn't point out every ingredient in the sauce, but it was super tastey. Items I could point out were ground pork, peanut sauce, tons of hot sauce and and green onions. The dish was so big, we had to take it home some leftovers. The downside is this makes terrible leftovers. The noodles soaked up the sauce, making the noodles mushy. Dang!

Taiwan Restaurant seems to be a popular restaurant in the Richmond. They seem to be specifically known for their breakfast/lunch items. I'd like to come back to try a noodle soup.
author: Sam L.

description:
Food is alright. The service could be better. The last time I went, this bitchy girl was making a big fuss because she said my mom cut her in line (it was busy so we had to get numbers). She kept staring me down the whole time. I was just thinking...hey at least I'm not ugly. Bitch.

They seated us in the middle table in the middle of the room. There was a skylight above us and I had to wear sunglasses while eating because the sun was reflecting off the table and was blinding. True story.
author: Jenny T.

description: I came here on a Monday at noon. It was busy without being crowded. Service was attentive and friendly. I ordered sweet rice and pork in bamboo leaf, dumplings (pot stickers) and the dry braised green beans. I thought the green bean dish was just the vegetable, but for some reason she asked if I wanted it with the pork and dried shrimp. I was confused but asked for it without the shrimp. The beans and pot stickers came quickly and were fresh and hot. The pot stickers were nicely cooked but not as tasty as I might like. Beans were excellent with lots of ground pork. The pork was too salty for me but I am hypersensitive to salt. The sweet rice and pork was very good. A decent place and reasonable.
author: John K.

description: Very typical of Chinese places around San Francisco not all that great, and my parents really did not enjoy it, oh by the way I am Chinese and know what Chinese or Taiwanese is supposed to taste like
author: Rachel N.

description:
This place has really gone down hill.  I used to love coming here on Sunday afternoons with my family as a alternative to dim sum.  I used to enjoy simple dishes like hot sweetened soy milk, fried onion pancakes and thick shanghai chow mein.  My childhood memories will have to stay memories because those days are no more.

Had dinner here with my sister and mom about a month ago.  We came at the perfect time and grabbed the last available table in the place.  The bicycle cops were working extra hard that night 

- Cold jellyfish.  I've never ordered this here before.  I was shocked to see that they serve the jellyfish over a huge bed of cucumbers.  I'm not a fan of cucumbers and it sucked that the jellyfish took on the cucumber taste.

- Hot & Sour soup.  It was a bit bland.  I had to add more pepper to make it hotter.  I'm just glad they didn't over do it on the vinegar.

- Salted mustard green bits & pork.  This dish I did like.  Was great with some white rice.

- Black bean sauce noodles.  I like the noodles that they use.  The sauce is a different story.  It just tastes different than I remember it.  I used to like it.

I wonder if they have a different chef i the kitchen now?  If Yelp was available back i the days, I would have rated it a 4.  It's now as bad as it's Chinatown location used to be and that place is closed now.  I really hope they get better.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Generally, when it comes to any hole-in-the-wall Asian restaurant, or one in a Chinatown-type area, I have very low expectations with the service. So I was very pleasantly surprised by the smiles when we walked in, and how helpful they were when helping me order the right dishes. Some of them had slightly different names here than at other Taiwanese restaurants I usually frequent, so it took a little work. We ended up with way more food than we could finish, yet the bill was still only around $30 for two people. Had we only only ordered what we could really finish, it would've been much closer to the $20 mark.

This is a genuinely great place to grab some delicious food, all for very little of your hard-earned cash. Taiwan Restaurant (despite the uninspired name) is great, and I wouldn't hesitate to come back or suggest it to friends.
author: Patrick L.

description:
I don't care what none of y'all say, I still love her. Her, as in Taiwan Restaurant. This is my favorite Clement Street spot for soup, dumplings and chicken with asparagus, which is crazy fresh and has excellent flavor. In fact, I have a ritual: reflexology followed by soup and dumplings at Taiwan Restaurant, and then off to Super Tokyo to stock up on Royal Milk Tea and a case of toasted seaweed. Makes for a comforting foggy afternoon. 

And the staff are so kind here, with their occasional free thank-you donuts and genuine gratitude. It makes me happy to tip them extra, and that almost never happens while dining  out in San Francisco.
author: Quinn B.

description: Every single dish we ordered was a disaster. I haven't tasted Chinese food this bad in my entire life. Avoid this place please.
author: zhicheng w.

description:
pretty pretty good

hard working folks 

spinach, dumplings, tofu, hot and sour soup - all pretty pretty good

would go back

parking is a biatch around there though
author: Bobby B.

description: It pains me to do this but I our last experience was horrible.  We arrived and ordered our favorite dishes and they were good as usual. However, as we prepare to pay my friend notices that there is a disgusting dead bug in one of our dishes.  That completely ruined our meal and we vowed never to return.  The restaurant did not make us pay for that particular dish but this experience ruined any chance of us ever returning.  Sadly, our love affair with Taiwan restaurant is officially over.
author: Jammie A.

description: Like the xao long bao, green onion pancake and all of the sauces.... great prices I always love a deal. Dinner tonight with my boys always a great time.
author: Tan N.

description: I've always passed by this place when I'm in the I-Rich so decided to pop in yesterday. Ordered up the  ('beef crepe'- one of my favorite snacks in Taiwan), expecting this : http://globaleats.blogspot.com/2010/09/taiwans-resurgence.html. Not even close. What I got was a flat (not crispy or flaky) super dry 'crepe' (more like a day old tortilla, if I'm being honest) filled with blandish braised beef slices and a few green onions. No griddle marks either!  Big letdown.
author: Anthony R.

description: Scared when I saw a waitress yell at one of the patrons for complaining the food was cold but my server was so extremely sweet!!! Gave me extra napkins to soak up  grease! ( so Asian). Food was delicious except the beef wrap was not really my kinda thing...This place is more like shanghai style than traditional Taiwanese
author: Katherine C.

description:
I remember coming to Taiwan Restaurant when I was just a kid. This would be one of the few places my parents would go to have chinese fried donut with warm sweet soybean milk. This was my chinese equivalent of a McDonald's happy meal.

Years later... I finally made my return visit to Taiwan Restaurant with a group of my co-workers. Of course I ordered my chinese happy meal. To my amazement some of my co-workers... some who are chinese did not know how to eat this!

So... this is how you eat a chinese fried donut with a bowl of warm sweet bean milk. The soybean milk should come without sugar. So, add sugar and mix till you find your perfect sweetness. Next, take a piece of donut and dip into the bean milk. Get it soaked and eat! Easy peasy... japanesey. Or you can toss in a couple of pieces of donut into your bowl and eat it like cereal.

As for the rest of the menu... some winners include the chicken wings, Taiwan Seafood Rice and Dry-Braised Green Beans.

The dishes may be a little on the salty side but most of the sauces that come with the dishes are tasty.

Prices are cheap... $10 bucks for a big lunch... good deal!
author: Sam T.

description:
I love this place. 

Cheap, and delicious food. 

I love the waiter. That one old man is so nice. They're not rude at all. They're patient with you if you try to order in Chinese and your Chinese sucks. 

I loved everything I've tried here.

My favorites:

Pan fried rice cake with shredded cabbage and pork - I always get this. It's not too salty or oily. 

Noodle.. with bean sauce? - I love this too! I prefer the one with meat, and not the vegetarian one because the sauces are VERY different. 

Noodle soups and fried rice is good too!

I don't even know what else I've tried here since I come here so often. But take a risk, and order whatever sounds good!

I'm going to try sizzling rice soup next time :)
author: Christina X.

description:
Had a Shanghai dinner for two and Five Spice Beef for Chinese New Year/Valentine's Day, shit was really good and filling- the Five Spice Beef was actually as good as my family's traditional recipe and the pork and chicken dishes were perfunctory, but well cooked and flavorful.
Quick service and surprisingly friendly staff for a neighborhood Chinese place and I can't wait to try this place for breakfast You Tiao and Mantou!
author: Heng W.

description: Fantastic food, very reasonable prices, friendly staff (seems like a family-run place), typical Inner Richmond Chinese restaurant ambience. Love the dumplings, wohl wonton soup.
author: Greg A.

description:
My first time at this establishment and, in particular, eating Taiwanese food was a satisfying experience. The wait staff was friendly, attentive and helpful for a mid-week, early afternoon lunch hour. The vibe and atmosphere of the restaurant was great: it was a calm and quiet setting to enjoy a nice lunch.

I got a sense they take pride in preparing meals for their patrons. For instance, the garlic, onions, and bamboo shoots used in their entrees were finely chopped, unlike other Chinese restaurants, where it's apparent less effort was involved in the preparation. Their food reminded me of home-style cooking, atypical of the oily and greasy Chinese fare one might expect. While food arrived at a nice pace, I didn't feel rushed to finish eating.

I ordered their Chicken Dumplings, Crispy Prawns (a daily special), Dry Green Beans (a daily special), Green Onion Pancake (not on the menu), Mongolian Beef, Szechuan Hot Sauce Noodles, and Wok-Fried Rice Cakes with Pork and Chinese Cabbage. Food wasn't too salty or, in the case of the Mongolian Beef and Szechuan Hot Sauce Noodles, spicy. With the exception of the overcooked, pasty and bland Wok-Fried Rice Cakes, I would recommend all the dishes, especially the Szechuan Hot Sauce Noodles that is not your usual chow mein but is topped with I think some kind of peanut sauce.
author: Cliff W.

description:
There are three statements I will commonly say that almost invariably brings a shocked look of disappointment and loss of foodie respect to most men's faces.
 
"I'm not big on pizza..."
"I don't really like Mexican food."
"Chinese food is not my favorite."
 
But let me explain.
 
I love excellent pizza, but it's extremely rare that I will find pizza of this class.  I had it once in NY, and found it again in Venice, Italy - and recently discovered it in San Francisco.  Three times over a lifetime isn't much - so it's easier for me to say that I'm not big on pizza rather than explaining how good pizza has to be for me to like it.  
 
While I enjoy a few things from Taco Bell - let's make clear that this is not Mexican food.  So then taking me to most taquerias results in a very mediocre meal for me.  But having had meals cooked for me by authentic Mexican families, and having had excellent dishes IN Mexico - - I love real Mexican food.  There's very little in life that beats a tamale that is too hot to touch, plump w/ fresh meat, etc.  There are some taco trucks in Oakland that the mere sight of requires a napkin to wipe the drool off my face.  But the majority of Mexican restaurants will result in an unsatisfying meal for me.
 
Then there's Chinese food....
Beef and Broccoli, shrimp w/ lobster sauce can only be so good and it's Americanized Chinese food.  It's just not my thing.  Dimsum, I love... but there, too, I am entirely too picky about what good dimsum should taste like.  I love porridge, but not when there's more water than substance.  Throw me in Shanghai, and I think you'd probably have a hard time stopping me from eating everything - but when friends are gathered deciding where to go for dinner, if someone mentions Chinese, I will usually pipe up with other suggestions, hoping to avoid more "so-so" meals.  But my search for excellence in Chinese food, though, has been kicked into gear lately, and there seems to be no end to how much Chinese food I can try.  Most, however, I will not like.
 
Enter:  Taiwan Restaurant.
 
Located on Clement Street, I would probably walk right by without a second thought if not for the small area in the front window showcasing a man making dumplings.  It looks good, but I'd enter assuming it's just "OK".  But Rob went to this restaurant a week or so ago with his friend and never stopped talking about it, and every night's dinner suggestion resulted in, "Chinese Food tonight?  Taiwan?"
 
Finally, we decided to go.
Photos uploaded.
 
The dumplings here are, in fact, extremely good.  If I had to ding them for something, it'd be that the wrappers are thicker than what I like in a dumpling.   I'd recommend the pork dumplings, and shrimp with chives dumplings.  The first is steamed, the latter boiled, but it gives you a good glimpse on what this place can create.  These are steroid-sized dumplings - REALLY BIG!  (We also ordered the beef, but there was no discernable difference between that and the pork - and if you had to pick one, I'd suggest the pork.)  We also ordered some entrees - - a scallop and snow peas dish, and Schezuan beef with an order of rice.  If I give their dumplings a 4.5 - I give their entrees a 3.5-4.  The ingredients are FRESH, and it's cooked well, but neither dish made the top 5 level that I expected after having the dumplings.  Chinese food at Yuet Lee is still the only one that I have found in the city to be top 5, no matter what I order - -- but they don't make dumplings - at least I don't think so.  I'm too busy eating porridge when there to notice much else.
 
Notable was  that the rice was more Korean than Chinese - sticky instead of jasmine type of rice.  Interesting.
Dumplings should be ordered first - - as they will take a considerable amount of time.
Service is professional and nice.  The hostess remembered Rob from the week before, including where he sat and what he ordered!  No doubt, I will be back to this place when I need a dumpling fix.   Their prices are also really economical!

Being Korean, I have no idea whether this is authentic or not.  It's not necessarily authentic that I am looking for - - just some really good food, period.  Goodness knows "authentic Korean" doesn't mean it's delicious.... just give me good, tasty food!!
author: Grace K.

description:
Not sure why it's called Taiwan restaurant.  The food certainly is not "Taiwanese" or "Hokkien".  It's more like Panda Express. 

The interior is depressing, like a funeral parlor.  The servers are all very old and tired looking.... bunch of old male servers.

The menu is really a mesh mash of Chinese and Americanized Chinese dishes.  The food is horrible here.  Greasy, bland, very poor quality and not authentic.  I ordered 4 dishes, had maybe 2 bites of each and just could not eat another bite after that.  Needless to say, I did not ask for doggie bags that night.
author: Paul K.

description:
Here's what you need to order:

Fresh Hot Soy Milk (add one spoonful sugar)
Onion Pancake 
Shanghai Pork Dumplings
Shanghai Thick Chow Mein
Garlic Szechuan Shrimp (request no batter, trust me!)
Beef Noodle Soup
Bowl of Rice (to mix with garlic szechaun sauce)

You can thank me later. 
(My fav lunch; cheap eats; hangover cure; Pepto Bismol colored restaurant in SF.)

Good food. Great prices. No frills. Taiwan. Restaurant.
author: Deanna T.

description: Wow this place is such a rip off. I bought the Mandarin Lamb for $9 and didn't realize that the to go box was so small. Inside this togo box was mostly vegetables and a little bit of lamb. I would not suggest coming here if your a college student looking for a good deal.
author: Joan B.

description:
This was the first time I've ever dined in a "Taiwanese" restaurant.... well I wasn't impressed with their food : -T so that was a bit of a let down. A friend, who's Taiwanese, ordered the oyster noodles and said it was all kinds of wrongs going on there... haha. The service was nice and friendly, they don't talk with you much (which i don't mind) but maybe that's because of the language barrier... They really tried to give us the best service that they could! 

Food: 
* Oyster Noodle - Corn starchy gravy with thin shrimp or egg noodles with lots of oysters. Oysters could've been fresher... : -T 
* "Clay Pot" Chicken - Sorry, but when was the last time that pot was scrubbed!! It was tasty enough but came with lots of boney pieces of bark meat... and lots of slices of ginger (those were pretty tasty and mild) 
* Green Beans - BEST dish we had, they were stir fried and had nice crunch! 
* Soy Sauce Chicken - It looked like soy sauce chicken with the sauce around it, but it had an interesting vinegary flavor to it. 
* Soup Dumplings - There's suppose be a little broth (soup) in each pouch, but there wasn't. The actual filling wasn't bad, but it crumbled (which it shouldn't). Some people may know these dumplings as Shanghai Dumping. 

Service & Space: 
This place is a complete mom-and-pop place in terms of the service and quality/preparation of the food. Old school Chinese restaurant with pink walls...
author: Fried Rice B.

description:
It's chinese food.  It's solid good, well priced chinese food. I like their deep fried pork chops and green beans. 
Minus one star for no consistancy. One day great next day way to salty or gamey tasting. 
If ur in the area i would highly recommed it. Especially if your into the hole in the wall place alot of the local chinese eat at.

Not much for dim sum. Meal for two under $15 plus tip
author: Spanky M.

description:
I'd heard so many good things about Chinese eateries in San Francisco so when I visited, I did some research on places that had "you tiao" and soy milk. I saw that Taiwan Restaurant "xiao chi" from Northern China and decided to give this place a try. 

The soy milk was decent and the you tiao was not bad, but the rest of the food was just shameful. The frozen dumplings I buy from Ranch Market are better than these. When I think of small eats from Northern China or Taiwan, I think of thin-skinned, juicy buns and dumplings. The dumplings and steamed pork buns were way too doughy and sticky. I have never had such thick-skinned dumplings! There was nothing "small" about these eats! Everything was large, clumsily and bland. Anyone who thinks this place has good food obviously doesn't know their authentic Chinese food.
author: Lulu W.

description:
Arguably the oldest Taiwanese restaurant in the Bay Area, maybe it was good when nobody knew any better, but with tons of restaurants offering similar and wider variety fare in the East Bay and South Bay, this place doesn't glow anymore.

Yelpers if you have actually been to Taiwan recently and have eaten anything from street food to restaurant fare, then come back and eat at Taiwan restaurant, you will either shake your head, laugh or cry (or both), question why this place exists and why people still flock here, and also wonder why people would debase themselves to eat such crap.

I'm not trying to be mean and I do appreciate that this restaurant exists to serve a type of cuisine that's virtually impossible to find in SF, that also has been around for a while.

From a Cantonese snack/fried starch palate standpoint, this place is nice in that you can get yoh tieou (crullers) and its respective variations, including the "beef tongue pastry" which is a sugary donut that oddly enough looks like a set of lips or depending on how deviant you are, a vertical smile. People who grew up in Hong Kong during the 60s to 80s might remember having this as street food. But then that's where the gems end. While soy milk and yoh tieou are great comfort food snacks, I dare say their soy milk isn't really that great, and anyone from Yung Ho Taiwan will laugh and cry for paying x2 to x2.5 prices for the same portion (heck even Yung Ho restaurant in Southern California, San Gabriel on Valley Blvd does a better rendition that's more like the real deal). It just sucks we don't have something like that up here.

The restaurants main menu has more or less stayed the same in the past oh I don't know 15 to 20 years. I know Taiwanese street food has been around 100 years at least, and the fact that the business doesn't keep up to date with food trends, what is considered a good snapshot or representation of Taiwanese food, or innovate means that they continue to offer the same stale standard fare over and over (much like most Chinatown restaurants).

And don't get me started about the one in Berkeley...
author: Ken K.

description: There are two things that I really enjoy here: the beef noodle soup and the dou hua.  The noodles always taste fresh, the soup is rich and flavorful and you get some nice chunks of beef.  It's comfort food, Asian style.  The dou hua, which they only have on weekends, is made on site, I believe, and you can really tell from the taste and texture.  It's a shame they don't have this that often since I could eat this all day long.  Another thing they have going for them is that the dumplings are also made on site, and you can't go wrong ordering the shui jiao or guo tie.  Lastly, their lunch special rice plates are humongous (I can only finish about half) and pretty cheap.
author: Jeffrey T.

description:
Potstickers and Siu Lon Bows are not as good anymore.  Potstickers are cold and too crispy.  They've gone downhill.

Service without a smile.  Based on these two factors,  I don't go as often anymore.
author: MickYee M.

description:
Mustard greens with pork noodles, side of pig ears and rice wine.  

I found out that I'm not a big fan of rice wine, but everything else was good.  Especially the bill for only about $10.  

The menu is huge and everyone in my group liked what they ordered.
author: Corey V.

description:
When I'm depressed or hung over, or both, the dumplings and pot stickers at Taiwan are among my staples.  On those occasions when I want to act like a girl, and eat my problems into deeper ones, I head there first. 

I just devoured an order of each, and now I'm going to cry myself to sleep.
author: Jason R.

description:
We came here for soy bean milk breakfast the day after yet more partying.  

The joint:   Typical chinese restaurant with Taiwanese fare.

The food:  With the soy bean milk we had the sweet and savory fried doughs as well as the green onion pancake, the fried rice cakes, noodles and dumplings.  The soy bean milk was alright.  You could go the same with the Golden Gate Soy bean milk you get from the store hot.  The fried dough was excellent though and we ordered another sweet roll after the first vanished so quickly.  The green onion pancake was crispy, hot and not too oily; better here than other places.  The dumplings were not as tasty though.  

The service:  though they take your order right away, you've got to wave someone down it you want anything else.
author: Marie L.

description:
Ahhh, Taiwan restaurant...  Brings back memories.  I've been coming here on a random basis since maybe 14 years ago.  Their green onion beef over rice has been one of my fav dishs for over ten years!  They also serve the good ol' soy milk and the long fried chinese doughnut thing.  hmmmmmmm, long fried chinese doughnut thing.....
Considering the low prices here, it really deserves five stars~
author: J D.

description: Taiwanese restos are meager in SF. Good thing I'm not that picky about Chinese food in general. The meat rice here and zha jiang mian are ok.
author: Erika C.

description:
When I first arrived in the bay area (from Taiwan to LA then to SF), this is about the only place that you can get some Taiwanese food:  fried chinese donut, soybean milk (savory), and most of all cuttlefish soup.  I was delighted to find a branch in Berkeley.  

Now forward 20 years to present day...I brought my husband to share the fond memory of surviving in a foreign land of no Taiwanese food...we ordered...ate...and he said as he shed his tear, "baby, I'm sorry you had to eat this nasty food growing up..."

The spicy wontons were the worst I had.  They were like frozen dumplings, thick skin not fully cooked, tasteless meats, and the "red oil" sauce is bland.  We couldn't even finish the dish and certainly didn't bother taking it home.  
The stir-fry rice cakes were very bland and greasy.  The cuttlefish soup is fishy and without good flavor.

I didnot believe it, and went back again...but sadly I feel like I was not eating anything Taiwanese cuisine, but really a panda express...

How has thou fallen so far down, O Taiwan Restaurant?  How do you survive with competitions such as Joy, Taste of Formosa, Southland Taste and the likes sprouting like springtime shoots?  

I think it's really one star but one extra star for old time sake...
author: MooMoo L.

description:
I'm a little stunned by the glowing reviews.
My experience was "adequate, maybe good food, abysmal service" 
Our greeter bluntly told us "This is taiwanese, don't mistake this Dim Sum for cantonese, you can get that down the street!" And a happy day to you too! All we asked was do you have dim sum.

We sat down, and waited, and waited, and waited and started to wonder if this was a buffet dim sum with the food in the back we were supposed to get until we finally got menus.  The whole vegetarian thing is a concept lost on them.  They have plenty on the menu to accomodate a vegetarian however.  

When we wanted to order some food to go after we ate, this caused major confusion and they finally sent out an American born, English perfect girl who was very helpful and clearly admonished her elders for some of what they were doing to the patrons.  

So look for her but don't look for me because we won't be back.
author: Sean S.

description:
Coming to Taiwan Restaurant is like coming home again...and again...and again...and if you are like me...again. The food doesn't change much and always greets you with a big hug (as much as a set of 'xiao long bao' or a heaping pile of 'zha jiang mien' can embrace one). I definitely still feel the love, and at a more than reasonable price. 

And to add to this already bountiful bundle of flavors, I would suggest the green beans, which I kid you not, would make any vegetable eating child (or adult, for that matter) rethink their diet. Deep fried pork chops, yiu tiao (Chinese donut), soy bean milk, deep fried chive pockets....yadda, yadda, yadda. I could go on for days....but I wouldn't want you to risk starving yourself where you could just go out and get the food.

Don't forget to wipe that river of drool from the side of your face either, I'm not sure how attractive that will look in front of the Taiwan restaurant crowd.
author: D L.

description:
Just read yelper Lolia's review. This restaurant definitely cooks with a lot of msg. The food is tasty and greasy. You will leave the restaurant feeling super thirsty. I like their noodle dish, sweet and salty soy milk with Chinese donuts. My favorite dishes for dinner are string bean and 3 cups chicken (direct translated from Chinese menu). The 3 cups chicken requires 30minutes of preparation time. 

Prices are pretty cheap here, about $10-$15 per person with plenty of left over.
author: Ervinna L.

description: Good food, but they throw the dishes around when cleaning tables. It is very distracting and keeps you on edge at all times.  Not a pleasant dining experience.
author: Andrew N.

description:
I am meh about this place.

I came here on a friday night and there was a couple waiting in front of us. There were two tables that should have been open up, but they were dirty and not cleaned up yet by the two waiters who were busy doing other immaterial things such as getting water for others. They should have hired more waiters. I mean, they're were two available tables that should have been cleaned up and it would only take two minutes to clean up but they didn't! They were busy doing other very menial tasks. 

Finally when we were seated, the waiter took another person's order before us even though we were seated first. We ordered Shanghai thick noodles and the fish flavored pork. 

And then when we finally got our food, the food was lukewarm and got cold quickly within two minutes. It was as if the food was left there for ten minutes until it got served to us.

I totally do not recommend this place as there are so many places in the sunset district that are so much better than this.
author: David N.

description:
Note: If you unfamiliar with the taste of Taiwanese food, you will be sorely disappointed expecting Cantonese taste.

I love Taiwan particularly Shihpen (Taitung County). When I grown up, you will find me here, roaming the surrounding canyon roads on my MV Agusta Brutale 910R or a KTM Superduke R with a base-jumping parachute on my back. Don't care too much for Taipei, Kaosung, or Taichung but I love the Eastern countryside. Among the majestic hills and forest, I felt a calling of home. Up high with low hanging cloud, it seems as if you look down from heaven.

I find the key to this establishment is to order off of the menu via the wall posting. Some of my favorites are Shanghai Noodle, Country Chicken, Country Lamb, and Lion's Head. The dishes are generally flavorful and can be ordered without MSG. Shanghai dumplings' skin is a bit on the thicker side and bigger in size than what I used to. Once upon a time, I had fantastic Shanghai dumplings in Taipei...Mmmmmmmmmmmmm. 

This is one of the better TW restaurants in the Bay Area. Enjoy!!!
author: DAVID N.

description:
Taiwan restaurant reminds me of lunch with my family after church on Sunday. We use to eat here all the time. I love Taiwanese style dim sum, here are my all time favorites:

-Sweet, warm soy milk. Be sure to order a side of fried bread (the long ones) for dipping.
-Onion pancake. Crispy pan fried pancakes made with scallions.
-Steamed pork dumplings. Always freshly, hand made by the window and steamed to order. Yummy with vinegar.
-Pot stickers. Similar to the steamed, but pan fried. Always crispy and full of pork and cabbage.
-Shanghai noodles. Fresh, thick flour noodles stir fried with beef and veggies
-Beef noodle soup. Savory beef broth with slices of beef and spinach and homemade noodles

Now that I think of it, I need to pay them another visit soon.
author: Denise L.

description:
This place has really good taiwanese food. I usually don't get appetizers, but this place has good finger foods. The soy milk (unsweetened) is yummy too. The dishes are tasty, but sometimes too salty. The food is out hot and fresh and orders are at most times promptly taken. Staff is nice and doesn't give you trouble. I would definitely eat there again.

my only complaint is that the chairs are getting old and snags on my clothes sometimes.
author: Cecile S.

description:
mmm... 

Just like I remember it. It's all so good. I'm super excited there's one in SF. All through college this was the singular restaurant my parents would take me to in Berkeley (Taiwan Restaurant on University). Today we stumble upon the SF sister (interior decoration is the same...quality of food is the same).

We of course over order. Steamed dumplings, sweet soybean soup, chinese donuts, boiled dumplings, rice cake and pork stirfry. My god. It's fabulous. Here I was thinking I would have to drive to Berkeley whenever I wanted to remember what good home cooked Chinese food tasted like.

Thank you.
author: Annie T.

description:
Surprise Taiwanese food discovery!  My beloved curry chicken with the fluorescent yellow sauce, and containing naught but chicken and onion.  No green peppers, mushrooms, water chestnuts, bamboo shoots, or other nuggets of anything to clutter it up.

Pork chop on rice (pai gu fan) extremely tasty, missing the brown sauce my friend was seeking but apparently it's prepared in many different styles of which this was one.

Low, low prices!  I am going to go back again and again.

A standout location in the Clemental region.
author: Walter K.

description:
I've gotten food here for probably over 20 years and it still remains a good place to eat.  My favorites are the Shanghai Chow Mein and Xiao Lung Bao..oh yes!  And also the Chow Leen Go..  I know...there's no soup in the xiao lung bao, but I like the gingeriness of it.  This used to also be my go to place for pot stickers which looks the same and probably still as good except that I'd rather have the steamed xiao lung bao instead.  

When I was young, I loved watching them making the chinese doughnuts in the window.
author: J T.

description:
Great cheap place for Taiwanese food.

Xiao Long Bao here are large with thick skin so it's definitely filling.

Minced Pork Rice is fantastic and is a great replacement for plain rice.

Green beans could have been cooked a bit more, but still good.

Someone recommended this place for breakfast, but I haven't been yet.
author: Jason K.

description:
Once i find a great Taiwanese food place... I'm going to move next door. Seriously? No. But i really am on the search for a few great Taiwanese places in the city (Spices already being one of them =). YAY!

I had the pork chop and rice, squid stew, and ba-wan (meatball bowl?) 

It was a nice quick fix but it was overall... ehh... just okay. The pork chop and rice was fried kinda strangely and the meat sauce on the rice was rather lacking. 

The squid stew was lacking quite a few ingredients that would've made it fabulous. 

I thought the ba-wan was pretty decent. 

The service was great! They were super nice and efficient. The food though? I wasn't impressed... but will i go back? Probably! 

Times like this... i miss my Taiwanese mother.
author: Angelinaaah h.

description:
The won ton soup and pork chop soups are pretty good. 
So is the lemon chicken. 
Mu shu pork isn't so great. They serve it with a thicker, pita/tortilla type of wrap.
No atmosphere to speak of.
The service is good.
Overall, Taiwan is an okay place to eat, but with so many other restaurants to dine from,
there's no real urge to return anytime soon
author: chris m.

description:
Can you say the best potstickers in town???

Other than that the food is a bit different ever since they changed owners..it isnt terrible..i still eat here so thats a good sign!

parking sucks by the way..good luck!
author: M W.

description: I was here on a weeknight and it was almost empty. This city is so strange. A couple of blocks down people are lining up to try to get into a restaurant and here is this place with cheaper and more authentic food and it sits empty. Go figure.
author: karabina c.

description:
I actually liked this place.  We ate a restaurant just down the street the night before but I would have to say I thought this place was better.

Thumbs up for the dumplings.  They were freshly made and quite tasty!  Made me think of the jiao zi my grandmother used to make.  YUM!

Yup, I'll come here again if I'm in the area and not eating somewhere else.
author: Juliana T.

description:
Four stars for the sesame cake/bun, everything else get 3 stars.

I crave the Northern Chinese/ traditional Taiwanese breakfast sometimes, but not many places serve it in the city, so I finally stopped here and try it this morning. We got the sweet and savory soy milk, fried donut, sesame bun/cake, and the jiu-tsai-he. 

The sweet soy milk is so good that I ordered 2 more for home. The savory one wasn't so great because they didn't season it, you have to do it yourself. A&J in cupertino village has better savory soy milk. The fried donut is WAY too bready. BUT, BUT, BUT, the sesame cake is REALLY GOOD!! Baked to golden and flaky, great with the fried donut and sweet soymilk. Yum....I miss home.

Will come back and try other "authentic" Taiwanese dishes some other time.
author: Yuchi C.

description:
One of the best deals in town for Chinese/Taiwanese food, and the folks who work here are quite nice.  The ingredients are fresh, little to no MSG, not too oily, and food always comes out fast and hot!   I'm here 2x a month and recommend the following:

Onion Pancake
Shrimp/ Chives Dumpling
Thick Shanghai Fried Noodles
Ma Po Tofu
Crispy Pork Spareribs
Long beans with ground meat
Noodle soup with mustard green

Never get tired... been coming here for years.
author: Hotung T.

description: I love the interior, it is so sparce and odd. Dumplings are delicate and fresh. The huge long dong chinese donut was meh... but everything else was good. I always walked by and was so happy i finally tried.
author: Chelsey G.

description: I came here for my friends 'birthday dinner'  since Burma Super Star was soo crowded and it did not seem like we would get a table. I was hungry so we decided to try go to this place. We had a lot to eat for $15 for 3 people. The service was good too! The lady was really nice, my friend was being all bitchy saying that she was talking in english just because we were ABCs. They were still nice. Lemon Chicken was fantastic!
author: Janet Z.

description:
I really think that bus stop that is covering this gem should be moved a store over. seriously? i would have missed it! 

I love this restaurant...i have total food coma which means that i ate too much...because it was so DELICIOUS! yummy! i love their cha chang myon (bean & meat sauce noodles), sweet and sour shrimp, crispy spare ribs, and the deep fried squid. 

and the best part? LEFTOVERS! 
so if your craving taiwanese food...go here!
author: Suzan L.

description:
I've eaten here a few times when I still lived in SF full time. Food is good, service is just ok.

I never order dumplings or boa here. I don't know why anyone would considering there are far better places that specialize in those dishes not far away in the Richmond district.

The noodles and the soy milk is what I come for. Don Don mien is perhaps my favorite there. Sometimes you just want a big bowl of noodle goodness.

As always, parking sucks but it's Clement, you should've already know that.
author: Jin S.

description:
The pot stickers and Shanghai dumplings are the best!  Freshly made and fried up fairly quickly, one of the best things about this place is the homemade fresh goodies they offer.  A favorite for us for Chinese breakfast, it is inexpensive, delicious and satisfying.  We particularly love the freshly fried Chinese donuts with our sweet soy milk.

Delicious!
author: Betty L.

description:
Dumplings, dumplings, dumplings....that's the best thing about this place!!!  Fresh, steamy, and yummy!!!!

Braised green beans....the second best thing about this place!

Everything else, I think is just, "meh!"  

This is one of the places where ordering your usuals and favorites is not a bad thing.
author: Jenn A.

description:
This place has it all.  Soy milk, noodles of all varieties, and dumplings around the China.  Nothing is overly expensive and everything is tasty.  I still want to go back and get some five spice beef noodle soup, something the Taiwanese know how to make.

Inside is your typical run of the mill Clement restaurant.  At first you walk in you get this interesting smell.  You can't put your finger on it but you know you've smelt it before.  After careful nose analysis, I've concluded that it smells like the perfume that people use to send out wedding invitations but it's been sitting too long and gone stale.
author: Tim L.

description:
Nine of us went to Taiwan Restaurant on Clement Street and 6th Avenue.  We have not been there in the past 2 years.  We got a seat immediately with the restaurant about 70% at capacity.  

The Food
For the price, the food was actually quite good.  We ordered the following items:
