1. Sticky rice in soup with vegetables.  The sticky rice was a bit overcooked and mushy, but the soup base was very tasty. They had a mix of vegetables including napa cabbage, carrots and some bok choy.  

2. Rice noodles with Beef with a beef soup base. The beef was extremely tender where the meat melted in your mouth.  Great dish and one of the first to be finished.  

3. Rice noodle with tofu with clear broth was another great dish with eggs an mixed vegetables.  Soup was great and the mix of tofu with eggs was also very good.  

4.  Shanghai noodles with spinach, pork and shrimp.  This dish was decent with the shrimp and pork being the stars of the dish.  The flavoring was not quite there for me.  May have needed a bit more soy sauce.  

5. Fried bread and sweet soy milk.  Add your own sugar so that you control how sweet you wanted the milk.  Kids loved it.  The bread did not go as quickly though, but looked good (like a donut).  

6.  Potstickers were nice and large, and above all, tasty.  

7. Shanghai dumplings (siu lung bau) was juicy inside and tasty too.  Both the last dishes takes awhile to cook so came at the end.  

Overall, the food was good but can be considered great based on the price.  For $48 (after tip) we easily fed nine hungry folks - five kids.  

Would definitely go back and order similar items in the near future.
author: J Z.

description:
Quick service. 

When we came in, we were quickly seated. The pot of tea was coming shortly. After ordering, bowls of hot & sour soup were coming our way. I ordered the general tsuo's chicken. It's very good and I had ordered it the last time I came here. Good portions of rice & chicken. I think I should try something else on the menu the next time I go back.

The lunch menu is quiet cheap! $4-6 for soup, fruit, and choice of entree!

**6/25/2008
I had the asparagus with chicken and it was absolutely delicious!!
author: Jay Z.

description:
Taiwan Restaurant is my favorite place to eat in SF.

The food is VERY affordable with generous portions and tastes awesome. Though, I'm sure the MSG will kill us all sooner than we'd like.

Must have dishes are Bean and Meat Sauce Noodles, Szechuan Hot Sauce Noodles (the vegetarian one is just as good, they just don't put pork), and Fish-flavored Egg Plant.

The only thing I would stay away from at this place is the lamb. The beef variants are fine. It's just that the lamb at this place never seems right.

As a kid I always enjoyed watching the sous chefs prepare the dumplings in the front of the restaurant. Really nice touch to show everyone that the food is freshly made.
author: Jason T.

description: never found a place that does the Taiwan country favorite ribs like this place. yummy squared! the deep fried doughy thingies (ngow lay so) that they fry up in the front display kitchen are slightly sweet and tasty as well. funniest thing about this Taiwan restaurant is all the Cantonese spoken here by staff and customers alike. i guess I need to go to the South Bay to hear Mandarin spoken in a Chinese restaurant!
author: Jeff W.

description: Nothing we ordered was very good. I wouldn't come back -- it's sub par Taiwanese food. I had the "peddler" noodle aka rice noodle soup with ground pork, beansprouts  and boiled egg. I've definitely had better such as the one at Tainan in Cupertino Village. My lovely dining companion had the braised beef noodle soup. Again, it was not very good -- the broth was not spicy and the noodles were not homemade or tasty. We also tried the green onion pancakes which were deep fried. Why would you deep fry the green onion pancake?
author: Helen Y.

description:
The place looks like a typical run-down Chinese restaurant with tacky pink paint color and dim lighting.  I think they tried to make it classy with a dirty sunlight, but i wasn't fooled.  Never go to a restaurant starving, because we ordered a feast for 8.

**HOT SWEET BEAN MILK -- had to add sugar yourself. tasted just like soy milk. nothing impressive.
**CHINESE STYLE DONUTS [yow teew] -- best i have ever had!!!!!!!! i even ordered one to go. it was light and crispy and not too oily.  The only downside is that the place did not serve congee to eat it with.
**CHINESE GREEN ONION PANCAKE -- not impressed.  Felt like i could buy a frozen bag of Chinese pancakes and open up a restaurant myself.
**MONGOLIAN BEEF -- surprisingly, one of the fave dishes out of everything. flavorful and not too spicy.
**TAIWAN COUNTRY FAVORITE SPARERIBS -- sweet and tangy. fried a little too much, it was a little hard to bite into.  strong taste of basil with it. 
**DUMPLINGS -- decent. enough said.
**STEAMED PORK BUNS -- decent. the stuffing inside had a taro texture to it.
**SHRIMP CHOW FUN -- a dish that can probably be ordered in any chinese restaurant. good but probably not the restaurant's specialty.


probably won't be a repeat customer for anything but the CHINESE STYLE DONUTS.  

and guess what, we ordered so much that it became my thanksgiving dinner.  why do the food gods hate me so?!
author: Bernice C.

description: The best eggplants hands down! I love this place.  It's cheap, fast and it tastes great!
author: Kevin L.

description:
I've been craving some Shanghai dumplings and this is the place to go to.  I  went here this morning and had myself some sweet soy bean milk, it sure hit the spot with the morning chill n all.  Also had the Shanghai noodle and a side of green onion pancake too.  It was a delicious brunch.  

When the bill came, we were surprised how cheap it was.  Now how can you beat that?!
author: hello k.

description: Food was OK not too exciting.  Service was poor.  Hate it when waiters bring dishes to the table before clearing the table for an open spot.  They just stand there and look and wait for you to make room for the next dish.  Honestly felt like I earned a share of the tips.
author: willie w.

description:
I love the food here. It is great, from the pot stickers to those oily bread things Yauw Ja Gwuy. The noodles are even better, Dahm Dahm Mean, it's so good. I also love the dumplings. I love everything about this place. It's still so good, and I always remembered it from childhood. Sadly I am no longer nearby this neighborhood that often, and I miss it sometimes between Spices and all the stores.

Update:
I no longer miss this place. The last time I was here, I found plastic in my dam dam mein. PLASTIC! Unwrap the damn thing before you serve it!
author: Michael C.

description:
Would be one star if their you tiao (chinese donuts?) and scallion pancakes weren't so damn crispy and addictive!  

Seriously, that was a really gross meal.  There was this noodle dish that was just chicken broth thickened with a lot of corn starch, a shit load of white pepper, and dried noodles that was probably supposed to soften in the soup.  Gross.

Inflation sucks a lot because the Chinese donuts used to be $.75 back in the day.  I think its over $1.25 now.  :(  I love that oily goodness with my congee!
author: Anna T.

description:
Total yummers!!!  Went there today with my girl, Nichole, and we had a delicious Friday lunch!

Try their Chinese donut w/ sweet soy bean milk, boiled dumplings and salty sticky rice!
author: Keika L.

description:
I really wanted to be impressed. Really. My boyfriend had been wanting to go here for a long time so we finally tried it out. The menu looked good, but the only think I ended up enjoying was the steamed rice! We ordered pork soup (I think it's a specialty of the house), sizzling beef, and baby squids. Everything was so salty it actually burned my mouth! And the baby squids were waaaayyyy over garlicy (even for someone like me who cooks everything with a couple cloves of garlic!). We meant to ask them to cook everything with no MSG and low salt but forgot. So I partially feel that the meal could have been better had we asked. That being said, the fact that you have to ask for things to not be loaded down with salt is an issue for me in itself. 

With all of the great places to try, I will definitely NOT be going back. Sorry, Taiwan. I really did want it to be good...:-(
author: Amy B.

description: This is one of the few restaurants that is open late (10:30pm), cheap, but not cheap enough to sell chicken feet an pig intestines (see D&A cafe). I ordered the typical chinese favorites--potstickers ($4) and green onion pancake. ($3) Turned out to be way too much food! It was a warm, yummy, oily meal. Just what I wanted. I think of it as my local american-chinese joint with a much better selection. I'm sure I'll be back at night to try the Taiwanese noodles.
author: Rahil P.

description:
Mmmmm, just like a home cooked meal at home in Taiwan. 

It's a little on the saltier side, but all good and authentic and can't beat the prices.
author: lily l.

description:
wide range of food selection. the food here is very close to what i used to have in taiwan so you can trust that it's really authentic taiwanese. 

the place smells a little bit (perhaps of mold) because the interior looks dated. The tables also don't look very clean but the cutlery look clean.
author: J P.

description:
Pretty good/authentic Taiwanese food. Get the fried onion pancake, steamed soup dumplings, and any of their fried noodle dishes. Food here is on the oily side, but hey, that's Taiwan for you.

Other things we tried:
-Sweet/sour soup: pretty good
-Sauteed green beans: get this

It's kind of your typical hole in the wall. The best part about it: a rope that's tied to the handle of the front door to the roof of the overhang. Guess they have a problem with the door sticking? Lol. Can't get anymore ghetto than that. Again, that's Taiwan for you.

The staff is courteous, fast, and friendly. And don't forget your (unwrapped) fortune cookie at the end of the meal ;)
author: Yee-Shing W.

description: I went here on a Monday afternoon around 2pm with fellow yelper, jason g. The place was not busy at all, it looked like there was only one waitress that waited the entire restaurant and there were only a couple of customers, so our orders were promptly taken and our orders came out quickly. We ordered fried pork chop over steamed rice with preserved veggie's, a dish that resembled general chicken but was sliced beef battered with a tangy dark sauce and chicken dumplings. I think we ordered too much meat, we should've ordered a vegi dish. The pork chop was good, it was lightly fried. Although I would probably choose the salt and pepper pork chops over that, like the ones they have in Chinese restaurants. The beef dish was just okay, it was an American-Taiwan dish I guess. As for the steam dumpings... aren't they supposed to be really juicy inside? Or am I just comparing this Taiwanese restaurant to other Chinese/dim sum restaurants? =/
author: Vinkin Ken T.

description:
I finally tried the beef noodles (hold the beef) and it was a nice broth however it was too plain.  It was noodles, broth, and vegies.  It lacked: green onions, pickled mustard, bits and pieces of fat.  But the flavor of the broth was nice.  I think if you order the beef noodles WITH beef, it would taste better.  I did ask for a side of pickled mustard - very delish, kinda sweet.  $6.25.

Also had an order of steamed vegie potstickers.  It was ok, but with a very obvious Chinese vegetarian smell and taste of fungus.  I'd skip this next time.  $4.

While the food is ok la, I like the female server who served me both times.  She's middle aged but smiley and doesn't ignore you.  

I'd come back to grab a bite whenever I'm in the area.
author: Mrs F.

description:
Clement is a center for Chinese people, so I figured to find some good Chinese food here. The other giveaway: we walked in and EVERYONE was speaking Chinese. Now, I thought, this place must have good authentic Chinese food!

The menus were in both Chineses and English, so there shouldn't be too much trouble for English-only speakers. Besides, I can't read Chinese anyway.

Service was nice and quick.  The place was very well lit and clean. The skylights really helped make the place very welcoming.

The food wasn't too oily, which I really appreciated.  While I can't read Chinese, I know most of the Chinese dishes by their Chinese names only.  So I would like to recommend a dish or two, except I don't know their English names.

If you want Chinese food and not that frilly "fusion" crap or Chinese-food-made-for-Americans like Panda Express, this place should be a top choice.
author: Robert L.

description:
Drove by this place almost a year ago and vowed that I would try it out. Hell, a place that calls itself Taiwan Restaurant (that's the name in Chinese too) is either full of itself or the real deal.

Was finally back in the area today and stopped by for lunch/brunch. I was just about drooling after a quick glance through the window - lots of fried Taiwanese goodies. My friend and I got the oyster pancake (o-ah jian), the shredded turnip cakes (luo bo si bing), the pork chop rice (pai gu fan), the bean & meat sauce noodles (zha jiang mian) and the soymilk (dou jiang)

The oyster pancake was pretty good, though a little light on the oysters. The shredded turnip cakes probably would have been really good, except they were already cold by the time they hit our table. The pork chop rice was fairly good, but the pork chop itself was a little too sweet. The zha jiang mian was probably the best dish, as it was a good representation of Taiwanese style zha jiang mian (lighter in color and with a higher water content that Shangdong style and Korean style zha jiang mian). The dou jiang was also pretty good, and I liked being able to sweeten it to taste.

Overall, pretty good Taiwanese fare though we did hit upon a few duds. Still, there looks to be enough depth in their menu to try again.
author: Albert C.

description: Reliable Taiwanese comfort food.  I like the steamed chicken dumplings, rice petals with por and pickled cabbage and the donuts.  Perfect place to visit on a rainy day in the city.  Not super well heated though so when it's really cold our, its also chilly inside.
author: Debra M.

description:
This was a delicious surprise. We rolled in, my food cohort and I, late on a Friday night looking for some post-movie grub. The service instantaneous and good throughout, perhaps because it was 10pm and we were the next-to-last people in there?  

I'm an onion cake kind of guy. Especially when they're the thick, pancakey kind... not those wafer-thin crisps. And these were good. $2.75 for two of them, which are cut into fours and could easily make a meal in and of themselves.

Also had the velvet chicken. Sauteed with snow peas and a wine sauce. Didn't get much wine out of it, but it felt pretty healthy. Because hey, I didn't have a massive coronary after grubbing down the fried onion cakes, which by rights I probably should have had.

I'd like to go back and see what else they've got going for 'em. The menu was frickin' huge and said "Fowl" for the chicken dishes.  Heh heh... fowl... how I love you and your egg brethren... but lets work on the name... still, you've got a good thing going on...
author: Rob W.

description:
I was invited to this dive by relatives so this got my hopes up. The service was decent for a typical Chinese restaurant. The natives were friendly! The place itself is clean and appears relatively well maintained. 
Now for the food, gulp! Their oyster pancake was underwhelming and so were the steamed dumplings. Not bad but not the "I've got to shout it out at the top of the mountain" variety, you know. They had not so crispy chicken which the kids liked, a vegetable delight that was undelightfully bland and a spare rib that had this artificial reddish hue which made me think twice about biting down on it. I did anyway against my better judgement. Ooooh! It tastes like orange chicken! 
The one really pleasant surprise was the bill. We had at least 10 dishes for 10 people. OK, more like 8.5 including three kids. Total cost? Less than $100! Not bad if all you want is to feed a gang of hungry peeps who you aren't trying to impress! If I'm flat broke and on a cheap date, this will be on my shortlist. Otherwise, keep on walking down Clement.
author: Eric T.

description: Yum!  I love their nian gao (sorta like chow fun but better!  Very chewy) and green onion pancake.  That's what I always order if I'm in the neighborhood!
author: Wendy H.

description:
One of my two favourite places to eat.
Their broccoli is the best you can get anywhere.  
Their chinese donuts are fabulous, and are very similar to the ones I regularly consumed while in China (unlike those sold most places in the city).  
The service is always incredibly fast, and they're so pleasant and nice!
They've come to recognise me and my family, occasionally giving us free extras, because we go there so often.  Which is really saying something, since we live over an hour away.

Wonderful place.  Did I mention how cheap their lunch menu is?  Generally $3.99 or so...
author: Leila-Anne C.

description:
The fried dough sticks and "beef tongue pastry" (sweet version of the former, don't take the name literally) are typical breakfast items from Canton. They are comfort food, especially when you get to dip them in warm soy milk. For this experience, I would keeping coming back to Taiwan Restaurant. 

One minor criticism: The fried items they make tend to be overly dense. If only they would make the dough lighter and more airy, I would give extra stars.

PS I think the beef tongue pastry is only available on weekends.
author: Mark C.

description:
Used to come here once in a while as a child.  When they first opened, it was a really popular restaurant but I think they've certainly lost a bit of their luster.  I really liked it then cause it was different and modern at that time.  But the place looks rundown now as compared to before.  

So I did make a return visit recently and they were okay.  Not super but a place I wouldn't mind coming to once in a while.  It seemed like the prices were pretty fair.  I was expecting their dishes to cost more.  

I always look forward to eating dumplings so when I am in the mood again, see you soon Taiwan.......
author: Mark W.

description: This restaurant could be easily overlooked, because it is small and rather nondescript, but that would be a HUGE mistake. The prices are unbelievably low and the menu is interesting. Especially notable are the noodle dishes and the fresh soy milk. The sizzling rice soup is also a winner. I like the $3-4 noodle dish that has the thousand year old egg in it when I just want a little gnosh after having cocktails or shopping.
author: Revive M.

description:
Everything was a bit too doughy for my taste...the "cow-tongue" crispy bread, the Shanghai thick noodles (which was a hybrid of flat noodles...strange), green onion pancake, and the skin of the xiao long bao (steamed dumplings) & potstickers. just everything...doughy! If it wasn't for the tea or the soy bean milk, i'd probably have a hard time stuffing all that food down my throat.

There are a few commendable dishes...like the soy bean milk & chinese donut, fried spareribs, the "three-cup" chicken and some of the other noodle soups. 

I come here sometimes when I'm craving taiwanese food and don't want to go far. The prices are reasonable for what it is. On weekends, you might have to wait a bit before getting seated.
author: Jeremy F.

description:
Order carefully. Not everything is great here, but there are some really great standards that keep people coming back. Good clue to know if you are ordering correctly, look at the table next to you. There's a lot of regulars at this restaurant and they know what's good. Not everything on the menu is great, but once you've gone enough times you will find your favorites.

I'm a sucker for this restaurant. I know it's not anything compared to what you'd find outside of San Francisco, but it's grown on me and I love coming here for steamed vegetarian dumplings, Schezuan spicy noodles, tofu and mustard greens, Taiwan special deep-fried tofu, dry braised green beans, sizzling rice soup.

This place is super cheap, has good food, and has an extensive menu with your normal and not so normal (see "stuffed baby squids") Chinese food. 

They are known for the dumplings. They make them in the window. I've heard their Xiao Long Bao are not so good, but I really like their vegetarian steamed dumplings.

Most of what you see in the window is on a small dim sum menu. Look in the bottom right corner of your menu to find it. It's on one of the folds.
author: Timothy P.

description:
I been to this place twice and still do not like it. The first time I came here with my friends from NY and we thought the food was below par and even though I forgot what we ordered, all I know was it is not authentic.

Recently, I came back for lunch with another set of friends. The only thing that stood out was the shao long bao (which by the way still does not stack up to Joe's Shanghai in NY). The scallion pancake was thick and similar consistency to american pancake and too fried/crispy. We got the meat sauce noodle which tasted like shanghai fried noodles (we agreed that Spices makes a more authentic dish). 

The potstickers were ehhh. When I discover this place serves oyster noodle, I was excited but was sorely disappointed when it came out. The oysters were superbig that none of my friends wanted to try it. After one bowl of it, I gave up. 

My question is this, why do they call it Taiwan restaruant when nothing here is served like Taiwan??? Last I checked when I went back to Taiwan, none of the dishes tasted this weird!!! Or is this what everyone calls FUSION??? Maybe I was under the impression of false advertisement or ordered the wrong dishes, but seriously now, coming from someone who does speak chinese and have tasted authentic Taiwanese food, I would not recommend this place.

*Also, cheap does NOT mean good! There are plenty of other places in SF that is cheap and is WAY better*
author: Sophie C.
Sandy Y.

description:
Came here for brunch.  The menu is basically the same as the one in Berkeley (yay), but the food is a little different.

Examples:
- cold jellyfish was tossed with a vegetable and had a lot of liquid
- sesame paste noodles came with cooked spinach and some chopped peanuts instead of raw cucumber, but was just as good
- pot sticker filling not as flavorful

This place is cleaner, smaller, and has friendlier service, but I prefer the food in Berkeley.  But maybe I just need to come here a few more times to have my mind changed.
author: Amy N.

description:
I come here whenever I want a potsticker fix!  My family and I used to frequent here just about every other weekend (my brother loves LOVES potstickers!).  These days I go back for the green onion pancakes, steamed dumplings, potstickers, "chow neen goh", and soy bean milk.

Altho the decor can use some revamping, this is still the place the go for some northern style dim sum in the Richmond District.
author: elaine i.

description:
As read above this place is awesome and such a good bargin.

I personally recomend going to eat here for breakfast . The dim sum served here at breakfast is one of my all time favorites. 

When you go , order the green onion pan cakes, the sizling rice soup and the chinese doughnut. 

You wont be dissapointed.
author: Benji C.

description:
This is a great family style, relaxed and cheap Chinese restaurant. Pork with mustard greens, crispy prawns, sizzling rice soup, red eggplant and pot stickers are all excellent and can be ordered with no msg and low salt- something which I heartily recommend. 

After years of great meals here, it's a must stop with guests from out-of-town, especially with kids. 

The only downside is the bathroom, which would not suffer from more frequent cleanings.
author: Eric F.

description:
Delicious, cheap, big portions, decent service. Nothing bad to say about the Taiwan. Make sure to order at least of one of the following (or get 3/4 people and get it all):

hot n' sour soup
dry braised string beans (how can string beans be so good?)
pork dumplings (the little kind)
green onion pancake (one of the only worthwhile I've ever had)
shanghai noodles
author: Sophie S.

description:
Taiwanese breakfast!  Yummy!  I come here for that exclusively when I'm craving those chinese donuts with a bowl of warm soy milk or a bowl of their sweet soft tofu.  The staff here are friendly and service is quite prompt.

You can see that they make the chinese donuts on site and they're fresh and pipping hot.  They also have great scallion pancakes, so anything dough based  that they make from scratch has been top-notch.

I'm not a complete fan of their lunches.  I've had three noodle bowls and have not been extremely impressed.  But, you can't really argue with the price.
author: Mei C.

description:
When I am extremely hung over, like the alcohol is literally seeping out of my pores hungover, I make a bee-line for this joint. 

Something about the combination of the steamed pork dumplings, Beef ala ShangTung and Wok Fried Bok choy Hearts with extra garlic and I am saved. Released from the hell I have self induced and free to roam the streets again in all my glory
author: Ham and Eggs M.

description:
Very casual, but nice restaurant that is (almost) a break from the monotony of Thai and Cantonese style restaurants on Clement street.

I like the pig's ear's or tripe in sauce, my Shanghainese company thought it was a little wrong. Whether it was actually wrong or a difference in preferred tastes I don't know.

But I do LOVE their meat buns!
author: Michael H.

description: Can't find a Taiwanese restaurant? Well, this spot might be ok for people to try. I've eaten here a few times here and there but I was craving some pork chop noodle soup. They make it pretty good here so until I find another place to fulfill my craving, i recommend trying this place out. It has been there for years and years so its gotta be pretty decent. Oh yea, their food is on the salty side but I've discovered thats the trend to a lot of Taiwanese food.
author: Gordon L.

description: Was here on Friday night.  The food's affordable and delicious. Great for impromptu dinner dates.
author: Marcus M.

description:
you are disgracing Taiwan...
please change your name...
you dont even have much Taiwanese food on your menu!!!!

now I miss Taiwan even more...the food just isnt the same T_T
author: phillip w.

description:
This is a great restaurant. I've been coming here since I was a kid and the food has stayed pretty consistent. Their shanghai stir fried noodles or whatever are OK, but the rice stick things are awesome. All the noodle soups here are really good too. Noodles taste like their home made but their sauces are a bit salty. Overall this is probably my favorite taiwan/shanghai style restaurant in the city. 
Great food, large portions, and cheap.
author: Ale x.

description:
3.5 stars.  I'm still full. It's been 2 hours already from our meal, but I still have to move slowly as I roll home. We didn't realize we had over-ordered until the plates were served. The portions here are HUGE. I liked the pork and cabbage dumplings. The lady said that they were soup dumplings. Although  shaped like them, but they actually weren't very soupy, but delicious nonetheless. Also, the salty soy soup is awesome. 
Overall, the service was great - very friendly.
author: GS M.

description:
I always get a bowl of soy milk, chinese donut, rice cake w/ pickled vegetables and pork, onion pancake, and dumplings. 

Maybe next time I'll get some noodles.  The restaurant isn't a looker, but I can look past that since the food makes my tummy happy.  All in all, I'm never disappointed.
author: Jeanne L.

description:
Okay I'll admit I've only ever had five dishes from here, but I LOVE everyone (and I get stuck in a dishes I love rut with asian food but thats my choice and don't disregard my review because of it).

Their General Tsou's Chicken is divine.  Not goopy sweet or ridiculously spicey like most places.  That perfect balance of sweet and spicey and perfect with plain white rice.  

Their Shrimp and Snow Peas is also amazing.  Simple, light but super flavorful.  This girl loves her snow peas and devours every one.  

I've also had the potstickers and pork fried rice, good staples that you can't go wrong with.  The potstickers have a nice firm skin and aren't a soggy mess and the pork fried rice is light and not greasy like a lot of places.
author: Dawn L.

description: I wish this place was good cuz Taiwanese food in SF is terrible.  All the Taiwanese people are in South Bay with all the good Taiwanese restaurants.  Supposedly.  Stick to the dirty canto food in SF.
author: Fatty A.

description: I've been here in the past and had really good memories of this place, but my recent visit has been disappointing. The (shao long bao) dumplings were not as delicate and just very bready. The beans were old and the dish was returned. But the onion pancakes were good. The service was good, they were nice about returning the dish but as far as the food quality, i know it could be better.
author: Michelle C.

description: For cheap and delicious food you must go here.  Their dumplings are freshly made to order are oh so juicy.  $4 for 6 big dumplings = best deal!  I also love the noodle with black beans and meat sauce.  This is my best cheap finding so far.
author: Mai-Tam N.

description: Inexpensive and tasty chinese-style food. We went to get dim sum at night, and ended up with vegi potstickers, eggplant and shrimp chow mein. The eggplant was awesome - potstickers average and chow mein greasy and tasty! Plus, bill for two was less than $25!
author: Kai C.

description:
One of my favorite small Chinese food spots (see also San Tung). (Though, in this case it would be Republic of Chinese food.) I've travelled to Taiwan a bunch and gone to a famous spot for dumplings in Taipei. The dumplings here are on par.

The other thing not to miss is the spicy prawns. These critters come lightly battered, fried cripsy, with lots of garlic. I almost always get 2 orders. Also check out the dried braised green beans ... crackin'!

Service is good (and quick), too.
author: C. A. S.

description:
Went there for a hearty dinner before finals. We ordered xiao long bao, black bean noodles and long beans with shrimps lunch plate (yes, the waiter told us lunch plate is still available)

The waiters there were very friendly and patient with us. They have an extensive menu and it took us a while before order. We wanted to order one of their sizzling plate but the waiter was honest enough to tell us that it's only so-so. Anyhoo... food came and portion is big. The black bean noodles were alright. I expected it to have more sauce and to be honest, i like the one in Shang-Dong better. Their noodles are more flavorful and has more sauce. Long beans with shrimp is a complete disappointment :( The waiter took the wrong order and thought I ordered long beans with rice (without the shrimp). And the long beans were obviously left-over. They weren't only warm.. and very salty. We told them not to put MSG (there's such option on the menu), but couldn't really tell if they really did as ordered. Xiao long bao was okay. It's freshly steamed but unfortunately, not juicy inside. The skin was also too thick. And, they only have the white vinegar, instead of the more traditional black vinegar used as the sauce.

Service was good, portion is big and price is reasonable. But food-wise, it's only ok. There are better chinese place nearby.
author: Doris H.

description: the 4 stars are  for Tainan noodle soup, the sweet soy milk, the Taiwan friend rice noodle~
author: Susan H.

description: they serve the best dry fried string beans in the city, and i mean it. come for brunch and order some soy milk with a chinese donut. come for lunch and get yourself a piping hot bowl of beef noodles. come for dinner and order some string beans with spareribs. sprinkle in some dumplings and pot stickers along the way. there, i just helped you with a day's worth of meal planning. you're welcome.
author: Melissa Y.

description:
taiwan my ass. there's nothing remotely taiwan about this place and its cuisine. even lowly moi can teach these people a few things about some good taiwanese street/alley food. 

well hell, i think i shall:

oh-ah jian (taiwanese oyster omelette)

4-5 farm fresh, cage free and organic large eggs
3 green romaine lettuce leaves, washed and chopped into strips
one jar of small pacific oysters, should be no bigger than half a finger's length
cornstarch or potato starch dissolved in water
salt and ground white pepper

sauce (any sweet and sour sauce variation, but this is one i use sometimes): 5 tablespoons of light plum sauce, 2 tablespoons of ketchup, 2 tablespoons of sugar, rice wine vinegar to taste and a little of the cornstarch water (heat ingredients in saucepan with some extra water, stirring constantly to smooth sauce, and remove any solid matter at end)

beat eggs with salt and pepper. heat frying pan with some oil on medium heat. drain oysters (do not rinse), mix with cornstarch water and place in frying pan with lettuce. immediately add egg to mixture and evenly distribute oysters throughout the omelette. turn heat down to medium low, flip once. once eggs are set (should look more like a frittata), pour plum sauce on top of omelette and serve.

(for a variation: chao-jiu style oyster omelettes have chives instead of lettuce. chao jiu is a small region in china's guangdong province)
author: May T.

description: Taiwan on Clement is a great place to go when you're starving--the food arrives super quick.  It's cheap, with lots of vegetarian eats and dim sum treats.  And the service was pleasant and accommodating.  It's reinforcement that, at Chinese restaurants, good food and service don't have to be exclusive from one another.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
this is me when i eat here with my mom and sister:

mom: "so what do you guys want?"
sister: "uhhh i don't care...."
me: "WE ARE EATING SHANGHAI NOODLES, THE SOUP NOODLES WITH PORK AND PRESERVED VEGGIES AND XIAO LONG BAO AND THAT'S IT!!"
mom: "did you want chinese doughnuts and milk?"
me: note that my answer will vary if my brother is with us. if he is, then it is a YES and if not, NO because they're generally too greasy for me. 

luckily my mom puts up with my selfish ways and lets me order the same 3 things every time we come here. what can i say, it reminds me of my grandma taking us to lunch here every once in a while when she was still alive. she introduced me to this style of food and i wish she was still around so i could eat dumplings (and her homemade wontons) with her all day.
author: Melanie C.

description: I've been going to this place ever since I was a kid.  The sweet soy milk and taiwanese bread rolls are always good.  I also like their egg with oysters and the taiwanese spare ribs.  The food is a bit greasy and filling so expect left overs.
author: JACOB L.

description:
had a lovely xmas eve dinner here with two of my favorite gents.

really, what more can you ask for? prompt service, succulent dumplings, delicious sizzling beef platter, excellent kung pao chicken and mu shu to die for!

the place is pretty no frills but offers up excellent food at cheeeeeap prices
author: Brooke M.

description:
The politics and resultant Chinese culture of Taiwan expressed in food...mmm...edutasty!

Just like the polyglot and frequently conflicting flavors of Taiwan's multiple waves of Chinese colonizers, settlers, and refugees, Taiwan Restaurant's menu is a Lazy Susan menagerie of its cuisines' best picks...or at least a very, very close approximation of what those picks can taste like, by using locally available ingredients and importable exotics.  You may not get the full "authenticity" of Northern Chinese fare like the shrimp and leek dumplings that you may get at San Tung Chinese Restaurant No. 2 (www.yelp.com/biz/M0JTO3oyu6gxh1mfFjU-dA), nor the defunct Happy Family Restaurant formerly at Geary and 2nd Ave. (God! I miss them so much!), but you can have fried rice flour-noodles with your steamed mini pork dumplings.  Meaning that you can have a traditionally Fujianese, Southern and coastal dish (rice flour noodles) with a traditionally Northern, Santung staple (the wheat flour bun) at the same table for the same meal in the same restaurant.  I know, I know, this distinction is like...wow, they have Neopolitan AND Sicilian pizza here!  Well, it's Chinese cosmopolitan, not just Cantonese.  I just wish they had more "crazy" sounding stuff...like that Hakka dish where salt-cured moldy mustard greens are stewed with ham hocks, or go trendy with stinky tofu.  Are you salivating yet?
author: Bruce L.

description: 7:30 Thursday night we dropped in and there were 3 tables open.  The place was generally packed.  Good service, good food.  The menu had a tofu section and a vegetarian section, but best of all it had dishes from all parts of China.  The menu explains that Taiwan has eclectic Chinese cuisine.  We chose the Taiwan dinner for two, which included black bean chicken, and prawns & peas.  It appeared to be Cantonese style, you know the sauces.  Short wait for the table, short wait for the food, short wait for the check.  A solid place to go.
author: David D.

description: The best kept secret of Clement.  Homemade dumplings AND "destination" Taiwan country spare ribs.  Their food is consistent, cheap, and DELICIOUS.  I probably go here weekly I love it so much.
author: Mariss D.

description: Not only will you be in total disbelief how incredibly tasty the various dishes are here (not to mention how  wonderful the aromas are) ... you won't believe how affordable it is... I just hope the place stays a Clement secret gem...just so the quality stays the same.  I'm vegetarian, but I've dined here many times with carnivore friends and their choices were even a little tempting just because of the amazing aromas rising from them.  Try it... you won't be disappointed.  Oh, it can be quite busy midday...but still worth the wait!
author: Grrrl W.

description: Good family style food at great prices!
author: Jared F.

description: This place is great.  Good food and very cheap.  Every dish was good.  I really enjopyed the Mongolian Beef, Fried Tofu, Sizzling Rice soup and dumplings were great.  I will definetely come back and the pricing is amazing.
author: Harry E.

description: I had dinner with my friends a while back. I ordered the fat noodles or something like that. I was pretty good. I was quite surprised at the size of the noodles though. We also ordered the onion pancakes which were yummy. I also had the sweet soybean drink but they forgot to give me it. If this happened on my bad days, they would only get 2 stars but I had a good day so 3 it is. The food is cheap tho.
author: Audrey M.

description:
this restaurant is a disgrace to taiwanese. 
being a true taiwanese, i've always searched for the best food that i can find in bay area. i gave this place a try and all i can say is *nothing*... (shakes Head)

how do they dare to even put TAIWAN in the name of the restaurant.. 
for the most part, i believe that other wannabe restaurants that served the slightest fake so called taiwanese food can do better then this.

the last time and only time i tried this place was years ago. i know for sure that no matter what i do, i'll never go back to this place. even if people say that this is the oldest taiwanese restaurant in san francisco.
author: Eric Y.

description: Homestyle chinese/taiwanese food at super low prices!  Great shrimp/leek dumplings, yeow tiaw (a.k.a. "fried chinese doughnut," although a little dough-y), and noodles.
author: Mitzi C.

description: This place is absolutely the BEST freaking Chinese type food in San Francisco... The vegetarian steamed dumplings are amazing, as are the spicy prawns, the brazed green beans, and the sizzling rice soup. I could go on and on and on, but I'll spare you. The atmosphere is plain, and is often filled to the max with people But it's great food. And prices are great.
author: Lindsey S.

description:
I've been a regular at this restaurant for over 12 years and I've seen a slight decline over the same time - service and cleanliness.  But, here's the bright spot, the food is pretty consistent; albiet consistently greasy and delicious.  Here are my high's and low's....

HIGHS:

- The service is TOOO fast and can sometimes be taken as pressure to eat quickly and leave.  But I like it because I'm only looking for a quick meal and I would rather not wait around here for very long.
- The food is prepared VERY quickly and some of it right before your very eyes.  When you enter, there is a little chef bay to one side (separated by glass) where their dumplings, chinese doughnuts, potstickers, and other doughy creations are hand made.  At least this station, up in the public eye, is kept relatively clean and you can witness the necessary skill to prepare your food.
- MOST of their dishes are authentic and well cooked.  You will get generous portions for the price you pay - which is laughingly only very little, considering that this is San Francisco.

LOWS:

- This place would be shut down for sanitary reasons if the health dept guy wasn't a family friend.  They really do need to clean the dining area better.  I don't think their back kitchen is any dirtier than your typical Chinese restaurant, so I won't complain about that.  I agree that the bathrooms should be overhauled at least once soon.
- The same generous portions are usually served swimming in oil/grease.  But hey, sometimes I actually like the additional lubrication!!  When/if you order the pan-fried rice cakes, you'll understand why (and for gawd's sakes, get it done dry - not too saucy).
- I've noticed that the waitstaff are not that friendly to white customers.  I walk in, speak Cantonese, and they're still not that friendly, but at least I get what I want (most of them speak Mandarin).  Most of the staff do not understand English - which generally means lower quality service, but more authentic food.  You be the judge?
- Don't wander too far off the core of the menu (it's like ordering pizza at a BBQ restaurant).  Even though the namesake is Taiwan, some of the more authentic dishes are NOT well prepared and shouldn't even be on the menu.  A prime example is their oyster noodles AKA "o wa mee swa" or "euh ah mi swa".  This, even as it is served, is a pathetic bowl of colorless broth, NO OYSTERS, NO FLAVOR, crappy FAT noodles (I don't need to go on).
- DO order what most people at the next table order and what they're well-known for:  potstickers, soup/fried noodles, chinese doughnuts, onion pancakes, steamed dumplings, and sweet/salty soybean milk.
- I don't order their rice dishes simply for the reason that there are better places that specialize in it.  OK, the prices are cheap and you might enjoy them, so do what makes you happy - it's all good.

And lastly, I hope they never change the pink paint outside.  It's not very good looking, but SO EASY to spot.  There is also a Taiwan restaurant in Berkeley on University, but I haven't been to that one in over 10 years.  I prefer this SF location because of their specialties.  I used to eat dinner at the Berkeley place because it was $4.95/dish and it was VERY good for the price when I was in college.
author: Alex J.

description: Try the vegetarian pot stickers and the Taiwan thick noodles.  This has been one of my favorite restaurants in the world since I was born here in 1983.
author: Kate J.

description: I recently ate here with a couple of my friends and I was pleased by how CLEAN the place appeared. I was seated quickly and the staff was pretty friendly. We ate the pork buns, fresh steamed vegetables, "spring rolls", lemon chicken, and a few other dishes. I thought the pork buns were delicious, but I was unimpressed with the "spring rolls". I was expecting uncooked and NOT deep fried. Basically, what came out were some egg rolls. Im typically pretty health conscious, so I stayed away from those. I thought the vegetables were cooked well and the lemon chicken was tasty, although I did not feel like anything was worth writing home about. I may eat there again someday.
author: Joelle B.

description: I ended up here with friends after failing to get into Ella's for brunch and was much happier than we would have been, not even factoring the crowd and wait at Ella's.  Lots of noodles in the noodle bowls, good prices, the stuff written in Chinese on the walls is translated too, and excellent fried dough sticks.  Okay soy milk -- the salty kind could have had more flavor.  But I thought it was did a good job presenting Taiwanese food.
author: Leo C.

description: Although I'm not a fan of things mandrin, I do love the noodle dishes here.  I'm a huge fan of the pork and pickled vegetable soup noodles, not sure if that is their english name.  Service has always been quick and friendly.  I have tried dishes that were below average but if you stick to the noodles and their specialities, you should be fine.
author: Bruce B.

description: I left home about a year ago and totally missed my mom's taiwanese cooking ~  I didn't think this would be a good place just cause taiwense food is just so totally obscure and the place looked like a hole in the wall.  But let me tell you, the food was delicious!  Especially the 'taiwanese entrees".  The bread they had in the window was my favorite part.  I suggest those and the taiwanese country styled spare ribs.  They were both a mix of sweet and salty.  My fave!  The prices are also super cheap and you can get a delicious crepe across the street right after!
author: Tiffany L.

description:
i've been trying to find dumplings like i'm used to in beijing and i've had a lot of trouble lately, even in this big city. i was surprised to find that this place had a great alternative. they've got a section in the menu that i believe is titled "northern specialties" and they've got some dumplings on there that are really fantastic. they're definitely spicy so be careful if you've got a sensitive palate. 

they've also got fry bread. another favorite of mine from way back in the day when i was living in beijing. i used to walk out my door every day and just around the corner there'd be tons of street food venders selling fry bread and bao zi. its definitely not good for you and soaked in oil but its really tasty actually. try it, i think one piece only costs something like a dollar fifty. 

try this place out. its great.
author: Georgia W.

description: One star for the Shanghai thick noodles. Everything else was bland (sauteed spinach), greasy (Tawain country ribs) or downright inedible (stir fried squid).
author: Yogi B.

description: Out of most of the restaurants on Clement this place seems to be the cheapest. I've eaten here twice and both times I've had pleasant experiences with the food and the servers. However there aren't too many things that stand out in this place. Very average.
author: Jordan A.

description: Excellent food, great prices, awesome customer service and right across from a terrific fresh tapioca drink place.   Parking could be a challenge being it's on clement but close to Muni Bus #38 and #2 line.
author: Ben L.

description:
I have lived in inner Richmond for 18 years.  Taiwan is my default Chinese restaurant.  I have never had a bad dish or bad experience here. The dumpings are excellent and most of dishes are great.  There are some selections that are a bit too authentic for a gweilo such as myself.  

I just wish they would take the flyers with random dishes and prices off the wall.  The menu is where this information should be!
author: Swaz E.

description: This place is near my work, so I eat here often.  The place looks like crap inside and outside, but the food is delicious.  Start with the steamed dumplings.  The dumplings are cooked when ordered, so it is fresh.  It is served with shredded ginger and you don't need soy sauce at all.  The spicy tofu is good but needs to be more on the softer side.  You can taste the tobacco which is good and it's served with minced pork.  The shrimps with snow peas and carrots is good too.  It has a starchy taste, which I love.  Beef soup with glass noodle is good to eat on a cold day.  It 's served with green veggies.  Very tasty.  Lastly, you have to definatly try the CRISPY SPARERIBS.  Omg, to die for.  Very tasty, big portion and crispy.  I never had crispy spareribs like this before. I brought my boyfriend here and he loves it.  So you to should try it out
author: marley b.

description: Mmmmm sesame meat paste noodles and spicy Szechuan noodles and yummyish dim sum.  I've eaten at Taiwan for over 10 years and for a real cheap satisfying meal of noodles this is it.  I also like the pan fried string beans.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
two stars is being generous.  i just ate there tonight after staying away for about 20 years.  they just reminded me why i stayed away.  taiwan restaurant USED to be good and even great at some point then things changed.  very disappointed with the food.  not much else to say but that it helped me remember why my friends and i stopped going there.  having the green onion pancakes be one of your better dishes is depressing if not morbid.  before i took a first bite into my "meat sauce over rice" a traditional taiwanese dish which ALL restaurants claiming to be of taiwanese influence should already have perfected since it's so simple...even before i touched my spoon my wife said "we are not coming back here again, they are lazy chefs".  she is right, they didn't use any pork belly meat in the meat sauce and it just look straight from a canned deal.  i would suggest "taste of formosa" farther down on clement or "tea garden" in the downtown area.

it will prolly be another 20 years before i listen to my wife and give taiwan restaurant a shot again.
i hated when i am hungry and get sucky food.....i just get pissed.
author: Ben L.

description:
Walked in thinking that I'd want to look at the menu before I sat down, but after taking a look ... the menu was varied and had a handful of things that just wouldn't be found elsewhere.

The Xiao Long Bao felt homemade and very tasty, the seasoning wasn't overly salty and just juicy enough.  I'd say it was comparable (albeit perhaps only better because of fresher ingredients) to food in Taiwan.  The Dan Dan Mian was delicious and definitely made in Taiwanese style rather than the Hong Kong style.  The turnip squares were quite delicious - among the better I've had for restaurant fare and the Scallion pancakes were different - a definitely deep-fried version that wasn't ringed in Cantonese style.  All in all, a definite restaurant I'd go back to.
author: Albert C.

description:
Food is really good, specially dumplings and string beans. Try out the eggplant dish as well. Not at all a fancy place but clean enough that the appearance will not kill your appetite. The best part is the price. If you want darn cheap good chinese food (but not your usual
MSG loaded food with boring choices) definitely make a visit here. Friendly staff is an added advantage.
author: Kingshuk g.

description: This place on 6th & Clement has been here for years & years.  The food is always fresh & always tasty !!   Not at all expensive (cheap !!) & very friendly service.  Try the dumplings which are made from scratch in the window or my favorite Taiwan County Favorite Spare Ribs.  This is the real thing as you will notice from the croud of locals eating here.  If you enjoy Chinese food this is the best place on Clement Street. One can pay alot more in other fancy places around San Francisco for Chinese cuisine but it won't be better.
author: mike d.

description: Probably the most inaccurate "Taiwanese" food that I have ever had. In addition to being terrible food, with no flavor or discernible difference from any other indiscriminate Chinese takeout restaurant, I have never seem more than 2 tables worth of people there, one of which is usually all the restaurant staff.
author: Shaina N.

description: OMG you guys, they totally have the cutest dish EVER!!!  Little rice UFO's with pork and cabbage.  For reals!
author: Jen S.

description: The #1 reason why I love it here is because they serve hot soy bean milk with chinese doughnut on a weekday!  Order the potstickers and remember to sweeten the soy milk with the sugar on the table.  Everything else is fairly decent.  Food is affordable, quick, and reliable.
author: Angie K.

description: There's no better place on Clement to have warm soy milk and a fresh chinese donut. The homemade dumplings are delicious, cheap & man-size here-- you can watch the cook in the window stuffing endless baskets of them during your short wait to be seated. This is a mom and pop operation, so I don't expect great service.  The thick Shanghai pan fried noodles are satisfying. I went here last week, and was amazed that their prices were still low and their portions huge.  If you don't mind being left alone to enjoy a big pile of food, then come here.
author: Miz J.

description:
i don't come here too often, but the dishes are always good when i do.  the waitress that took our order was very nice.  we ordered the green onion pancake, siu loong bow, hot and sour soup, and shanghai style chowmein.  everything was very tasty and my tastebuds were having a blast.  they also have yummy chinese donut and hot soymilk.

what i also like about this place is that you can see some of the guys making the chinese donuts in the front window.  it's fun to watch them if you're waiting for a table.
author: Lauren Y.

description: Come here for the lunch. Double cooked pork EXTRA spicy. $4.25. Happy.
author: k w.

description: If you are in the mood for traditional Taiwanese breakfast - fresh deep fried bread with homemade warm soy milk...this is the place to go ..This is also another great place for dumpling!  My favorites are the onion pancakes and wonton soup....The noodle dishes are also very hearty.  One downside - parking...nearly impossible.  Wait for a table can be longer on weekends...
author: Peter W.

description:
ive eaten here quite a few times.  my buddy loves it here and everytime we meet up he wants to come here.  i dont have the heart to tell him its not as good as he remembers it to be.  but i think last night he may have realized that.

the service is pretty good.  theyre really eager to serve you.  tea right when you sit down etc.  maybe because there arent that many people there.  but i almost feel bad saying something bad about it because they look like such nice people.

the food is really mediocre.  i usually order the bean thread noodles with fish balls and everytime i get it i finish it because i dont want to waste it not because its good.  the noodles break and have no elasticity.  theyre stale or something i cant tell what it is exactly.  last night i had the bean thread, or silver noodles, stir friend instead to see if they were better that way.  but still stale.  i didnt even bother finishing it.  ive ordered pork and tofu and also mixed vegetables here before too.  the tofu dish being way too oily and the vegetables being way too soft and covered with too much of the water and corn starch mixture.

my friends usually order the noodles with beef or pork.  they slurp all of it up.  but i think its because they are dudes and eat everything.
author: claudia y.

description: The dumplings are pretty good. They hand make them in the window! Also, I love the fried breads. Dip them in soy milk! I also like the tofu salad, and the shanghai noodles.
author: Bub B.

description:
Solid Chinese food for Chinese people. Had the beef noodle soup and it tasted almost like the soup in Taipei. Great dry fried string beans and dumplings as well. Huge portions, not overly salty and CHEAP!

They need to clean up the interior. Pink bare walls and dirty floors. 

Ambience *(*** for a Chinese restaurant)
Food *****
Value *****
author: T L.

description: I've eaten here twice now, and I feel both times were just so-so. We went with a big group so we ordered a variety of dishes, and none of them really stood out. I'm not Taiwanese, but a few in my group were and they thought the dishes were just so-so as well. The servers were friendly, but not very respectful. A server ran right into my back as I was drinking hot tea and almost burnt my tongue off, and I continued to get bumped over and over again at which point I consciously started dodging the servers.  I should probably take off another star for this, but I'm no drama queen.  Besides, it gave my friends a good laugh.  This place may receive 3 stars anywhere else, but not in this part of San Francisco where Chinese is everywhere.
author: Daniel L.

description:
This a classic staple of the City.  Cheap, consistent, delicious.  Been going there for over 10 years and I love taking east coasters here who have no idea what Asian food is supposed to taste like.  No other reviewers seem to mention the steamed dumplings (pork and chicken) that is the SIGNATURE of this place.  Those dudes in the window do nothing  but fire off dumplings all day.  That's what you must get at Taiwan.  The crispy spare ribs are off the hook too.  Totally unique.  

You can't go wrong here.  Just don't go for the decor.  Enjoy!
author: Peter J.

description:
heck yea!

the only problem with this place is that i don't know what to order. and it's very pink.

the food was great, the bill was cheap, and the service was not your typical crappy asian service (not that they were super nice or anything).

i can't recall everything we ate, but i do recall that i loved each dish.  we had some fat noodles, potstickers, beef noodle soup, etc...

p.s. it was also clean :)
author: Ameer N.

description: This is my favorite chinese restaurant................love the dim sum, the noodles and the mongolian beef is amazing..........
author: Dena S.

description: Oh what???  Flies!  Those pesky flies really got on my nerves.  The whole time, my friend and I were swatting flies.  Furthermore, the way they describe their food is totally different from what we actually got.  My friend inquired about their green onion pancake (normally pan fried) and what we got was deep fried batter with specks of green (which i'm assuming is the green onion) and my black bean noodles came no where close to what black bean noodles are suppose to be...I'd only go back for their jook (porridge).
author: Julie H.

description: Went here with a group of like 12 for dinner. They have a huge array of items to choose from. The food is affordable as well as tasty..9.1/10 tasty.
author: Prescott T.

description:
so the other day i was run down with a cold and knew that the only perfect comfort food that would hit the spot and nourish me right were chinese steamed veggie + meat buns (cai rou bao). 

cai rou bao from shan dong in oakland's chinatown, to be exact.

however, shan dong is closed on mondays.

so, the hunt was on for the perfect-as-can-be cai rou bao. 
i searched left and right, used all of my online research prowess, but to no avail. not even the folks on chowhound could help.

which led me back to the same question that often haunts me: why is san francisco barren of quality chinese food? what the hell does it take to get some downhome northern china lovin' around here?!!!

finally, i decided to give taiwan restaurant a try. i knew they had buns and made killer stuff out of dough, but was unsure of the regional stylings of their cai rou bao. 

well, after biting into the steamed bun, i must admit i was pleasantly surprised. the filling was a lovely, simple blend of ground meat, napa cabbage, clear noodles, mushrooms, and herbs. not bad at all!!

the dough was slightly sweet, but fluffy enough and contrasted well with the savory innards.

now i know where to get cai rou bao when i can't get them from shan dong.
author: jennifer y.

description: I decided to go here after reading a glowing review in the SF Examiner. We ordered what that the reviewer recommended, such as the hot boiled dumplings with porkand cabbage and the fried oysters. Well, the fried oysters were good, but nothing outstanding. They lacked that creamy ocean goo in the middle. The fried pork chop noodle soup was kind of bland, and the pork chop was too gristly for me. The boiled dumplings were nothing special.. just your average dumpling. I would not go here again.. also, the leftovers smell kind of funny in our fridge.
author: O K.

description: The various dumplings are tasty and fairly inexpensive, but the beef chow fun was mediocre at best. I'll give this place another chance based on it's reputation, but I was fairly unimpressed with my first visit.
author: Ziad E.

description:
from the outside and the inside, this place will not wow you with its decor.  but, i come here for the food, not the ambiance. 

now, if you're expecting non-greasy chinese food, you are SOL at 95% of chinese restaurants out there. this also depends largely on what you order, however. everything i've had here has never been overly oily or greasy, and i've liked all the items. a sample of dishes i've had recently:

- bean and meat sauce noodles :
great; my favorite dish here so far. Taiwan Restaurant does this dish VERY well, the best zha jiang mien i've had outside of Taiwan. this dish is also HUGE, as are all portions at this restaurant (this dish served me for 3 meals). the noodles were also excellent, chewy and fresh. 

- chinese doughnuts & hot soy milk:
good, not great (like all yiu tiao, too oily to be eaten often); the yiu tiao are very good, more doughy than normal, though i like that, and still retaining that crispy exterior; super fresh (i first walked in here b/c i saw the guys making them fresh in the window), and huge. the soy milk was ok; fresh, though you add your own sugar or salt to taste. i prefer when they add the flavoring, since the sugar incorporates better and faster. 

- pork dumplings:
solidly good; extremely fresh---they make them to order i believe (as in stuffing, wrapping, and steaming per order), and are ginormously stuffed to near-bursting. the skins are thicker than i like, but they're still very good. like eating mini pork&veggie buns. 

- pork chop fried rice:
really good; though, they don't include the stewed egg or ground pork stew here.  the pork chop is great (crisp, but juicy and tender, with a sweetish seasoning). also includes the requisite chopped mustard greens and my favorite, sour pickled veggies (i love these so much i wanted to ask for more on the side). 

- mustard greens & shredded pork noodle soup:
good; esp nice on a cold night. the broth is light but substantial, very clear flavors. noodles in this were great as well (i think they make anything using dough fresh in-house, there's just no accounting for that taste and texture).

this is a great place for inexpensive, tasty, fresh taiwanese food w/super generous portions. the service is decent, they're actually friendlier and more helpful than many chinese joints--- if you get the older waitresses (the younger ones, i think the kids of the owner? not so much. not that they're incompetent, just not as attentive and quick). those older ladies know what they're about. 

i only wish that (1) this place was closer to me (though SF is better than going to SJ, and waaay closer than LA), and (2) they would include tzo dofu and fan tuan on the menu here
author: L C.

description:
I eat here almost weekly for take-out so I am jaded but consistent.

Food is always good, clean, good serving size, hot, and fresh.

Some of our favorite - wan-ton soup, steamed chicken dumplings, snow peas + water chestnut + mushrooms, Mongolian beef, noodle with peanut sauce, \crispy spare ribs.
author: david s.

description: Very "home cooked meal" feel.  Not sure I want to know how they make the "country chicken", but it is tasty.  The staff are friendly.  A good neighborhood haunt.
author: Cristin O.

description: I love this place. Truly what I would call comfort food. Regardless what mood I'm in, I've never turned down the idea of going there!
author: Annabel N.

description: I like their pork chop noodle soup!  I always order that dish.  I also like "fish flavor chiken".  They have taiwanese dishes and they are also good. I usually don't order those, though...  Their pot stickers are good.  Surprisingly all of their food servers were very nice.
author: Mike M.

description: I love this place, I've been coming here since I was a kid. They have the best "dan dan mien" that I've ever tasted. and these dumplings called "xiao lung bao" (sorry don't know the english name), and they're awesome too. You can't really go wrong with whatever you order. And a major plus to this place, is it's dirt cheap and the portions are ginormous!!!
author: Lynette R.

description: I'm so glad I found this place!  They have the real authentic Taiwanese food and I just love going there on the weekends!  The restaurant is not very big but you can still do walk-ins if you go early.
author: JenJen W.

description: Maybe I didn't order the right things, maybe it was the fact that i just about fought my four year old niece for the last prawn out of the chow mien only for me to let her win, her eat and then regurgitate it because she "didn't liiiiike it" but I rate Taiwan a mediocre experience and food. However while writing this, I did upgrade from two stars to three stars because after recalling the leftover chow mien and sweet and sour chicken (I know, truly unadventurous, keep in mind we had a four year old with us) the leftovers were noteworthy! Maybe it was the lack of four year old company that made the second meal, out of red and white boxes, just that much more enjoyable.
author: Jenny T.

description: Great food, good prices, really no complaints - it's not amazing or mind-blowing, but definitely a good standby. I always get the garlic string beans and taiwanese special spareribs when I come here - soo good. As others have mentioned the place is clean which is great.
author: Sung P.

description: My family really likes this place...I think it's all right. It's not the best food but it's nowhere near the worst. Prices are decent and the broths for the soups are good but, other than that, it's just chinese food.
author: Tiff L.

description: The main thing that sticks in my mind about this place is that the sweet soy milk is absolutely delicious.  Perfect for dipping donuts at breakfast-- so refreshing!
author: Hallie M.

description: This place is pretty good AND cheap. I love the dumplings, and I always order the thick noodles (not sure the exact name, but it seriously makes me laugh when I have to order them). They are really good. I think they have beef, chicken, and shrimp in one delicious noodle dish. I usually go with a group and its usually $15 per person max. I've never had to wait to be seated either.
author: Jennie B.

description: This place hasn't really been the same since the change of ownership about 2 years ago.  But I still love it.  I been coming here since when I was a toddler.  They have the best Chinese donuts, and their potstickers are all homemade in the display window.  You gotta have the General Tsuo's Chicken, Spicy Shrimp, and green onion pancake.  The hot and sour soup is pretty good too.
author: Alan N.

description: My favorite Chinese food in the city.  Try: Won Ton Soup, pot stickers, Taiwanese Country Fried Spare ribs.  The vegetables are cooked al dente so it is not a vegetable mush.
author: Liz G.

description: I'm not quite as well versed in Chinese cuisine as Bruce down there, but I know good General Tso chicken and this place has it. I've been frequenting Taiwan Restaurant for almost 12 years now and my worst complaint is inconsistency. Friday night might bring big juicy cuts of battered and fried chicken pieces covered in thick, glistening sauce while Tuesday afternoon may bring non-battered scraps in something more watered down. The dumplings and doughnuts are good everyday and who can beat lunch for two for under 15 bucks. All menu items featured on the walls seem to be the bread and butter. The wait staff can be curt but my meal is always promptly served and the takeout flexibility is clutch. Give it a second chance.
author: Christopher V.

description: I  would have to say that Taiwan Restaurant is  my favorite Chinese/Taiwanese lunch place.  They provide great service and great food, especially their dumplings and noodles soups - always fresh and hot. Every time I go there, it brings back memories of when I lived in Taiwan.  I love the fact that I can eat the food that I grew up with right here on Clement Street.
author: Stephanie D.

description: this place was a godsend during my vegetarian year. tons of meat-free selection. best comfort food ever; makes me wish i were chinese so maybe my grandmother would know how to cook this deliciousness at home. always seems to be filled with large families and their adorable little kids who run around the restaurant like monkeys. i don't mind at all. i've been considering going into elementary education and eating here feels like training.
author: Jane P.

description: It had been a restaurant I liked to go until most recently when I ordered "Jiao Zi" - hand made dumplings. The came out with skin all broken therefore they were soggy. I complaint to the waitress. She said: "We froze them therefore they are like this. There is no way that they aren't broken. " I said :"but they don't taste good." She walked away saying;"we can't go nothing." Thanks for reading...I am just sharing...
author: Vat S.

description: i'm chinese, parents grew up in taiwan...i've been a few times...maybe i'm out of practice at being chinese...but the menu at taiwan restaurant completely overwhelmed me.  i had no idea what to order...and just started pointing at other people's tables and saying "give me that!"  the waitress didn't seem to mind, though...so, this place is cool with me!  i need to come back with my mom so she can do the ordering for me.
author: Tabatha Y.

description: OK, so it's not the fanciest, cleanest, trendiest restaurant in The City, or even on Clement street for that matter. But it's also NOT the most expensive, blandest, unimaginative Chinese food in the area. Pretty much every other table will have the shredded pork with mustard greens noodle soup and the braised green beans, and yours should too. The prices are incredibly cheap for the quality of the food. Service is good to very good, but no frills of course. Not 5 stars because some dishes can vary from visit to visit.
author: Brian O.

description: Taiwan Restaurant is one of the best food bargains in San Francisco, bar none. A tasty and generous meal for two can be had for well under $15. Fill up on dumplings, because they're the real standout here, along with everything else made in tiny front kitchen that looks out on this international stretch of Clement Street. Standouts include delicate boiled shrimp and leek dumplings and picture-perfect kuo teh. Steamed pork buns are enormous and contain a portion of savory ground pork, not the sticky-sweet BBQ pork to which one is accustomed. Red cooked eggplant and dry braised green beans make for delicious side dishes, and the General Tso's chicken is a unique take on the dish, but far and away my favorite. The bright pink bi-level room is bizarrely dramatic but ultimately charmless. If you can get here for lunch, lunch combinations are less than $5 and include soup, your choice of entree, rice, and orange slices for dessert.
author: Jon L.

description: I always order the same two things from the menu (onion pancakes and what i refer to as: rice noodle saucers) and get them to go. This time though, I ate at the restaurant. I wasn't paying attention when our friend was ordering so I don't know the names of the dishes that were ordered. I do know that the tofu dish and the noodle soups were not very impressive. The string beans were actually pretty good, but let's face it. No matter how good they are, veggies can never make up for the rest of the meal. The onion pancakes appetizer was definitely the favorite.
author: Nicole N.

description: I'm not Chinese, Taiwanese, or any other "ese".......  I'm a white dude who likes to eat.  I do not particularly enjoy Panda Express or any Chinese combo meal featuring egg rolls, fried shrimp and sweet and sour soup.  If you are a fan of either of these things, then Taiwan Restaurant may not be for you.  What I do enjoy is the wonderful flavors and generous portions that I receive.  A few favorites are the lamb with onions and the green beans with meat.  They have dim sum items as well, but I usually stick to the entrees at Taiwan restaurant and grab some take-out dim sum down the street at Wing Lee.
author: Adam L.

description: Today, I took my parents here for lunch as this is my ultimate test for any Chinese restaurant. We had soy milk, potstickers, Chinese donuts, and beef tendon noodle soup. Everything was very tasty. The best thing was that there wasn't a single complaint from my parents which meant the food was pretty authentic. The place was clean compared to other Chinese restaurants. I can't wait to go back and try more.
author: Chanli S.

description: This menu looked promising, with lots of items I hadn't seen before; however, the experience was very disappointing.  I hate to waste food, but no one at our table took more than the initial taste of the sauteed baby squid, and we certainly weren't going to take the rest home: it was neither fresh nor freshly cooked, just old and hard.  The dumplings were freshly made, but like everything else, bland.
author: Sumomo O.

description: just hook me up with an order (or two) of the xiao long bao and the green onion pancake and i'm good.
author: Craig I.

description: The dumplings... one look when they got to the table and I knew the skins were too thick.  The filling was... meh.  Had the steamed pork dumplings (xiao long bao) and there was more cabbage than pork.  Also had the veggie ones as well, too much pickled mustard greens and not too much else in them.  Had the beef tendon noodle soup which was good, the tendon was very tender.
author: win c.

description: i'm not a huge fan of chinese food but my friends and i came here on saturday evening, armed with boba drinks from up the street. s was starved so we got a lot of food. a lot. and it was still only $50 somethng! that was a meal for 4 people plus leftovers. i had the velvet chicken which was pretty tasty. the general chao (sp?) chicken was good too... some beef thing ok, and the potstickers, eggrolls, lo mein, hot and sour soup,... but my very favorite was the pork buns. they were stuffed with meat and so filling and tasty. next time if i ever went again id get a full order of just those! good customer service, a guy even came back to check about sesame allergies since we were allergic to peanuts. none of us loved the potstickers actually.  and s was eh on the beef and noodles. but overall a pretty good chinese food place. nothing really special.
author: Merredith L.

description: Some of the Taiwanese dishes here hardly resemble the real stuff.  The bigger problem is they don't even taste too good.  I am not one to say everything has to be "authentic" as long as it's tasty. I welcome innovation or improvements over the original dishes; if you can't even come up with something that taste remotely like what it should be, you should not be making it.
author: Steve C.

description: soymilk, sweet & savory. the savory soymilk doesn't come curdling (i.e., thicknening into a loose tofu-like mixture) like it's supposed to be - so if you want it how it's supposed to be, you'll have to add a few drops of vinegar and it'll be curdling in no time. drop in some youtiao (fried dough) to suck it all up.
author: Lijia X.

description: one of my favorite chinese restaurants in the city--the crispy prawns here are mind blowing. also worthy of consideration are the green beans (with minced pork), hot and sour soup, and general's chicken. oh, the szechuan beef is top notch.
author: dusty d.

description: since the change of ownership, the food from the kitchen has been so salty. good thing they kept the dim sum chef in the front. only thing I still like are the potstickers, soy milk, and deep fry goodies at the window.
author: Katie K.

description: ate here tonight and was happy with the great prices and decent food.  you definitely have to try the onion pancakes.  i can make this a taiwanese girl's regular outing from now on.  and i got great, fast, efficient service.
author: Jennifer D.

description: Craving freshly made dumplings?  Authentic chinese/taiwanese eats?  Look no further!  These are the best dumplings I've had since I left the PRC.  Never been to Taiwan but eating Taiwan's food makes me want to make it my next foodie destination.  Think: Shanghai style dumplings with the succulent pork with the perfect melt in your mouth pocket of juices and not to thick not too thin outside texture.   Finding a good source for these is like uhm...finding parking on Clement on a Friday night.  I think they call these dumplings just plain pork steam dumplings on the menu.  The mustard greens pork noodles are great as well as the special taiwan pork spare ribs.  The take out service is great too.  They pack it well enough to preserve your car from sauce spills.  Be sure to ask for the vinegar sauce for your dumplings.  While you're waiting for your food check out the cool fish pet store next door.
author: Ann F.

description: Very good , cheap, yummy potstickers, green bean and hot and sour. Not the cleanest wall or greatest ambiance, but who cares.
author: B D.

description: We've always walked pass this place and have always wondered if their food was authentic Taiwan flavor. Finally decided to try it a couple of weeks ago. Love the crispy ribs and won ton soup. Authentic Taiwan taste for the crispy ribs. I recommend this place if you want chinese food that's different from the usual chinese flavor.
author: J C.

description: I just got back from a hike in Mt. Tam and wanted some warm soup and Wor Won Ton Soup sounded so good.  Problem is that I hadn't found a good Chinese restaurant since I've moved here almost 3 years ago!?!  I was always worried about picking a wrong restaurant, but I turned to Yelp and found this place.  I called in for Take-Out and ordered the shrimp chow mein, dry braised green beans, lemon chicken and rice.  He said it would be ready in 10 min.  I left the house immediately, especially since finding parking is nearly impossible on Clement.  My BF found a spot out in front, and the food wasn't ready yet.  The food was ready in about 15 min (not 10 min), but it was worth the weight.  The soup was so good and authentic. It had 2 shrimps in it.  The chow mein was good and had 5 shrimps, but were big pieces.  The beans were good, too.  The rice was dry, and the lemon chicken was so-so.  I'd go back and order the soup again and the beans.  I finally found a good and reliable Chinese place!  P.S.  Check the cartons when you look in the bag, most of it had opened when I got home, and my BF spilled the green beans on the table.
author: Jen C.

description:
won ton soup -- good
mu shi pork --- terrible
steamed dumplings (beef) -- ok
fried spring rolls -- ok

service -- good

we didn't eat all of the food and refused to take it home -- bad sign.
author: M F.
