description: Cheap, good, friendly, clean, AND not too greasy.  Taiwanese food is great. Looooove the steamed chicken dumplings.  And the noodles, get the noodles. You can see the chefs making the dough as you come in too.  I could eat here for a while and not get tired of it, which I can't say the same for a lot of chinese restaurants.
author: Priscilla P.

description:
let me start by saying this food is very good and not that expensive. i loooove the food at this restaurant and have taken all my friends and family here. i would have to say that they are one of the best restraurants on clement...until now...


The restraunt food is unfortunately not that clean.  one day a friend and i went to this restraunt for dinner. expecting to receive our favorite taiwan dishes steaming hot, we noticed, after taking a few bites, that the food had a piece of hair in it! we pointed it out to the waitress, a very nice and understanding lady, who quickly rushed the dish to the kitchen and demanded a new one to be delivered to us. as she apologized and brought forth the new dish,  we began to eat it again.as i was tasting and chewing on the food she brought forth i noticed a sponge-like felling in my mouth. i didnt want to know what it was that i was feeling in my mouth because i knew if it was foreign to what was suppose to be in that dish, i would NEVER come back to this restraunt. i spat out the food, pulling from my plate a piece of steel wool-like sponge that they use for cleaning their woks and pans! 
very very dissapointed, that my favorite taiwanese restraunt had such things like hair and steel wool in their food i got up and told the hostess/waitress to come to the table. i pointed it out to her and she had nothing to say. to conclude, she canceled the dish off our bill but unfortunately it left me with the imprint to never go back to this restraunt and to deem the restraunt dirty!


beware as the food is good but might have "foreign" disgusing stuff in the food!!!!!!!1111
author: alex a.

description: I recommend this place.  It's kind of a hole in the wall restaurant, but the value is there.  You can have a good meal feeding two or three with less than $20.  Don't forget the potstickers and the soy milk.  The soy milk is made fresh.  The shanghai noodles are good too.  The pork chop over rice is tasty too.  They deep fry the pork job.
author: Amy V.

description: Good, solid, inexpensive Chinese food. Noisy, casual and family friendly.
author: John S.

description:
we just got out of this place an it was good.  according to my Taiwanese gf  the oyster pancake was not very authentic according to her albeit high standards.  my favorite food was the Taiwanese doughnut deep fried.  they serve it with your choice of salty or sweet soy milk.  i preferred to try the Sweet as the doughnut was really quite salty enough.  they served it bland which i thought was odd but easily remedied as i just added sugar and stirred.  that was my favorite item that we had today.  and i hadn't seen anything like that before anywhere else in San Fran.
I tried the oyster pancake... not for me i must say.  there was a gelatinous layer of what appeared to be a cornstarch mixture that was a little to close to slime for my liking.  i also have a a little bit more than a strong aversion to anything fishy to cross my palate as this would serve as my breakfast.  i also had the Taiwanese country spare ribs which i thought were tasty however again according to my gf not up to true Taiwanese standard.  she felt they were more Chinese than Taiwanese but good nonetheless.  
the steamed pork dumpling was good and the sticky rice with pork on top was good.  notice a theme here?  had it not been my first meal of the day there were actually a lot of items on the menu that looked interesting to me for example the 5 spice tripe soup and other Taiwanese dishes that are A little off the beaten path for a white guy like me.  overall we all 4 stuffed ourselves for 26 bucks with tip.  you don't get more bang for he buck here in the city and i am actually looking forward to dinner one day.
author: Anthony Y.

description: if you are around during the lunch hours this place is a steal. i love the dishes here.  pot stickers, broccoli beef and chicken are delicious.  you also get soup, orange for lunch for like $3.50 to 4 dollars.  nice hole in the wall.
author: Kevin M.

description: don't get the chinese donuts, they're hard and tough and not very good, but everything else was delicious, just takes a while.... the wait on the weekends... and they run out of certain things, like the daikon cakes... but still, very good
author: Janet P.

description: i have been going to this restaurant for many years now.  used to come here pretty often.  so much so that one of the chefs that makes the potstickers and shanghai dumplings would remember what we ordered each time and prepare our potstickers as soon as we sat down.  had a major craving for shanghai dumplings after i came back from my trip to china, so i thought i'd try to relive the memory of eating shanghai dumplings in shanghai by coming to taiwan restaurant.  i've never been disappointed by this restaurant before, but nothing compares to eating REAL shanghai dumplings in shanghai.  unfortunately, when i took a bite of my shanghai dumpling, it didn't bring me back to shanghai.  don't get me wrong, it was still good, but it just didn't compare to my experience in shanghai.  i guess i somehow was tainted by the experience of eating REAL shanghai dumplings and now nothing else will compare.  overall, taiwan is a good place to eat potstickers, their noodle dishes are tasty and cheap, and their lunch specials (that are only served during weekdays) are well worth the price.  some suggestions to try would be their mustard green and pork soup noodles, szechuan hot sauce noodles, pork chop noodle soup, bean and meat sauce noodle, potstickers (of course) and of course the shanghai dumplings.
author: Jeannie W.

description: so, i've only been to this restaurant a couple of times...each time to pick up their fried doughnuts.  so, my comments are going to be conflicting because i don't think that this place has the best anything.  so, why go here more than once?  well, because my husband is always driving nearby...so more for convenience.  for those that like the potstickers, steamed dumplings (xiao long baos), soy bean milk, deep fried chinese doughnuts, go one block down towards Geary Boulevard.  Five Happiness Restaurant (near the corner of Geary and 6th avenue) serves all these authentic dishes, only it tastes WAY better!
author: Jenny Y.
